CPU Temperature Indicator
Comment_Body: @Padre2 Next time mention me, please: @claudiux. I will try to install Arch on a real machine, not a virtual one, to debug this.

Name: CPU Temperature Indicator
Comment_Body: @claudiux  After further checking I can confirm that this CPU temperature applet is displaying the GPU temperature in the panel. This is the last sensor (2nd temp1) in the following list: sensor.log S,lmsensor it8720-isa-0228 temp1,101 S,lmsensor it8720-isa-0228 temp2,101 S,lmsensor it8720-isa-0228 temp3,101 S,lmsensor radeon-pci-0100 temp1,101  This is further confirmed by checking on same machine running Manjaro OS with Cinnamon 4.2.4, which only displays the (same) GPU temperature.  Also, if I load the  gputemperature@silentage.com applet, it only displays the same GPU temperature values on both Arch and Manjaro.  I do not leave this applet running as it displays a  _not compatible warning_  on loading and crashes Cinnamon from time to time.  I posted the issue several days ago, but have had no response from @silentage.com. My priority would be to get the GPU temperature running rather than the CPU, because I never overclock and have not had any CPU overheating issues.

Name: Weather UUID: weather@mockturtl
Comment_Body: weather@mockturtl With 1 instance loaded and **+** still showing in white colour, clicking the **+** changes the applet into the loading icon and adds a 2nd loading icon and the computer freezes (see attached photo), requiring Ctrl+Alt+Esc/Del to reboot . On rebooting, it has many multiple instances across the panel (see attachment). I cannot understand why it is necessary to allow multiple instances for this applet. As far as I am aware, other applets change the **+** and **-** from white to grey or vice versa after using and only permit loading 1 instance as, I believe was was the case before. ![Weather_2x_loading_freezing](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38849451/69794917-bfc55480-11fd-11ea-85d2-552d21e34a42.jpg) ![Multiple_weather after_freezing_2019-11-28 15-59-53](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38849451/69795445-cbfde180-11fe-11ea-9289-67900b56afed.png)

Comment_Body: weather@mockturtl Sorry, was closed. Must have clicked the wrong button

Comment_Body: It was limited to 3 applets (for multiple places). I do not know why it is not enforced (anymore? I never really checked).

Name: Weather UUID: weather@mockturtl
Comment_Body: @Gr3q  weather@mockturtl The issue right now is that clicking **+** more than once on Cinnamon 4.4 will try to install a second instance and the computer will freeze, per my message 4 days ago. Are you looking at this issue, or is anyone else taking care of this applet?

Name: Weather UUID: weather@mockturtl
Comment_Body: I'm working on the applet the most this year.  I looked into it, adding multiple instances in quick succession does not freeze Cinnamon for me, but both the ability to freeze and able to spam the button is there.  The limit actually not working is not exclusive to this applet, it seems it only works if its set to 1.  I think the problem is with the 'Applets' Cinnamon settings at this time, you should create an issue in the main cinnamon repo. (about failing on limiting and allowing to spam the + button)

Name: Weather UUID: weather@mockturtl
Comment_Body: @Gr3q  I changed the max-instance from 3 to 1 in the metadata.json file and it fixes the issue. I tried to open a PR, but new to GitHub have never used before. Can you take a look? I see no reason why more than one instance would ever be needed in the Cinnamon panel.

Comment_Body: You need to install the translations.  If you cloned this repo, open a terminal: ``` cd <path/to/cinnamon-spices-applets> ./cinnamon-spices-makepot weather@mockturtl --install ```  This will install the new translations. Then restart cinnamon _(or your computer)_

Name: Why have some Spices lost stars ???
Comment_Body: @claudiux I believe stars expire after 1 year, albeit it needs someone to give a star for the count to adjust down to reflect the expired stars. I don't really like this behaviour either, as I think the star system is relatively hard to discover for new users. In an ideal world I'd like end users to be able to give stars directly from the relevant Cinnamon settings modules, or a mechanism to be introduced to count downloads.

Name: mem-monitor-text Inconsistent RAM occupation
Comment_Body: Being tired with it, I fiddled around with the code and found the solution.  The new update function of the applet.js file of **mem-monitor-text**:  ```js _update: function() {         try {             GTop.glibtop_get_mem(this.gtop);             this.maxmem = this.gtop.total;             this.user = this.gtop.user;              let percent = Math.round((this.user * 100) / this.maxmem);             this.set_applet_label(this.mem_label + " " + percent.toString().slice(-3) + "%");             this.set_applet_tooltip(_("Click to open Gnome system monitor"));         }         catch (e) {             global.logError(e);         }          Mainloop.timeout_add(2000, Lang.bind(this, this._update));     }, ```  I'm a noob regarding to contributing in open source project, what do I do now? A pull request? Could someone help me with this?  Thank you

Comment_Body: A pr would be great. Name: gmail@lauritsriple : Not working on Linux Mint 19.1
Comment_Body: I am working on a new release with better error handling, but for now, could you try to run `seahorse` and see if your username and password has been added to the keyring? They should be under the default keyring with the description: mailnotifier. You can filter/search for this inside seahorse.  This error comes from the python script (getGmailFeedJson.py) either finding a blank or no password from the keyring or it fails later when it attempts to do the HTTP request. You can run this script manually to test correct username/password after changing the applet settings with `~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/gmail@lauritsriple/getGmailFeedJson.py yourusername` . Note that the error output is not as descriptive as it should be, but a new release is coming shortly.  If you have 2-step verification enabled follow the steps in the [readme](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/gmail%40lauritsriple/README.md) that was recently updated by @smurphos (Thank you)  From the readme:  _You might have to enable access for less secure apps in gmail_. Test in your browser if you have access with one of these links. https://mail.google.com/mail/feed/atom or https://username:password@mail.google.com/mail/feed/atom  Enabling access for less secure apps can be done here: https://myaccount.google.com/u/0/lesssecureapps  Let me know how it goes.

Name: gmail@lauritsriple : Not working on Linux Mint 19.1
Comment_Body: I have enabled access for less secure apps and the issue is still there. I have checked seahorse and my Gmail username and password is available under the default keyring. I have installed the dependencies using apt and not using pip3. Does this create any issue?

Name: gmail@lauritsriple : Not working on Linux Mint 19.1
Comment_Body: I can't think of any issues that can come of installed via apt instead of pip.  Which version of the python libraries are you using?  Can you provide python version of your default python? `python --version` Hopefully you will get output version which is python3, e.g python 3.7.3  Try the following to see that python can retrieve your password (change yourgmailusername to your gmail username. The part before @gmail.com): python -c "import keyring; print(keyring.get_password('mailnotifier','yourgmailusername'))"  Please try: `~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/gmail@lauritsriple/getGmailFeedJson.py yourgmailusername` It should output a json message with either an error or the unread emails in your gmail inbox.

Name: gmail@lauritsriple : Not working on Linux Mint 19.1
Comment_Body: `python --version` gives `Python 2.7.15+`  Python 3 is also installed on my system and I can access it via `python3` command.  `python3 --version` gives `Python 3.6.8`  I think both versions are installed on Ubuntu 18.04 and I have to use `python3` to use python 3.  `python -c "import keyring; print(keyring.get_password('mailnotifier','mygmailusername'))"` gives following error  `Traceback (most recent call last):   File "<string>", line 1, in <module> ImportError: No module named keyring`  and `python3 -c "import keyring; print(keyring.get_password('mailnotifier','mygmailusername'))"`  gives my password as output.  I also request you to consider Oauth2 authentication so that users don't have to enable "Less Secure Apps Access" on their Google account.

Name: gmail@lauritsriple : Not working on Linux Mint 19.1
Comment_Body: I just tried from a fresh install. Ran the following after the install: `sudo apt-get install python3 python3-keyring python3-feedparser`  Then I installed the applet, added my username and password. Created a keyring when prompted, and it seems to be working.  Mint 19.1 Cinnamon 4.0.8 Linux 4.15.0.20-generic  I am considering to change to Oauth2.  Please try: `~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/gmail@lauritsriple/getGmailFeedJson.py yourgmailusername` It should output a json message containing your emails.

Name: gmail@lauritsriple : Not working on Linux Mint 19.1
Comment_Body: `~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/gmail@lauritsriple/getGmailFeedJson.py gmailusername`  gives the following error  `{"info": "Search the web or create issue on git", "error": "Python can't import FancyURLopener from urllib.request"}`

Name: gmail@lauritsriple : Not working on Linux Mint 19.1
Comment_Body: Found the cause of this issue. My Gmail password contained a question mark and this was causing issues with feedparser. I have changed my password and the extension is working fine now.

Name: Spices website: old versions of applets being downloaded
Comment_Body: @claudiux Unfortunately I think that the issue is still present. Yesterday I downloaded Spices Update applet using the steps I described when the [pull request](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/2482) was opened. Today the pull request is merged into master. Then I download the applet again with `Download` button I get cached version. `metadata.json` file still has `"version": "2.0.0"` in it. The same happens when I installed the applet today through `Applets` system app. Can you reproduce the above steps with the website for an opened pull request ?

Name: Spices website: old versions of applets being downloaded
Comment_Body: @cardsurf Ok, I see. If you use the Download button, which links to https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/files/applets/SpicesUpdate@claudiux.zip, then a cached version of this zip file is downloaded.  But, if you add a question mark at the end of this URL, that forces the server to send the latest version: [https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/files/applets/SpicesUpdate@claudiux.zip?](https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/files/applets/SpicesUpdate@claudiux.zip?)  @clefebvre Is it possible to add this question mark at the end of the Download button link?

Name: Spices website: old versions of applets being downloaded
Comment_Body: For cinnamon-settings, https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon/pull/8746 solves this issue.  For the Download button of the Spices web site, the problem is still present: ![Capture du 2019-08-04 18-58-59](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/33965039/62426849-8adf4000-b6ea-11e9-886f-233763dbe15c.png) You can see that this applet was updated 22 hours ago and that the downloaded zip file is 6 months old.

Name: gputemperature@silentage.com: only basic info shown with AMDGPU and only visible from top panel
Comment_Body: Hello, @some-username-here1.  > Limited to basic function...  That's the expected output for your hardware. What you see in the screenshot from the Cinnamon Spices website for this applet is the output of an nVidia card, [which the applet gathers using the `nvidia-settings` command](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/gputemperature%40silentage.com/files/gputemperature%40silentage.com/applet.js#L194). In your case, using an ATI card, the applet gathers only the cards' temperature [by parsing the output of the `sensors` command](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/gputemperature%40silentage.com/files/gputemperature%40silentage.com/applet.js#L95).  > Limited visibility to the top panel...  The applet is not multi-instance. There can be only one instance of the applet placed on any panel. And even if it were set to be multi-instance, [it isn't initialized as such](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/gputemperature%40silentage.com/files/gputemperature%40silentage.com/applet.js#L886).  > Cinnamon warning about the applet with...  That's just a warning. It is triggered by the applet using some function calls using synchronous operations (`GLib.spawn_command_line_sync`).

Name: gputemperature@silentage.com: only basic info shown with AMDGPU and only visible from top panel
Comment_Body: Oh, thanks for the clarification. About the second thing, though, is that I don't mean it in having more than one instance of it, sorry for the confusion on that, but having it on the bottom taskbar instead of the top doesn't allow it to be shown when clicked on: Top: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34193156/59318110-c45f7600-8c7a-11e9-9f0c-b8af887a56e0.png) Bottom (I did try clicking on it, but nothing came up from it): ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/34193156/59318230-1e603b80-8c7b-11e9-9d53-53b77aef979a.png) unless this was intentional? and I would fix this if I knew how to code, but I'm still an amateur on it

Name: gputemperature@silentage.com: only basic info shown with AMDGPU and only visible from top panel
Comment_Body: > unless this was intentional?  No, it isn't intentional. What happens is that the applet code hasn't been updated (its functional parts at least) in more than three years. More than 6 mayor Cinnamon versions have existed since then. And a lot of changes in core functionality.  Your problem could be that the applet doesn't handle orientation changes (moving the applet from the top to the bottom). Try restarting Cinnamon after you place the applet in the bottom panel. That might restore its functionality.

Comment_Body: I had the same issue on Linux Mint 19.1 and managed to solve it with the tips from the [Cinnamon Spices site](https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/applets/view/131). So `sudo apt install sox` did the trick.

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu - spamming xsession-errors
Comment_Body: I got these xsession-errors too and hoped you got them (I'm assuming) like me, by running teamspeak, but this doesn't seems to be the case. Currently I can't reproduce this error anymore, BUT the same error appears by using Grouped Window Lists and i.e. closing an applet window, which never were in the foreground and thus no thumbnail got rendered.  The message clearly states something (an icon) got referenced, which isn't there anymore. Does these errors appear after every restart or after quite some hours?  Could you please try to close the programs in your systray one after another and try to find out if a specific program causes those error messages?  Another approach would be to save your collapsible-systray config, uninstall and reinstall it and set up everything again.  If you tried both steps or already tried them on your own, we need to dig depper. Also keep in mind collapsible-systray isn't actively developed for quite some time. (just some version number updates by asking the author for it - he is very busy)

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu - spamming xsession-errors
Comment_Body: Hi,  I've actually reinstalled Cinnamon on a fresh machine since posting the original issue and set up the applet from scratch. The start-up errors are consistent on every login or Cinnamon restart and are reported prior any systray icons loading. The applet is trying to populate it's menu of currently inactive icons when it's producing the errors.  Expanding the applet's menu also produces different errors. repeated occurrences of  (cinnamon:1849): Clutter-WARNING **: 06:51:16.251: clutter-actor.c:10055: Actor 'StBoxLayout' tried to allocate a size of -8.00 x 22.00  All of this is with Indicator support off.

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu - spamming xsession-errors
Comment_Body: With Indicator support on with Cinnamon 4.2 I'm no longer getting the errors on hide/show icons. But there are other breakages - Chrome's icon does not display with Indicator support on and the nm-applet icon doesn't deactivate as it should with the network manager applet installed, but also doesn't actually display an icon. Whether this is an applet or a Cinnamon issue I'm unsure. I'll test with the stock systray at some point.

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu - spamming xsession-errors
Comment_Body: Depending your second comment: NM-Applet works without problems for me, chrome/chromium probably too, but I'm not using it. Did you tried to move the nm-applet to collapsible-systray? Spoiler: I think this will cause problems since this feature isn't fully implemented yet. Currently I'm using both systray-applets. I didn't added applets like nm, sound, power, energy-control and  screenshot+recorder to collapsible systray and didn't got such errors so far.  The applet with the yellow underline is the "spacer" between collapsible-systray and normal systray in the picture below:  ![](https://i.imgur.com/jMptF99.png)

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu - spamming xsession-errors
Comment_Body: I think you misunderstand. Network Manager provides a systray icon. The network manager applet if active on a panel should hide the systray icon (i.e in collapsible systray it should be listed as inactive). That appears to be broken with collapsible systray in 19.2 but only with indicator support on. The network manager systray icon is listed as active, but just displays a space. This doesn't appear to be an issue with regular stock systray applet.

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu - spamming xsession-errors
Comment_Body: Ah well, you're right, I didn't noticed so far. I deactivated my nm-applet now, but didn't got errors.  I will test this further and see if some errors occur later.

Name: openweathermap data not accurate for Australia
Comment_Body: Hello,  I agree, BBC weather data is accurate, when they provide data.  For example, Cambridge haven't had current weather observations for the whole last weekend in their rss feed, and they often omit weather conditions from there too.  I'd like to include it but it may end up more unreliable than the others.  The other option is that I can fill up the holes from the forecast data, but it will be less accurate that way.    Bit more technical stuff: The best would be get the data from the HTML page (would need care often because webpages change constantly) but I can't find a JS HTML parser, or have hard time convert one to be usable. Probably looking at the wrong places.   Its really easy to do in Python (might need dependencies...) , but the only way I know to get the data back into JavaScript from Python atm is write/read files, what I really don't want to do.

Name: openweathermap data not accurate for Australia
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @Gr3q  > ...but the only way I know to get the data back into JavaScript from Python atm is write/read files...  You could look at the Feeds Reader applet for [how does it calls a Python script](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/feeds%40jonbrettdev.wordpress.com/files/feeds%40jonbrettdev.wordpress.com/feedreader.js#L134) to get [the return data](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/feeds%40jonbrettdev.wordpress.com/files/feeds%40jonbrettdev.wordpress.com/getFeed.py#L96).  It basically does this:  ```javascript Util.spawn_async(["python-script.py", "arg1", "arg2"], (aStdout) => {     let data = aStdout; }); ```  Even Cinnamon does it this way to open a Save/Open file dialog from JavaScript code (the [fileDialog.js](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/blob/master/js/misc/fileDialog.js) module uses the [cinnamon-file-dialog Python script](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/blob/master/files/usr/bin/cinnamon-file-dialog)).  For my own fork of the weather applet, I looked into the BBC Weather feeds to see if it would be worth it to include a dependency to `feedparser` (the Python module that the Feeds Reader applet uses). But I dimmed it not worthy at all (look at their [Forecast response](https://weather-broker-cdn.api.bbci.co.uk/en/forecast/rss/3day/2643123) and [Current weather response](https://weather-broker-cdn.api.bbci.co.uk/en/observation/rss/2643123)).

Name: openweathermap data not accurate for Australia
Comment_Body: @Gr3q, you can check out whether [nodejs-htmlparser2](https://github.com/fb55/htmlparser2) could be implemented somehow.

Name: openweathermap data not accurate for Australia
Comment_Body: @cranes-bill Even if I could, I'm not sure if it's not a too big tradeoff. That module has 8 files, and 6+4 dependencies. Include that into the applet would be a huge overkill. I was actually looking at [this](https://github.com/blowsie/Pure-JavaScript-HTML5-Parser).   @Odyseus bbcwx has a pure JS XML parser (marknote) so I can use that for RSS feeds. I could live with the thing that BBC's rss feed is utter garbage, as long as they provide data consistently, but they don't even do that

Name: openweathermap data not accurate for Australia
Comment_Body: >Even if I could, I'm not sure if it's not a too big tradeoff. That module has 8 files, and 6+4 dependencies.  Oh, that makes nonsense... Also I'm absolutely agree that "_BBC's rss feed is utter garbage_". I was used it for a while when the applet was non working and noticed that they do not provide a correct data, so i failed to realise why @Normmron determines them as "_accurate_".

Name: openweathermap data not accurate for Australia
Comment_Body: You need to compare the weather data with the data provided by the Australian Weather Bureau, its almost identical.  I've verified the BBC's accuracy for Australia with the desktop applet over several months (the desktop applet uses the BBC weather as its source).    The desktop weather applet uses the BBC reference number from the webpage: "https://www.bbc.com/weather/2158177" for its configuration (ie 2158177).  The panel applet is unusable with openweathermap as its data source - its just too inaccurate (that's comparing it to the local weather forecasts over a couple of months).  Can't say that if the BBC weather is accurate for other locations around the world - its likely that each weather source has its strengths and weaknesses.

Name: openweathermap data not accurate for Australia
Comment_Body: I have a similar issue here in Seattle.  Right now the weather applet says light snow.  It is definitely not snowing (or even raining) right now.  Yahoo weather has the right info; cloudy, rain later on.  I've noticed this several times this week; current temperatures and weather conditions were way off. I've verified on the openweathermap site that it's not the app's fault - the source data is incorrect.

Name: openweathermap data not accurate for Australia
Comment_Body: @Normmron @dilinger actually integrated BBC Weather, but I never released because sometimes it does not provide current weather.   I can try to get Yahoo working again instead, now that their website is actually functioning correctly...but it is still a fact that it won't be available below Cinnamon version 3.8 for now as I've got serious issues backporting it.

It uses a [data](https://api.met.no/weatherapi/locationforecastlts/1.3/documentation) from **Norwegian Meteorologist institute**, which requires no api key. **NOTE:** _Just a suggestion, I'm pretty fine with Openweathermap_

Name: [CinnVIIStarkMenu@NikoKrause] Feature Request: Merge Favorites with Application categories
Comment_Body: Hey @hadirena ,  the look of this applet is inspired by the Windows 7 Start Menu and the Linux Mint MATE Menu. Merging 'Favorite' into application categories is too far away from this purpose.  The Windows 7 Menu always opens with the 'Favorites' window. The MATE Menu opens with 'Favorites' menu as well, but it remembers if it has been closed with 'Favorites' or 'All programs' window. That's what CinnVIIStarkMenu does as well. You can try this by choosing the "MATE-Menu" layout in the settings.  What can be done is to add an option to have 'All Programs' opened by default (as you suggested). Since I'm very busy lately I can't add this right now. But I can target this for Mint 19.2, i.e. May/June.

Name: weather@mockturtl: Weather details fail to load - Service Unavailable
Comment_Body: Had the same problem - while the API URL understands any of `Plano`, `75024`, `75024,USA` or `Plano,USA` only the last of them worked when typed into the configuration box.  Looking at the code, I'd suggest regexp validation to detect lat/lon values and IDs and passing anything else as `q=`. How about `/^-?\d{1,3}(?:\.\d*)?,-?\d{1,3}(?:\.\d*)?/` for lat/lons and `/^\d{`N`,}/` for IDs where N is the minimum acceptable number of digits?   Oh and THANK YOU for fixing the applet!

Name: weather@mockturtl: Weather details fail to load - Service Unavailable
Comment_Body:
>If that were the case @cranes-bill how would Firefox be able to access the API URL?   Because Firefox and Cinnamon both are different applications. And I gave IPTABLES just as an example, did not say that it causing the problem. It might be a port problem and so on... The applet works very well for me, and also there is no other related bug reports. However, does the following script work for you _(you need to enter valid api-key as first argument)_: ```python #!/usr/bin/python3 # -*- coding: utf-8 -*-  import sys from requests import get import json   CITY_ID = '13669' CTRY_ID = 'us' show_data = 'Service Unavailable!' data = None  def get_data(key):     jsn = get('https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?q=%s,%s&APPID=%s' \     % (CITY_ID, CTRY_ID, key))     if jsn.status_code == 200:         return jsn.text     return None      try:     the_key = sys.argv[1] except IndexError:     print('Please enter your api-key as first argument!')     sys.exit(1)      req_data = get_data(the_key)  if req_data:     try:         data = json.loads(req_data)     except ValueError:         print('Bad data!')  if data:     dgr_sign = u'°'     the_city = data['name']     the_ctry = data['sys']['country']     the_desc = data['weather'][0]['description']     klvn_tmp = data['main']['temp']     the_temp = round(9 / 5 * (klvn_tmp - 273) + 32)     the_pres = data['main']['pressure']     the_hmdt = data['main']['humidity']     the_wnds = data['wind']['speed']     the_hedr = '---------------'      show_data = '	%s, %s:
	%s
	%s
	%d %sF
	Pressure: %d hPa
	\ Humidity: %d %%
	Wind speed: %.1f m/s' \ % (the_city, the_ctry, the_hedr, the_desc.title(), the_temp, dgr_sign,\ the_pres, the_hmdt, the_wnds)  print(show_data) ```

Comment_Body: @EdPhere Now remove current applet from the panel. Move the applet folder somewhere if you want to keep it up: `mv ~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/weather@mockturtl weather@mockturtl.old` or simply delete it: `rm -fr ~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/weather@mockturtl` then copy the new one to the applets folder: `cp -r cinnamon-spices-applets/weather@mockturtl/files/weather@mockturtl \ ~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets` Also I recommend you to delete the old settings: `rm -fr ~/.cinnamon/configs/weather@mockturtl` Then restart Cinnamon and add the new applet to the panel.

I initially tried psi.  ``` #    the_pres = data['main']['pressure']     hpa_pres = data['main']['pressure'] #    the_pres = (hpa_pres * 0.0145037738)     the_pres = (hpa_pres * 0.02953)     the_hmdt = data['main']['humidity']     the_wnds = data['wind']['speed']     the_hedr = '---------------'  #    show_data = '	%s, %s:

Name: weather@mockturtl: Weather details fail to load - Service Unavailable
Comment_Body:
Haha, that was a quickly written script just for the testing purposes, it probably can be done much better, but since you finding it useful, you might do the following changes: <details> <summary><b>Click to see diff</b></summary>  ```diff @@ -12,7 +12,7 @@  data = None    def get_data(key): -    jsn = get('https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?q=%s,%s&APPID=%s' \ +    jsn = get('https://api.openweathermap.org/data/2.5/weather?q=%s,%s&APPID=%s&units=imperial' \      % (CITY_ID, CTRY_ID, key))      if jsn.status_code == 200:          return jsn.text @@ -37,15 +37,15 @@      the_city = data['name']      the_ctry = data['sys']['country']      the_desc = data['weather'][0]['description'] -    klvn_tmp = data['main']['temp'] -    the_temp = round(9 / 5 * (klvn_tmp - 273) + 32) +    the_temp = data['main']['temp']      the_pres = data['main']['pressure'] +    the_pres *= 0.0145037738      the_hmdt = data['main']['humidity']      the_wnds = data['wind']['speed']      the_hedr = '---------------'   -    show_data = '	%s, %s:
	%s
	%s
	%d %sF
	Pressure: %d hPa
	\ -Humidity: %d %%
	Wind speed: %.1f m/s' \ +    show_data = '	%s, %s:
	%s
	%s
	%d %sF
	Pressure: %.2f psi
	\ +Humidity: %d %%
	Wind speed: %.1f m/h' \  % (the_city, the_ctry, the_hedr, the_desc.title(), the_temp, dgr_sign,\  the_pres, the_hmdt, the_wnds) ``` </details>  Adding `&units=imperial` to the request link will make temperature to be received **directly in Fahrenheit** as well as **wind speed in miles per hour**. The pressure are converted to **PSI**.  And yes, it can be made to receive a 5 days forecast...

Name: vnstat@linuxmint.com does not work with VPN
Comment_Body: I think the problems is with vnstat which needs to be set up for every interface that it is building a database for. It is automatically set up for interfaces present when it is installed by Mint. That will not have occurred for VPNs. It is an old program and the addition of interfaces is not trivial, I have done it for Bluetooth and mobile internet dongles. It is documented and `man vnstat` should provide information but will need some experimenting even if it is possible.  The applet only detects interfaces which are managed by the Network Manager and I would not expect two to show up, in fact I have difficulty seeing how that can happen in a single cycle.   You may want to try my other applet the Network Usage Monitor with alerts as that shows what has been detected and is active using similar code.   I currently do not have access to Linux machine where I can test but I can see you have done a lot of coding so the essential thing is to get vnstat creating a database after which you can fix the device to get vnstati to display the correct interface.

Name: vnstat@linuxmint.com does not work with VPN
Comment_Body: I've done a manual fix where I commented out the code that detects the interface and assigned the name of my connection to the variable, so it's working.  If it disconnect from the VPN the applet detects just the wired connection, as it should, and everything works correctly then. I think a check to see if vnstat can return a database from the connection could be helpful, but I'm not sure what that would look like in code, or how I'd use that to try the other interface.

Name: vnstat@linuxmint.com does not work with VPN
Comment_Body: @NathanSalapat Would it be useful to VPN users to be able to have two instances of the applet or the matching desklet (which already allows multiple instances) so you can see more than one interface, a manually set one for the VPN tunnel and the automatically detected one covering other traffic? This would be for 'advanced' users as vnstat would still need to be set up for the VPN.

Name: windowlist@cobinja.de: File manager context menu doesn't have standard options when pinned
Comment_Body: What exactly do you mean with this?

Name: windowlist@cobinja.de: File manager context menu doesn't have standard options when pinned
Comment_Body: Apparently I was a bit mixed up on this one. The default list manager does not in fact have this feature, only Icing Task Manager does. And it doesn't really have anything to do with pinning aside from the fact it's sometimes used with the "pin" itself, but it's also often used from the button of an open window. Here's a picture of ITM's context menu for the file manager: ![2018-03-15_151247](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12024557/37486058-3d9de548-2885-11e8-97e4-2e728327c4b4.png)  What I'm referring to is the links in the menu to jump straight to whatever folders have been added to it, as well as the "My Places" section. This allows opening it to commonly used directories very quickly. So it would really be just a feature request to add this.

Name: windowlist@cobinja.de: File manager context menu doesn't have standard options when pinned
Comment_Body: That's something I probably won't do, at least not for nemo bookmarks, maybe for XDG folders like Pictures, Videos.... I'll consider the latter.

Name: windowlist@cobinja.de: Can't pin apps
Comment_Body: Update: apparently, for some apps the option to pin them becomes available right away, whereas others (e.g. Pale Moon, Notepadqq, and likely others) it's unavailable until the app is closed and reopened.

Name: windowlist@cobinja.de: Can't pin apps
Comment_Body: The pinning feature depends on whether the application has a .desktop file

Name: windowlist@cobinja.de: Can't pin apps
Comment_Body: I don't think that explains (or maybe it does, this is all still pretty new to me) why the feature suddenly became available after closing and reopening the apps. Does CWL add the file for all apps, but it doesn't take effect until the app is restarted? Perhaps there should be a note in CWL's settings that some apps may not have the option until they're restarted?

Name: windowlist@cobinja.de: Can't pin apps

Name: cheaty@centurix: yaml instead of json-template
Comment_Body: @Centurix

Name: cheaty@centurix: yaml instead of json-template
Comment_Body: @uocxp Consider writing your cheatsheet in YAML and then feeding it through Node's yaml2json converter.

Name: cheaty@centurix: yaml instead of json-template
Comment_Body: I agree, YAML is easier to edit than JSON. It'd be nice if there was a native YAML reader/writer for the cinnamon applet space. In one of my other applets (Homestead Manager) I made a quick-and-dirty YAML reader to read the config from another application, but it's not terribly robust and only supports the very basics of YAML (and badly).   I did consider making either a small GUI to edit these, something in Python/TKinter, and then thought about having some kind of central repository of sheets where you can add/edit without having to add the sheet to this repo every time. Requires some hosting/building which leads to a Cinnamon applet dependent on a third party service.  I'll have a dig around for a YAML solution. I think it is better. Is anyone here aware of a good YAML parser that I could maybe use that would work well here?

I'll start looking into this again on another laptop and see if I can apply a fix for the "what is not working" issue. Thanks for the heads up!

Name: tracker@glebihan: Install dependencies when adding the Tracker search applet?
Comment_Body: There are a lot of applets in this repo. Which one are you talking about? Please add it in the issues title.

Name: tracker@glebihan: Install dependencies when adding the Tracker search applet?
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause I am sorry! I meant the Tracker search applet. I updated the title.

Name: tracker@glebihan: Install dependencies when adding the Tracker search applet?
Comment_Body: Ah yes. That's always an issue. The problem is, that Cinnamon (and therefore it's applets) is not Mint only. It's a desktop used by different operating systems Ubuntu/Fedora/Arch, etc, which use different packaging systems. So installing dependencies automatically is a little bit difficult. Most applets handle it by poping up a notification, that a dependency is missing. This can be done for this applet as well.

Name: tracker@glebihan: Install dependencies when adding the Tracker search applet?
Comment_Body: > Most applets handle it by poping up a notification, that a dependency is missing. This can be done for this applet as well.  This would be great, @NikoKrause! :-)  Great idea.

Name: [CustomApplicationsMenu@LLOBERA] Placeholders in desktop files
Comment_Body: As you noticed, if you use `desktopFile`, the applet will use the associated desktop file.   The desktop file for `libreoffice-calc` has the following line:  > Exec=libreoffice --calc %U  As `%U` is not defined it will show you an error the same way as you would execute it in bash.   So you can overwrite the `Exec` by adding a `command`:  > {"desktopFile":"libreoffice-calc", "command":"libreoffice --calc"}

Name: [CustomApplicationsMenu@LLOBERA] Change applet's icon
Comment_Body: The Mint-Y icon theme shows a star. But yes. It can be changed to use the star icon.

Name: [CustomApplicationsMenu@LLOBERA] Change applet's icon
Comment_Body: I use Mint-X, that might explain the different icons.  What would be even better, than changing the icon: Making the icon configurable?  BTW the context menu might do with a clean-up: It shows `About` twice … (should I open a new issue?)

Name: [CustomApplicationsMenu@LLOBERA] Change applet's icon
Comment_Body: I'm not sure, if it's really needed to add an option to use a custom icon. If we use the applets icon, it should be enough.  The About dialog is shown twice, becaus the applet is very old and it has no author.

Name: [CustomApplicationsMenu@LLOBERA] Change applet's icon
Comment_Body: I just thought if it is not too much work to read the icon from the `applications.json` file, it would make everybody happy.  I am aware that it is an old applet, so I just mentioned the About menu, so that it can be removed if somebody dares to touch the code.

Name: [CustomApplicationsMenu@LLOBERA] Change applet's icon
Comment_Body: To change the applet icon:  1.  go to `~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/CustomApplicationsMenu@LLOBERA` 2. edit the file `applet.js` 3. line 97, replace `help-about` by another icon name  > this.set_applet_icon_name("help-about");  4. icon names are file names of `/usr/share/icons/<yourtheme>/scalable/actions` without extension 5. restart cinnamon (right-click in task bar → Troubleshoot → Restart Cinnamon)

Name: Turn on wiki (Github repo settings)
Comment_Body: Some other ideas for things that could be documented in the wiki include the settings-schema types, I found out by searching and playing for awhile there is a "soundfilechooser" type.  It would also be good to explain the dependency field.  Also the interaction model between the applet file and the settings, In vs BI-Directional..etc. The idea of a wiki is to make it editable by everybody so the developers could help fill out the documentation and hopefully make it easier to find information regarding how to build applets in the future.

Comment_Body: This is the developers tutorials website: http://developer.linuxmint.com/reference/git/cinnamon-tutorials/index.html  And here is where the contents comes from, i.e. where you can contribute your documentation to:   I'll link this in the README of this repo: https://github.com/linuxmint/linuxmint.github.io/tree/master/reference/git/cinnamon-tutorials

Comment_Body: Another good resource is the devhelp package.  `sudo apt-get install devhelp cinnamon-doc muffin-doc libclutter-1.0-doc`

Name: Turn on wiki (Github repo settings)
Comment_Body: @jake1164 the list of available settings types is already documented in Cinnamon, and as @jaszhix mentioned, it is available in devhelp. All fo the documentation used to be on the developers website, but it quickly got out of date, and atm it is non-trivial to update it, so it was removed. We should probably include some information in the readme about how to access the documentation.

Name: Turn on wiki (Github repo settings)

I think it might see more use here since spices are more focused on the Cinnamon JS architecture and API, where as the Cinnamon wiki needs to cover a wider range of topics. It could be used as a staging area for information, and then possibly syndicated to the developer site later.

Name: sticky@scollins: intercepts clicks through windows

What I said in my last message: "some time after I initialize again the notes, it isn't giving me the fail". The true of that is that I remembered now that I click "Reboot Cinnamon" but I didn't notice the relation with the notes. Of course, it has relation because the notes applet is part of the Cinnamon system.  To everyone with this problem, I encourage to everyone to use "Reboot Cinnammon", because this applet is so good and it can help to us to continue using it, while the problem persist and someone find the solution.

Name: sessionManager@scollins: security issue after suspend
Comment_Body: This caught my eye in email... @collinss I'd consider using cinnamon-session's command utility (synchronously) rather than dbus - this way you don't have to worry about whether you're using consolekit or logind, and cinnamon-session also ensures (theoretically) a secure desktop prior to suspend/hibernate happening, by explicitly locking the desktop if required.  There have also been a few commits in cinnamon-session and cinnamon-screensaver related to some of this, and possibly eliminating some of the issues for the next release.

Name: sessionManager@scollins: security issue after suspend
Comment_Body: @mtwebster Thanks, I'll have to take a look when I get a chance. I don't know a lot about how all the power management stuff works. When I wrote the applet, I think I just went looking for a command that would work (I probably stole it from some other applet or something). Also, I never use the screensaver and almost never use suspend either so that's probably why I never saw the issue.

Name: sessionManager@scollins: security issue after suspend
Comment_Body: Two comments:  @collinss I tried starting the cinnamon screensaver (cinnamon-screensaver-command --lock) explicitly right before starting Util.spawnCommandLine("systemctl suspend"), but that made no difference (no waiting time between them, perhaps a race condition or cinnamon-session works very different).  @mtwebster I like this applet, because you can choose a command with one click (and it looks good and slick with symbolic icons). With cinnamon-session(-quit) you have to click once more (e.g. for suspend), or ist it possible to use it for selective commands without dialog? I know, there are other problems in the world...

Name: vboxlauncher@mockturtl: Start VM in background/decoupled
Comment_Body: Allows via command line?  Can you explain a bit what background / decoupled means?

Name: vboxlauncher@mockturtl: Start VM in background/decoupled
Comment_Body: It is documented here: https://www.virtualbox.org/manual/ch08.html#vboxmanage-startvm  background = headless: The VM is started without showing any Window. Useful when you have a VM with a database in it and just need to connect to that database.  decoupled = separate: Starts the VM with detachable GUI, so you can close the GUI-Window later without stopping the VM

Name: Office Center by collinss
Comment_Body: What exactly happend? I installed it here on Linux Mint 17.3 Cinnamon 2.8.8 and everything worked fine?  What exactly did you do? Was it a fresh install or an update from an older version of this applet? What happened after you installed it and what did you do to recover your desktop?

Name: Office Center by collinss
Comment_Body: @glikar Hi, I'm the author of that applet. I'm sorry it isn't working for you. I use it every day without any problems (in fact, I am currently running it on Mint 18.1, and have used it on every release since I wrote the applet years ago), and I haven't had any reports of it not working, so I don't think we need to go advertising that it's dangerous or broken. However, I would like to know what caused the problem so that I can fix it if possible. Could you please include more information on what happened, as well as anything in the logs that might be relevant (glass.log and .xsession-errors are the ones you want to look at). I would also like to know if you were using the default settings, or if you had modified them. Did it happen as soon as you installed the applet, or when you restarted the computer? Also, please use pastebin or something similar if you are including any log entries or such that are longer than a couple of lines.

Name: Office Center by collinss
Comment_Body: Sorry if I offended I'll take it down, if you like.  Was a first time install, downloaded and installed from the applets dialog. It started the install then just hung. Tried everything to get control,  but nothing on the keyboard worked, alt F2, nothing. Except; ctrl/alt/f1 to f6 still worked giving me a new session also  ctrl/alt/backspace worked taking me back to the login screen.  Logging in opened a bank black screen and the only thing that did  anything was moving the mouse cursor  but nothing there to click on. I was starting to think it was malicious because in a repair session I  deleted the app directory  2 or 3 times, ".cinnamon/configs/..." and it  kept reappearing! Ha, was reminding me of my windows days 20 years ago.   Anyway,  eventually gave up and went for supper.  Came back rebooted a few more  times.  On reboots login always appeared and noticed the login wallpaper was  changing, that's from Variety, so figured something must still be running. Logged in again and left it sit for 1/2 an hour upon returning blessings  of all blessings my desktop was there and your icon was on the panel. But stupid me, clicked it and the problem started all over again. Followed the same steps and got back to a visible panel and right  clicked to get the  applets dialog and deleted the app. It took around 10 to 20 minutes to delete, probably because it was  looking for the app directory which did delete the last time I tried.  Thanks for your reply! Name: Office Center by collinss
Comment_Body: One of the things that the applet does by default is create a menu item for each file in your documents folder. If there are enough files there, the system can't handle it and it crashes or freezes. I tried to find a different solution, and it helped a little bit, but it still has problems with large numbers of files.

Name: Office Center by collinss
Comment_Body: 114 files total and  60 are directories. Thanks for your time!

Name: Office Center by collinss
Comment_Body: Maybe it was trying to create a directory name that already existed.

Name: Office Center by collinss
Comment_Body: Okay! You are right of course, I renamed Documents and created a new one, added a few sub folders and installed Office Center.  Works great. Very nice just what I was looking for! Thank you very much.

Name: Office Center by collinss
Comment_Body: An additional note, since it installed okay was able to use 'Configure', there selected 'Show contents of documents folder' then uncheck 'Include subfolders' and finally 'Use alternate directory'. If 'Include subfolders' is checked the same problem occurs. The alternate directory I choose had a few saved html sites in it with piles of images.  The script kept digging deeper and deeper.  Maybe leaving the directory options unchecked in 'Configure'  would let it install and the user could then select directory options.

Name: Cinnamon-Sticky-Notes: one workspace only
Comment_Body: It's always good to hear that my work has benefited someone else! That is probably possible, though it would involve a great deal of work, and I'm not certain I could implement it in a way that would be clean and easy to use, at least not with the API as it is currently. It might be something I decide to work on at some point, so I'll leave this open, but unfortunately, it probably wont happen any time soon.

Name: SpicesGeneral - Security Enhancement - Run applets from signed tar file
Comment_Body: It's all in the user's home folder, so couldn't some nefarious software simply change the signature as well? The only way to make this work would be to require root access to install. But honestly, if something is able to change the files in your home folder, you have bigger issues. I don't see this as any better than the current situation, personally.

Name: SpicesGeneral - Security Enhancement - Run applets from signed tar file
Comment_Body: Not if you used a Cryptographic Signature, ie RSA Public / Private keys. The repo would hold the private key and when the code is submitted and approved it would create the tar and sign the file.  The OS would hold a public key that would validate the signature on execution, or startup maybe.  You do have to have root to install applications so should applets be less secure?

Name: SpicesGeneral - Security Enhancement - Run applets from signed tar file
Comment_Body: Applets are not applications, they are more like firefox extensions, which also don't need root access to install.  Also, having the signature on the server means that the os would have to check the server whenever it checks the applets. For those who have consistent high-speed internet this is not a problem, but many do not.  Also, I feel that it would annoy many users for something that is almost a non-issue. I'm not a security expert but it seems to me the likelihood that someone would be able to utilize this to access someone's  computer when other methods fail is negligible.  You'll have to check with @clefebvre since he's the one who will make that call, but I personally don't see the point.

Name: SpicesGeneral - Security Enhancement - Run applets from signed tar file
Comment_Body: @clefebvre was there any decision made about the direction of this issue/ticket? I'm currently trying to go through older tickets and attempt to resume work on them or see if they can/should be closed.

Name: Update metadata.json
Comment_Body: @mockturtl

Name: Update metadata.json
Comment_Body: I do not think that this is the right way to solve the issue, this only works around the problem that the applet manager does not enforce max-instance setting correctly nor it prevents the user to spam the Add button.   The issues related to the applet manager should be raised in the main cinnamon repo [here](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon/issues) first as it affects all applets.  Also giving users the option to have multiple weather applets is a feature already enabled for the applet, and I usually vary to take features away even they are broken (I'm pretty sure we will break at least a few people's workflow disabling it).   If the others think the feature should be disabled for the weather@mockturtl applet, then I won't say no either.

Name: Update metadata.json
Comment_Body: @Gr3q  @mockturtl @claudiux I have only recently started using Linux and am trying to get up to speed with Arch and my chosen DE Cinnamon. I am getting the latest updates daily and Cinnamon is already at version 4.4.3, whereas even Manjaro (Arch) is still on Cinnamon 4.2.4.  An objection to removing the ability to allow users to load multiple instances of this Weather applet is puzzling. I cannot conceive of any need to display 2 or 3 instances of this applet on a desktop panel. What am I missing?  I must accede to your decision,  because my knowledge of the coding in Cinnamon is very limited and this is my first PR.  As far as raising this issue in the the main Cinnamon repo, I will leave this to you, as I don't understand how this change would affect all applets.  This is a popular applet and I think there will be a more issues raised as other distros catch up. I have had no issues at all with Weather since I made the suggested change, so will be ok until there are updates.

Name: Update metadata.json
Comment_Body: >  I cannot conceive of any need to display 2 or 3 instances of this applet on a desktop panel.  What am I missing?  Some users like to know the weather in multiple cities.  I can imagine a better interface to support it, but multiple instances are an easy workaround.  Likewise, if multi-instance is broken in a recent Cinnamon release, editing the metadata file feels like a "hotfix" until the underlying problem is resolved.  I suggest we use votes on this PR to decide which is causing more pain.  In any case, it will help if someone with more information [opens an issue upstream](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon/issues).

Name: Update metadata.json
Comment_Body: @mockturtl > Some users like to know the weather in multiple cities. I can imagine a better interface to support it, but multiple instances are an easy workaround. >  > Likewise, if multi-instance is broken in a recent Cinnamon release, editing the metadata file feels like a "hotfix" until the underlying problem is resolved. >  > I suggest we use votes on this PR to decide which is causing more pain. In any case, it will help if someone with more information [opens an issue upstream](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon/issues).  Ok, now I understand.  No problem for me right now, if not merged. We can wait and see how this develops.

Name: turn-off-monitor@zablotski - Does not turn off the monitor
Comment_Body: @Padre2 After clicking on the icon, do not move the mouse. What's going on, then?

Name: turn-off-monitor@zablotski - Does not turn off the monitor
Comment_Body: @claudiux If I position the cursor and hold the mouse absolutely still using my left hand and left-click, it will turn off the display and the D-SUB No signal message will appear and the power led will come on, then the D-SUB message will disappear and the power light will flash. The slightest  mouse movement will open the display again. Can be done with one hand, but need to take extra care not to have any movement.

Name: turn-off-monitor@zablotski - Does not turn off the monitor
Comment_Body: @Padre2 Please try to edit the `~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/turn-off-monitor@zablotski/applet.js` script and change the value `1000` by `5000` (line 36). Save this file and restart Cinnamon. Your mouse will become inactive during 5 seconds (5000 ms) instead of 1 second (1000 ms) actually.  If that suits you, I'll modify this applet to implement some settings. Its author seems to be inactive on Github.

Name: turn-off-monitor@zablotski - Does not turn off the monitor
Comment_Body: @claudiux  Thank you for looking at this. It does reduce the sensitivity making it useable.  However, after further consideration I will probably not use this applet. When I need to blank the screen, I can use  _xset dpms force off_  from an alias and it doesn't even need _sudo._  I see you often help with solutions for various applets, which is much appreciated. Is there any way I can contact you directly on this subject, without going through github?

Name: turn-off-monitor@zablotski - Does not turn off the monitor
Comment_Body: @Padre2 I'm proposing the PR #2729 to improve this applet. Can you test it, please?  The best way to contact me is Github. I watch Github more often than my emails.  Kind regards. Claudiux

Name: turn-off-monitor@zablotski - Does not turn off the monitor
Comment_Body: @claudiux  I'm happy to assist with testing.  I am not yet fully familiar with the workings of GitHub. Will you be updating the applet or do I need to download it from GitHub?  The reason I asked about an email address, is that I have several issues with certain applets and how Cinnamon behaves, e.g. I noticed differences in the way that the CPU Temperature applet displays on different distributions on the same machine, but don't want to go into this on GitHub, at least not yet. Although I use Arch that I compiled, I also have available Manjaro (Arch) and Feren (Ubuntu), both with Cinnamon DE.

Comment_Body: @claudiux  No problems. Cjs-Message: 13:48:30.241: JS LOG: [LookingGlass/info] Loaded applet turn-off-monitor@zablotski in 22 ms  Good job with the additional configuration and icon!

Comment_Body: Good evening, @fluntelion,  A very old theme is certainly present in your `~/.themes` folder.  Can you, using 'insert code', give me below the result of the `tree -P metadata* ~/.themes/` command, please?  @claudiux

Name: SpicesUpdate fails to open
Comment_Body: Good evening, claudiux,  Here's the answer to your question.  name@WorkStation:~$ tree -P metadata* ~/.themes/ /home/name/.themes/ ├── Glaucous │   ├── cinnamon │   └── metadata.json ├── Numix-Curry │   └── cinnamon │       ├── background-assets │       ├── buttons │       ├── control-assets │       ├── expo-scale-assets │       ├── metadata.json │       ├── misc-assets │       ├── panel-assets │       ├── third-party-APPLET-stylesheets │       ├── third-party-DESKLET-stylesheets │       └── third-party-EXTENSION-stylesheets ├── Numix-Green │   └── cinnamon │       ├── background-assets │       ├── buttons │       ├── control-assets │       ├── expo-scale-assets │       ├── metadata.json │       ├── misc-assets │       ├── panel-assets │       ├── third-party-APPLET-stylesheets │       ├── third-party-DESKLET-stylesheets │       └── third-party-EXTENSION-stylesheets └── Numix-Red     └── cinnamon         ├── background-assets         ├── buttons         ├── control-assets         ├── expo-scale-assets         ├── metadata.json         ├── misc-assets         ├── panel-assets         ├── third-party-APPLET-stylesheets         ├── third-party-DESKLET-stylesheets         └── third-party-EXTENSION-stylesheets  35 directories, 4 files name@WorkStation:~$  And here's a question. Which one would be the very old theme?  Thank you in advance for your answer  fluntelion  Sent with [ProtonMail](https://protonmail.com) Secure Email.  ‐‐‐‐‐‐‐ Original Message ‐‐‐‐‐‐‐ On Monday, November 11, 2019 6:18 PM, claudiux <notifications@github.com> wrote:  > Good evening, [@fluntelion](https://github.com/fluntelion), > > A very old theme is certainly present in your ~/.themes folder. > > Can you, using 'insert code', give me bellow the result of the tree -P metadata* ~/.themes/ command, please? > > — > You are receiving this because you were mentioned. > Reply to this email directly, [view it on GitHub](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/issues/2681?email_source=notifications&email_token=AKCWEVIMCJ7HB4UIKKQTJ5DQTGOXJA5CNFSM4JLYX2RKYY3PNVWWK3TUL52HS4DFVREXG43VMVBW63LNMVXHJKTDN5WW2ZLOORPWSZGOEDXVFHY#issuecomment-552555167), or [unsubscribe](https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AKCWEVJX4NR3B5UDLXESBIDQTGOXJANCNFSM4JLYX2RA).

Name: SpicesUpdate fails to open
Comment_Body: Good evening, @fluntelion,  That's what I thought. I have already fixed this issue on my computer. The next version of Spices Update will take into account the themes that do not contain a metadata.json file in their folder but in the cinnamon subfolder.  If you want to fix yourself this issue on your computer: ``` cd ~/.themes cp Numix-Curry/cinnamon/metadata.json Numix-Curry/ cp Numix-Green/cinnamon/metadata.json Numix-Green/ cp Numix-Red/cinnamon/metadata.json Numix-Red/ ```

Name: SpicesUpdate fails to open
Comment_Body: @fluntelion  These three themes no longer exist in the Cinnamon database.

Name: SpicesUpdate fails to open
Comment_Body: Good morning, claudiux,  "These three themes no longer exist in the Cinnamon database."  You're right and you aren't, because they never did. :-) 'Numix' is in the database by the name of Numix Cinnamon Transparent. Numix Curry, Green & Red weren't and aren't, because they are my forks of the original. I removed transparency, some lines and shadows as well as some other fancy things, and gave them new highlight colours: Curry, Green, and Red. What I did not do is move any file from any folder to any other folder, so all three are still in the original state - except for the changes within the css files.  The puzzling thing is that the combination of a forked Numix theme and Spices Update worked perfectly well for nearly one year - until last week when there was an update of Spices Update itself. ;-) What's more: Changing the theme to different default themes did not make Spices Update work either.  Hence the question: Who loads an applet, desklet or extension? No matter which theme or the OS itself? I'm inclined to say that it's the OS itself, most of all because .xsession-errors said: Applet SpicesUpdate@claudiux: Could not create applet object. and: Error importing applet.js from SpicesUpdate@claudiux.  But howsoever, could I get a short message when the next version of Spices Update will be available? I cannot find the number of the current version at https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/applets/view/309.  Kind regards, flunti  Sent with [ProtonMail](https://protonmail.com) Secure Email.  ‐‐‐‐‐‐‐ Original Message ‐‐‐‐‐‐‐ On Tuesday, November 12, 2019 11:56 PM, claudiux <notifications@github.com> wrote:  > [@fluntelion](https://github.com/fluntelion) These three themes no longer exist in the Cinnamon database. > > — > You are receiving this because you were mentioned. > Reply to this email directly, [view it on GitHub](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/issues/2681?email_source=notifications&email_token=AKCWEVM4SUL3YMPJALQ7OJ3QTM7B3A5CNFSM4JLYX2RKYY3PNVWWK3TUL52HS4DFVREXG43VMVBW63LNMVXHJKTDN5WW2ZLOORPWSZGOED4L3FA#issuecomment-553172372), or [unsubscribe](https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AKCWEVIJZFXFCFFN2FM2I6LQTM7B3ANCNFSM4JLYX2RA).

Name: Spices Update: frequency field ignores value if it is too high
Comment_Body: Hi @LinuxOnTheDesktop,  Is your session open permanently? The "Frequency" tooltip shows: "Please note that the first check will take place one minute after this applet starts."  Thus, one minute after the opening of your session, a first check is made. Then, the next check will take place 72 hours after this one, unless you close your session.

Name: Spices Update: frequency field ignores value if it is too high
Comment_Body: Ah yes, my mistake. I have deleted the mistaken comment.  Let me clarify the problem. If I enter '72' into the field at issue, and then close the window and re-open it, then the value is not retained. However, if I enter '24' instead, then the value is retained.

Name: Spices Update: frequency field ignores value if it is too high
Comment_Body: OK. I see where is the problem.  Please check the contents of your `/.cinnamon/configs/SpicesUpdate@claudiux/SpicesUpdate@claudiux.json` file.  From line 650 have you that? ```     "general_frequency": {         "type": "spinbutton",         "default": 1,         "min": 1,         "max": 720,         "step": 1,         "units": "hours",         "description": "Time interval between two checks",         "tooltip": "Please note that the first check will take place one minute after starting this applet.",         "value": 72     }, ```  If the "max" value is set to 24, Cinnamon did not apply the changes to the `settings-schema.json` file in #2616 and I'll go to open an issue.  Please try to completely remove and then reinstall Spices Update. After deletion, the `~/.cinnamon/configs/SpicesUpdate@claudiux` folder should no longer exist. This folder will be recreated after the reinstallation.  EDIT: Before removing Spices Update, please try to renew its installation using... the settings of Spices Update -> Applets tab -> check both cases for Spices Update and press Refresh.

Name: Spices Update: frequency field ignores value if it is too high
Comment_Body: @LinuxOnTheDesktop I had the same bug by directly typing the frequency value instead of using the `+` and `-` widgets.

Name: Spices Update: frequency field ignores value if it is too high
Comment_Body: Replacing this `spinbutton` widget by a `scale` one, this issue is solved.

Name: Batterymonitorwithoutlocalfiles
Comment_Body: @sphh Just to let you know I am aware of your PR and the changes look useful and positive!  I obviously need time to look in detail and run tests on my machines. How much testing have you done and has it been on a number of machines and flavours of Linux?  I note that you have also updated many (all) of the associated files such as changelogs and have spent a lot of time on this PR.  Only immediate comment is that we should update cinnamon-version to include 4.4 as we must be getting towards the early versions being available for test.  I have no strong views on removing old temporary files - "Perfect is the enemy of Good" (Voltaire)

Name: Batterymonitorwithoutlocalfiles
Comment_Body: Glad that you like this PR (so far).  Since I only have one machine (Linux Mint 19.2 Cinnamon), I am sorry that I could test it only on this flavour. Here it is running without any problem. I tried to mimic the `batteryscript.sh` as closely as possible, so if `upower` does not change its output, it should work (AFAIK).  If you are so inclined, please feel free to advance the cinnamon version to 4.4!  My opinion is that "A program should always clean up behind itself" (???). But it is a overhead to check for those files every time the applet starts.

Name: Batterymonitorwithoutlocalfiles
Comment_Body: I have several machines I can access and also use persistent LiveUSBs for test but it takes time.  I wonder if there is a clean-up mechanism in Cinnamon when one uninstalls? I think not.   I will try it out in the next few hours.  You should credit yourself somewhere - perhaps as contributor of 1.4.0 changes in CHANGELOG.md or in the source code.

Name: Batterymonitorwithoutlocalfiles
Comment_Body: I noticed that the applets forget their settings when they were uninstalled ...  Adding a button to the configuration to delete these two files could be a way forward.

Comment_Body: @sphh @pdcurtis Maybe this will help you? https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon/pull/8919

Name: Batterymonitorwithoutlocalfiles
Comment_Body: @sphh Agreed - it avoids any overhead.  I have not seen any problems yet so you just need to acknowledge yourself, change to include 4.4 and do above and I am happy to proceed.  I am not sure how one alerts the system that I have agreed the PR. Failing anything else change title to include something like [AGREED] to attract attention as I can not change any flags. @claudius perhaps you can enlighten me on correct way to alert the 'team'

Name: Batterymonitorwithoutlocalfiles
Comment_Body: @pdcurtis I now added a button and updated the translation files. I also updated the cinnamon version to 4.4.  If you want to credit me, please feel free to add it wherever you seem appropriate.  The last time I made a pull request, I asked @brownsr if he could push it to the main repository. And he did.

Name: [stopwatch@pdcurtis] FEATURE Make it more flexible, add some features, style to better fit in panel
Comment_Body: ping @pdcurtis

Name: [stopwatch@pdcurtis] FEATURE Make it more flexible, add some features, style to better fit in panel
Comment_Body: ping @pdcurtis

Name: [stopwatch@pdcurtis] FEATURE Make it more flexible, add some features, style to better fit in panel
Comment_Body: @l00k  Thanks for the suggested features and @brownsr for alerting me to the PR. I haven taken a while to comment as I wanted to try it out for a little while and to get my thoughts together.  @100kI am impressed - there are a number of interesting ideas and you have made some additions to the context menu that i did not realise were possible, although there are still a few anomalies which would need sorting out.  I do however have a number of concerns with some of the concept. The original applet was deigned to have a very low footprint on the toolbar so it could always be present and to be very simple and quick to activate as a timer during expense critical activities such as phone calls, time chargeable internet access etc. I therefore kept the count to minutes and seconds only with an indicator that it had over-run so the tooltip could be checked. I resisted adding many 'Bells and Whistles'  quite deliberately. This was made clear in the Rationale statement.  It was also made clear in the header that It was also intended to not only useful in its own right but is also provides a 'tutorial' framework for other more complex applets - for example it provides a settings screen and a 'standard' right click (context) menu which opens the settings panel and a Housekeeping submenu accessing help and a version/update files and also the gnome system monitor program in case you want to find out how much machine power this applet is using at various update rates. It also provides an example of how to implement l10n localisation/translation support.  So I would like to include some of the additions you have put forwards for the context menu when the anomalies have been removed but have concerns over changing the panel display to occupy addition space unless it is available as an option.  I currently do not understand the rationale for the ability to change the timer 'on the fly' unless it is intended as a substitute for a timer which brings me to another point - I do not thing there is currently a good combined timer, stopwatch clock applet giving the functionality we have come to expect in mobile devices running android etc.  I would appreciate your and perhaps @brownsr 's comments on whether  a useful way ahead would be for you to 'fork' my applet with your Features into  a new stand alone applet which could in the longer term provide not only a stopwatch but also a timer to which alerts etc could be added and perhaps even offer some clock functions such as alarm clock and global times.  In the meantime I have seen some anomalies in the modification of the title in the context menu where changes initially displayed incorrectly - sometimes a cinnamon restart then displayed the correct text but not every time.

Name: [stopwatch@pdcurtis] FEATURE Make it more flexible, add some features, style to better fit in panel
Comment_Body: @pdcurtis I personally use it as time tracker. That is why I have added feature to be able to quickly rename each applet. I have multiple applets added (as multiple tasks) - it is usable to move time between them - that is why I have added features to edit time. Style is really subjective - I have to admit I didn't tested vertical panels.  If you don't mind I would be pleasant to make fork and publish it.

Name: [stopwatch@pdcurtis] FEATURE Make it more flexible, add some features, style to better fit in panel
Comment_Body: Firstly I am happy for you to fork my applet and make a version which satisfies your specific requirements but to some extent it is up to the Cinnamon team whether an extra applet is accepted.  In any case I am working on integrating most of your modifications either in the baseline or as an option.   The first phase would be changes to the context menu to give access to title and make a single line for the various start pause and resume options. However I still see anomalies in when title changes are applied even with an extra update u call.  The next phase will be to add Option of size of panel display on a instance by instance basis.  That only leaves your timer modifications which I do not expect many people to use in its existing form but could be an Experimental Option.  There are also a lot of updates to change logs, help etc  needed.  I do not have views on style differences - they looked small and there is a way to edit with persistence so lower priority.  Sorry about all the edits the post button is right next to where one types and I am on a small mobile!

Name: [stopwatch@pdcurtis] FEATURE Make it more flexible, add some features, style to better fit in panel
Comment_Body: @pdcurtis Heading to the timer can be implemented in a tooltip. Then the applet will occupy the same space, but will become more informative. For example, add entry in the settings. If the field is empty, display standard header. In General, it would be convenient to have the countdown timer and stopwatch in one applet

Name: [stopwatch@pdcurtis] FEATURE Make it more flexible, add some features, style to better fit in panel
Comment_Body: @AleksiMagner The timer already displays in the tooltip as you suggest and can be longer than would be practical in the panel and it is set up in settings. THere can be up to ten instances of the timer with different headers. It also displays the 'status' and current count.  ![Stopwatch_Screenshot from 2019-10-30 11-39-18](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2843925/67855344-35100d80-fb0a-11e9-8947-fb2eb6179d16.png)  I agree that a more comprehensive applet with a timer with various alarms would be nice but would be a lot of extra work although some of the groundwork exists in my Network Usage and Monitoring Applet (NUMA to the left) and the Battery Applet with Monitoring and Shutdown (BAMS to the right) .

Name: [stopwatch@pdcurtis] FEATURE Make it more flexible, add some features, style to better fit in panel
Comment_Body: @l00k I have implemented most of the changes for a new major version 2.2.0 ### Version 2.2.0   * Adds option option in Configure... to display Counter Heading in Panel.   * New single line layout for Start, Pause, Reset, Continue and Continue from Start Time in Context Menu   * Adds ability to edit Counter Heading in Context menu as well as Configure..   * Adds option in Configure... to add experimental functions such as an ability to modify time by buttons in Context (right click) Menu - a possible precursor to a flexible timer function.   * Implements changes proposed by @100k (Łukasz Dobrowolski)in #2648 and uses code provided by him to implement his suggestions.   *  Minor changes in stylesheet.css to match the other applets in the suite. Also   * Updated CHANGELOG.md much as above   * Updated README.md including acknowledging @100k major contributions by @100k to ideas and code.   * Updated metadata.json to version 2.2.0  I suggest the time modifications should be changed to +- 1 Min +- 10 Mins and +- 1 hour as precursor to including a flexible timer. @100k  Any views as it a feature you use extensively?

Name: [stopwatch@pdcurtis] FEATURE Make it more flexible, add some features, style to better fit in panel
Comment_Body: Screenshots of v2.2.0rc  ![Stopwatch_Screenshot_v2 2 0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2843925/67887004-64427100-fb42-11e9-9dce-72520bf3f4df.png)  ![Stopwatch_Screenshot-v2 2 0](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/2843925/67887014-66a4cb00-fb42-11e9-9367-3741ba065f30.png)  Theme is Cinnamox-Willow-Grove

Name: New Italian translations
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @Dragone2: Expanding on what **claudiux** and **collinss** said; the applet `WindowListGroup@jake.phy@gmail.com` actually doesn't use its translations (at least not in newer versions of Cinnamon). Cinnamon only uses .po files found inside a folder called **po** at the root of the xlet folder and those .po files are automatically installed/uninstalled every time that an xlet is installed/uninstalled.  I think that what you should do is just add the **it.po** file inside a folder called **po** in the `WindowListGroup@jake.phy@gmail.com` applet so at least the Italian translation is functional in this applet. Its structure can be fixed in a different PR (that is, moving all the other .po files and the .pot file inside the **po** folder).

Name: hwmonitor@sylfurd : Applet crashed in Cinnamon < 4.x
Comment_Body: I think the problem is caused by the way how the settings of the applet are set up. `this.settings.bind` (see:  [#L95](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/4d70956a3befdc2da4d13fada897b03486b2cd4e/hwmonitor%40sylfurd/files/hwmonitor%40sylfurd/applet.js#L95)) vs `this.settings.bindProperty` in all other applets I have installed.  At first "just" errors `Could not set up binding - settings object was not initialized successfully for hwmonitor@sylfurd` are shown but as `border_color` in [#L98](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/4d70956a3befdc2da4d13fada897b03486b2cd4e/hwmonitor%40sylfurd/files/hwmonitor%40sylfurd/applet.js#L98) is not loaded, the `createThemeObject` function fails when trying to call `getColors` in [#L318](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/4d70956a3befdc2da4d13fada897b03486b2cd4e/hwmonitor%40sylfurd/files/hwmonitor%40sylfurd/applet.js#L318).

Name: hwmonitor@sylfurd : Applet crashed in Cinnamon < 4.x
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @Hultan: Several errors in your fork:  - Do not use **2.8** as a version, use **3.2**. There isn't a currently supported distribution that uses Cinnamon version 2.x (Linux Mint 17.x has been EOL (End Of Life) for more than six months now). - Copy **ALL** files into the **3.2** folder **EXCEPT** for the **icon.png** and **metadata.json** files. Do the same for the **3.8** folder but do not modify any of those files. - Convert to *JavaScript prototypes* **ALL** .js files inside the **3.2** folder, not just the **applet.js** file.

Name: hwmonitor@sylfurd : Applet crashed in Cinnamon < 4.x
Comment_Body: `apt install devhelp gir1.2-devhelp-3.0 libgtk-3-doc libglib2.0-doc libpango1.0-doc cinnamon-doc` then use devhelp to go to Cinnamon Tutorials -> Extension system -> Applet, desklet and extension settings reference.  You can also download all (latest) versions of Cinnamon and look at the files in the `cinnamon-x.y.z/files/usr/share/cinnamon/applets/settings-example@cinnamon.org/` folder.

Name: hwmonitor@sylfurd : Applet crashed in Cinnamon < 4.x
Comment_Body: @Hultan: In addition to the documentations suggested by **claudiux**, it also exists [this on-line documentation](https://lazka.github.io/pgi-docs/) about GObject libraries (Clutter, GLib, Gio, etc.). These libraries are greatly used by Cinnamon itself and by Cinnamon xlets. It can also be [downloaded for off-line use](https://github.com/lazka/pgi-docs) as a static HTML site, and also can be downloaded as [Devhelp books](https://github.com/pygobject/pgi-docs-devhelp).

Name: Add applet Rate currency
Comment_Body: If this PR is open and you want to change, fix things, all you need to do is to commit and push those changes to your branch (what you used to open this PR). It will automatically show up in this PR.  When this PR is accepted and is merged, and you want to add a new feature you need to open a new PR, what your can do like this _(this is my actual workflow)_: 1. Rebase your Fork's master branch to cinnamon's original master branch _(to be in line with the original repo's state)_, which you can do:    1. Add cinnamon's original repo as a remote (do this only once): ```git remote add <give-it-a-name> https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets.git```. I use "mint" as the remote name.    2. Fetch from all your remotes ```git fetch --all```    3. Switch to your master branch ```git checkout master```    4. Rebase your master to cinnamon's master ```git rebase <remote-name-you-chose>/master```    5. Push it to your remote ```git push``` Now you are in line with cinnamon's repo state.  2. Create a new branch for your feature from master, switch to branch, etc. Exactly what you did with this PR.
