Name: weather@mockturtl: Temperature not translated
Comment_Body: Hey,  I just checked. And it's translated in other languages. In Hungarian there are 25 missing translated strings. The "Temperature:" string is marked as `fuzzy`, which means it's translated automatically, which most of the time means, it's a bad translation. And Cinnamon ignores fuzzy translations.  You can help by translating this applet: https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/weather%40mockturtl/files/weather%40mockturtl/po/hu.po  You can translated it with the `poedit` application (which can be installed with the software center) and create a pull request.  If you have any questions feel free to ask.

Name: sane-menu@nooulaif: Update for Cinnamon 3.6
Comment_Body: This applet hasn't been updated in 5 months: https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/commits/master/sane-menu@nooulaif  A menu applet as Sane Menu is a huge project compared to other applets. And in the long run you'll need someone, who has time to maintain it. This applet has no author right now and it's already broken. Pull requests are welcome and it's open for maintainers to jump on the bandwagon as an author for sane menu. But if nobody wants to fix it, then I guess it'll be deleted sooner or later.

Name: sane-menu@nooulaif: Update for Cinnamon 3.6
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause Ahh, terribly sorry, I was just browsing the Issues about the CPU/Mem monitor applet (hwmonitor@sylfurd), and somehow I did not read the title of this issue correctly. I tried to find some info about this Sane Menu thing, and only place which has good description: https://libraries.io/github/nooulaif/cinnamon-sane-menu "It drived me mad when I typed sett or g the first result was Accessibility." I tried it with the Cinnamon 3.6.7 stock menu (I believe it is stock, installed with AntergOS). For "sett" it gave me relevant results: Light Locker Settings, Print Settings, Qt5 Settings, System Settings. For "g" it also gave me relevant results: Geany, General, gitg, Google Chrome, GParted, Users and Groups. So I think they improved the stock menu a lot and I am not sure what is the current use case for this Sane Menu which the stock menu does not support.

Name: sane-menu@nooulaif: Update for Cinnamon 3.6
Comment_Body: The Sane Menu has an improved search feature. It sorts the found results. The problem is, that sorting the results costs performance.

Name: gpaste-reloaded@feuerfuchs.eu: Add key binding to show history
Comment_Body: So I follow [these instructions](https://help.github.com/articles/syncing-a-fork/) to keep my version of the Cinnamon Spices repo up-to-date, but as you can see it adds way too many commits to pull requests. Any ideas how to prevent that in the future?

Name: gpaste-reloaded@feuerfuchs.eu: Add key binding to show history
Comment_Body: I would create a second branch on your fork and work off of that. Its easier if you fetch the upstream remote before making changes, so you don't have to do any reconciliation afterwards. Then push your branch to your fork and and open the PR from it. After the PR is merged you can delete the branch and start the process over by fetching upstream and creating a branch from that. This keeps the master branch clean and in sync with upstream/master, and reduces merge conflicts.  A handy tool that's recently grown on me is [Gitkraken](https://www.gitkraken.com/). The CLI is still fundamental for development, but it makes rebasing and viewing complex repositories less tedious. Its free for non-profit use.

Comment_Body: @jaszhix Thanks, I'll give it a try!

Name: General: System Settings - Applets do not update
Comment_Body: Its working for me too. Are you behind a firewall? It could be blocking the spices server. Anyway, I think this should be opened in the Cinnamon repository since it has to do with cinnamon-settings.

Name: General: System Settings - Applets do not update
Comment_Body: Could we store the released versions of applets under releases as they are updated? So under releases would be  UUID_version.tar / zip  allowing users to download the latest zip file and install it from github (in cases like this when its blocked / not working).    This would also allow users to downgrade an app easily, ie troubleshooting a new issue since an older release.  Example of the Cinnamon repo's releases: ![selection_107](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1832491/32783964-78e62332-c91b-11e7-8a11-b595127d6f5b.png)

Name: General: System Settings - Applets do not update
Comment_Body: The releases in github are for the whole repo. Even if you somehow automate to create releases for certain applets (not sure if it's possible), we have already almost 2500 commits in less than a year. Try to find a specific applet release in GitHubs release list with 2500 releases. It's already annoying in Cinnamo. Repo with just 140 releases.  You can download the latest zip file for an applet on the spices website and install it manually.  And if you really have to install an old version of a specific applet (not sure if it happens that offen), you can search for it in the applets github history and download the ZIP there, e.g. https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/tree/4470d1b35368bbd0cd5a83efccfde08223a754a1 There's a button: "Browse this repo at this point of the history"

Name: General: System Settings - Applets do not update
Comment_Body: Sorry for the late reply. I will try supply the missing information:  Cinnamon Version: 3.4.6 Distribution: Linux Mint 18.2 Cinnamon 64-bit  Screenshot after `Refresh list`: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4856462/32800041-447979b8-c971-11e7-9d95-87b25526f8b9.png)  `~/.cinnamon/spices.cache/applet/index.json` [index.json.zip](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/files/1472246/index.json.zip)  ``` $ ll index.json  -rw-rw-r-- 1 sph sph 68797 Nov 14 19:13 index.json ``` (which is the current date, so the index.json got updated)  After I purged the cache with `rm ~/.cinnamon/spices.cache/applet/*`, I started the applet manager again. It downloaded 149 files, but the result is the same as above.  Tomorrow I will take my laptop (one of the two computers with exactly the same symptoms) into work and will try to update the list there (it's a different ISP). I will post the results.

Name: General: System Settings - Applets do not update
Comment_Body: I brought my laptop into work and everything works fine. After returning home and refreshing the list I get the list as displayed in my [post](#issuecomment-344405514l), hence I entertain the suspicion that my ISP caches the file https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/json/applets.json (at least that's the file name mentioned in `/usr/share/cinnamon/cinnamon-settings/bin/Spices.py`). Therefore I close this issue.  One curiosity: If I download the file https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/json/applets.json with `wget` I get a different file from opening it with waterfox...  Thank you all for your comments and help!

Name: UUID: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 - adding disk health indicator
Comment_Body: This is out of scope for the applet, sorry. There are already excellent tools available for anticipating data loss from HDD failure with `smartmontools` and the GNOME disks app included in Mint/Ubuntu. I think monitoring hard drives is something everybody should be a little hands on with. I wouldn't trust my data to an applet, personally. If it should exist, it should be a new applet because this multicore-sys-monitor is already seeing the effects of feature creep.

Name: UUID: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 - how to add disks to display
Comment_Body: <!-- Author list: https://github.com/jaszhix -->  **Notify author of applet** @  As I had heard nothing from you in a few days, I started poking around and located your applet code on my system.  I have never programmed an applet and have very little experience with such coding languages, so I may be utterly mistaken in my understanding of the code.  So take my input for what it is worth.  Looking at the file DataProviders.js I see a function GetDiskDevices which, if I am correctly reading the code, is to return a list of all mounted disk devices.  If this is indeed the case, it is not working as designed on my system.  The root system is hard coded in this function, as of course it is always mounted.  But as you can see from my fstab in an earlier comment I also have two other disk devices mounted, /perm and /rosa, that are not being returned.  If I am correct in my understanding of this, how can this function be corrected?  Can I provide any additional information or run any test code that would assist?

Name: UUID: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 - how to add disks to display
Comment_Body: My first guess was it had to do with the partitions using the JFS filesystem, which I haven't tested with. Are you able to format an ext4 partition and test if this is the case? I'll try to look at it this weekend.

Name: UUID: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 - how to add disks to display
Comment_Body: <!-- Author list: https://github.com/jaszhix -->  **Notify author of applet** @  As this is a multiboot system I have a few NTFS partitions for Windows 7 already present.  I created a mountpoint for one of them and mounted it as:  sudo mount -t ntfs /dev/sda2 /w7  mount | grep /dev/sda  /dev/sda12 on / type jfs (rw,relatime) /dev/sda13 on /rosa type jfs (rw,relatime) /dev/sda10 on /perm type jfs (rw,relatime) /dev/sda2 on /w7 type fuseblk (rw,relatime,user_id=0,group_id=0,allow_other,blksize=4096)  I then went into your applet preferences and still only the root partition shows.  Do I need to restart the app somehow?  Perhaps a cinnamon restart?

Comment_Body: I would actually be surprised if NTFS was supported. I don't have any plans to. It may need to be in your /etc/fstab as I have never seen removable drives show up in the applet. Are the JFS drives being seen? The documentation for the API behind fetching the volumes to monitor can be found on [devdocs](http://devdocs.baznga.org/gio20~2.50p/gio.volumemonitor).

As I commented previously:  dhdurgee@Z560 ~/Downloads $ mount | grep /dev/sda /dev/sda12 on / type jfs (rw,relatime) /dev/sda13 on /rosa type jfs (rw,relatime) /dev/sda10 on /perm type jfs (rw,relatime) /dev/sda2 on /w7 type fuseblk (rw,relatime,user_id=0,group_id=0,allow_other,blksize=4096) dhdurgee@Z560 ~/Downloads $   In the above listing the NTFS partition appears to be supported via type fuseblk, whatever that is.  All of these partitions can be viewed in mc and other file managers, so they are certainly being seen there.  If you have a diagnostic program you would like me to run for you and post the output here please let me know.

Comment_Body: Can you try this version?  [multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23.zip](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/files/1462882/multicore-sys-monitor.ccadeptic23.zip)

Name: UUID: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 - how to add disks to display
Comment_Body: @jaszhix   That is interesting.  I now see my gigolo mounted network shares as well as the root drive, but not the other locally mounted partitions.  I see the gigolo shares in the preferences dialog and can disable them, but even when I do so they show up with 0 values in the hover-over listing.  I also notice that my network activity graph shows activity, but all networks in the hover-over listing show zero values.  I noticed you only changed the DataProviders.js, so that was all I replaced.

Name: UUID: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 - how to add disks to display
Comment_Body: I think I know where the confusion is, the partitions that show up in the list each represent a drive. We are pulling all the available drive information because we are mapping the drive list by the info from   the `get_drive` call. If there is I/O activity occurring in /rosa or /perm, it should be reflected under the `/` root partition, because we can't get per-partition I/O numbers. The version I gave you simply gets the mounts instead of the volume, but that's broken for removable drives so it won't be used.  Maybe the default label for the system drive should be "System" not "/", as that is confusing.

Name: UUID: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 - how to add disks to display
Comment_Body: @jaszhix   If this is indeed data at the drive, then it would likely make more sense to label it, for example, as "/dev/sda" instead of as a partition name at all.  To label it as "/" or even "System" might confuse.  I assume that the device name is part of the data you have access to, which would allow this to be a single loop as opposed to special casing "/" as you do now.

Name: UUID: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 - how to add disks to display
Comment_Body: Actually, I think I'll leave it as is because the values are cached in JSON. Since this applet uses its own settings mechanism entirely, its probably not worth writing logic to migrate everybody over a text label. Sorry for the misunderstanding.

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 incompatibility with Cinnamon 3.6.0
Comment_Body: Well, I've been running it with the latest Cinnamon git for months - let's try to figure out what's causing it first before asserting its not compatible... Cinnamon will run with the latest version folder in the applet directory, so a `3.4` folder should work. Icing Task Manager works the same way, Cinnamon serves 3.2, 3.4, and 3.6 users from files in the 3.2 directory. I re-tested installing this applet with a clean installation a couple times today.   Do you have `gir1.2-gtop-2.0` installed? What other applets are you running? Check with `gsettings get org.cinnamon enabled-applets`.  I'm reproducing the issue with opening Preferences. Its kind of weird:  ``` (cinnamon:3095): Cjs-WARNING **: JS ERROR: Exception in callback for signal: activate: GLib.SpawnError: Failed to execute child process "prefs.js" (Permission denied) ProcessSpawnHandler.prototype._init@/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23/3.4/SpawnProcess.js:15:49 ProcessSpawnHandler@/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23/3.4/SpawnProcess.js:8:3 anonymous/MyApplet.prototype.launchPreferences@/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23/3.4/applet.js:226:34 _emit@resource:///org/cinnamon/cjs/modules/signals.js:142:27 PopupBaseMenuItem.prototype.activate@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/popupMenu.js:178:9 PopupBaseMenuItem.prototype._onButtonReleaseEvent@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/popupMenu.js:151:9 ```  When I check the permissions on the file:  ``` drwxrwxr-x  2 jason jason 4096 Oct 31 09:50 . drwxr-xr-x 64 jason jason 4096 Oct 31 09:50 .. -rw-rw-rw-  1 jason jason 6356 Oct 31 09:50 prefs.json ```  I'll see what I can find.  Edit: Oops, I misread that. prefs.js has the bad permissions. ~~But it looks fine, too~~.  ``` $ ls -al total 184 drwxrwxr-x 2 jason jason  4096 Oct 31 09:02 . drwxrwxr-x 6 jason jason  4096 Oct 31 09:02 .. -rw-rw-r-- 1 jason jason 12905 Oct 31 09:02 applet.js -rw-rw-r-- 1 jason jason  6405 Oct 31 09:02 ConfigSettings.js -rw-rw-r-- 1 jason jason 12075 Oct 31 09:02 DataProviders.js -rw-rw-r-- 1 jason jason  1209 Oct 31 09:02 ErrorApplet.js -rw-rw-r-- 1 jason jason 13387 Oct 31 09:02 Graphs.js -rw-rw-r-- 1 jason jason 23168 Oct 31 09:02 prefs.js -rw-rw-r-- 1 jason jason 88136 Oct 31 09:02 prefsui.glade -rw-rw-r-- 1 jason jason  3215 Oct 31 09:02 SpawnProcess.js -rw-rw-r-- 1 jason jason   149 Oct 31 09:02 stylesheet.css ``` Try `chmod +x ~/local/share/cinnamon/applets/multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23/3.4/prefs.js`.  Not sure why its not executable, but it needs to be called with `cjs` anyway.

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 incompatibility with Cinnamon 3.6.0
Comment_Body: I have libgtop (v2.38.0) installed though pacman and everything was working fine with it before the cinnamon update.   Here are the other applets: ``` ['panel1:left:1:menu@cinnamon.org:0', 'panel1:left:2:panel-launchers@cinnamon.org:1', 'panel1:left:3:window-list@cinnamon.org:2', 'panel1:right:14:removable-drives@cinnamon.org:3', 'panel1:right:11:notifications@cinnamon.org:14', 'panel1:right:12:keyboard@cinnamon.org:4', 'panel1:right:13:systray@cinnamon.org:7', 'panel1:right:15:power@cinnamon.org:8', 'panel1:right:16:network@cinnamon.org:6', 'panel1:right:17:sound@cinnamon.org:9', 'panel1:right:18:calendar@cinnamon.org:10', 'panel1:right:19:windows-quick-list@cinnamon.org:13', 'panel1:right:0:multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23:28'] ```  chmod the prefs.js solves the preference pane issue when using a 3.6 folder. Doing it on the 3.4 folder of a fresh install gives me a `Something went wrong ...` message in the applets manager.

Comment_Body: Not reproducing that. Do you see anything new in .xsession_errors when this occurs?

Name: [cinnamon-timer@jake1164] Make "Presets" configurable (again)
Comment_Body: This has been added to v1.1.0.    To configure right click on the applet and select configure to go into Cinnamon-Settings then select the 'Preset Times' tab.  Add / Delete / Modify the preset settings.  Once you make the change the settings will take effect.   Each setting now has a 'Label' field which will be displayed on the popup menu as well as a Custom Message that will override the default message.

Name: New Applet BgMedia@spacy01
Comment_Body: If you don't habe intention in maintaining the old BgRadio applet, you should delete it, if your new applet is a fork of your old applet.  Other Option would be, that you update the old applet with your new features. You can change the name in metadata to reflect that it has TV stream now. All you have to keep is the old UUID.

Name: New Applet BgMedia@spacy01
Comment_Body: If you keep the old UUID the people, who use your BgRadio applet, can easily upgrade to BgMedia.

Name: New Applet BgMedia@spacy01
Comment_Body: Okay, there's also [another applet](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/tree/master/radio%40driglu4it) that was forked from your radio applet that's still being maintained.  Applets sometimes break when Cinnamon is updated, and it puts more strain on us if there's more applets being fixed than there needs to be. I would only submit this one if you intend to maintain it.  I still see the re-declaration of the gettext variable I mentioned in #1402.

Name: CinnVIIStarkMenu@NikoKrause - Unable to read search results within cinnviistarkmenu in dark theme and cant find where to mod
Comment_Body: Ping @NikoKrause. I'm a little confused, are you talking about the category texts?

Name: CinnVIIStarkMenu@NikoKrause - Unable to read search results within cinnviistarkmenu in dark theme and cant find where to mod
Comment_Body: Yea the left side of menu, notice in screen 1 and screen 2 on the left inside the menu.  one is a search result typing in search bar on bottom left. the next is categories on left.  ive sent through all the configuration settings and cant seem to get the items appearing on left of menu above search bubble to he very readable. see how on the right it's nice crisp sharp darker easier to read but both search and categories on left seem as if to be faded or males me feel there's a hidden transparency slider in a sense. hehe  again not a major issue, just strange I can't find a way to darken or change color, etc of search results or categories.  do you see what I'm talking about? course full honesty I do wear glasses but to me the left pane of the menu text is faded.  But I just wanted to mention and ask and suggest something as an addon feature or maybe where can I adjust opaqueness or color of text and categories on left side. The text results from search are worse as screenshot 1 and 2 show.

Name: CinnVIIStarkMenu@NikoKrause - Unable to read search results within cinnviistarkmenu in dark theme and cant find where to mod
Comment_Body: I guess you are using the Carta theme.  The search results are perfectly readable. What you describe to be unreadable are the categories (Games, Internet, etc.) during the search.   First: It's not a CinnVIIStarkMenu issue only. It looks the same with the default Cinnamon menu. Second: It's not the problem of a menu to deal with themeing. Colors are handled by the theme. Thus it should be fixed by the theme. Third: The categories are greyed out during the search to indicate, that you can't click those buttons during the search.   If you think it's unreadable, you probably should get in touch with the creator of the theme. The [Carta theme](https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/themes/view/Carta) is maintained by [andr35](https://github.com/andr35).  If you want to change the theme on your own (I think you searched for something like `search`), since those are the category buttons, which are greyed out, you can change those by changing the `cinnamon.css` theme, namely the lines: ``` .menu-category-button-greyed {     color: rgba(250, 0, 0, 0.45); } ``` The changes you make will only apply after restarting Cinnamon (CTRL+ALT+ESC).  But remember, that your changes will be overwritten, if you update the theme.

Name: CinnVIIStarkMenu@NikoKrause - Unable to read search results within cinnviistarkmenu in dark theme and cant find where to mod
Comment_Body: P.S.: I'm happy that you like the menu and I hope this solves your issue.

Name: CinnVIIStarkMenu@NikoKrause - Unable to read search results within cinnviistarkmenu in dark theme and cant find where to mod
Comment_Body: Thank you very much! I wasn't sure if it was the applet or my desktop theme that might have been getting in the way. I started wondering if my eyes were going bad, I already wear glasses as it is... haha  But I do appreciate your time with this, that css line mod did solve it all for me. I was digging in wrong place in the css, Trying to use gcolor2 to copy in the css color codes to see if I could stumble across which was responsible for it, but still it was a fun time killer anyhow when I didn't have anything to do really.  And yea when I was using 'nano' to dig and search css (extremely old habit, as back after getting cs degree, and a couple certs, I'd always be found on our campus library system doing email in pine and editing files lazily in pico lol).  But you are spot on, I was searching for "search" in the code and trying to locate the rgb values there.   I'll add a little memo to self when updating themes where/what to modify in future after reading any latest updates here.   Again thank you for your time. Recently I rebuilt one of my old pcs in closet and maxed out the cpu on it, threw a ssd in it and my old gaming 9800 card from years ago, primarily used as my home "cloud" with 5 internal 'WD blue' drives and 3 external drives; 2 usb & 1 esata. And gave Linux Mint a try and I really  enjoy it, super light, I absolutely loved that menu applet instead of stock. I've been a Slackware guy since late 90's around the 2.0.25 kernel, but Mint is one of the perfect distros for adding a ton of new life to an aging machine.  So thank you everyone, I greatly appreciate it and hope you all have a good weekend!

Name: All Applets - Installing Dependencies
Comment_Body: I don't think there is. My applets all use gulp to watch the files and reload the extension on change. I just list the instructions to install it in the readme. For dependencies that are needed for the applet to run, its probably just a matter of ensuring the user can opt-in to installing them once the applet loads.

Name: All Applets - Installing Dependencies
Comment_Body: There's no standard way. Problem is that Cinnamom is available for Ubuntu based, Arch, etc Distributions.   You can check this applet: https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/applets/view/204  It has a way to check with apt (works at least for Debian based distros)

I recommend not wrapping big chunks of code in try-catch blocks, so it is easier to catch these kinds of small mistakes. :)

Name: [disk-read-and-write-speed@cardsurf] Add a new applet
Comment_Body: @jaszhix Thanks for the help.  Before making the pull request I tested the applet using a clean image of Linux Mint Cinnamon 18.2. I didn't see any warnings/errors in Looking Glass and the applet was running fine.

Name: [disk-read-and-write-speed@cardsurf] Add a new applet
Comment_Body: No problem. Unfortunately Looking Glass/Melange logging (~/.cinnamon/glass.log) doesn't show the logging from ~/.xsession_errors (also available with `cinnamon --replace`), and in some distributions with a different login manager, that file doesn't exist. CJS will warn or show more thorough errors in xsession_errors. Lately I've been modifying the logging function in ui/main so it dumps glass.log's output to xsession_errors, but something should probably be done about the split logging so all errors can be seen easily.  Edit: Tested again, working.

Name: sysmonitor@orcus fails to load with Applet.AllowedLayout is undefined
Comment_Body: It's because the `AllowedLayout` was introduced in Cinnamon 3.2 for vertical panels.  @OrcusCZ  You can fix this by using `try/catch` as it was done here: https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/1242/commits/9875bbce97b912d8cecc4d43425a7375e7f097c6

Name: sysmonitor@orcus fails to load with Applet.AllowedLayout is undefined
Comment_Body: Thanks.  I tried the modification you suggested locally, but the applet wouldn't load for a different reason.  I think there are probably other things that are not compatible with pre-3.2 Cinnamon in here.  If @OrcusCZ can figure out the issues that's great, but I might just try to get my Cinnamon upgraded to a newer version.

Name: sysmonitor@orcus fails to load with Applet.AllowedLayout is undefined
Comment_Body: I've installed your Cinnamon version to a virtual machine, fixed that AllowedLayout issue and found out why it won't load. I use layouts and switch controls in settings schema, they have been added in Cinnamon 3.2. To make the settings schema work in 3.0.7, layouts must be removed and switches changed to checkboxes (which are deprecated since 3.2).  I can make the applet multiversion to support both schemas, I don't think there is a better solution (correct me if I am wrong). I just tried it in my VM, it works for me and upgrading Cinnamon from 3.0.7 to 3.4.6 (version I use now) worked well and kept the settings.  @jbaldassari can you try my updated version and tell me if it works for you? Clone branch sysmon-3.0.7 from my fork, for ex. using: `git clone -b sysmon-3.0.7 https://github.com/OrcusCZ/cinnamon-spices-applets` and copy the folder `cinnamon-spices-applets/sysmonitor@orcus/files/sysmonitor@orcus` to `~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/` after removing the applet you currently have installed. Then restart Cinnamon and it should work.

Name: sysmonitor@orcus fails to load with Applet.AllowedLayout is undefined
Comment_Body: Hi @OrcusCZ.  Thanks for the quick reply.  I actually upgraded to Cinnamon to 3.2 this morning as a workaround, and then the applet worked perfectly without any modifications.  I'm sorry to have made you go through that effort, but maybe others who are still on 3.0 will benefit from the fix.  Thanks for your excellent work on this applet.  It's still my favorite system monitor!

Name: sysmonitor@orcus fails to load with Applet.AllowedLayout is undefined
Comment_Body: Hi, no problem. I've a VM setup for this because every time someone has a problem, it's always different version of Cinnamon than mine. I'll assume that this fixes the issue for everyone on 3.0, since it works for me. Glad you like the applet :)

Name: added applet ipindicator@matus.benko@gmail.com
Comment_Body: Cool applet, it seems to work well. I noticed one small issue, though.  `Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/ipindicator@matus.benko@gmail.com/applet.js 122]: assignment to undeclared variable IpGateway`  This is not crashing the applet because of the try-catch block in your applet's `_init` method, but I recommend fixing it because it may crash the applet in newer versions of Cinnamon. You just need to declare `Debugger` and `IpGateway` with `let` or optionally `const` if they are not re-assigned later.

Name: [commandLauncher@scollins] notification with error
Comment_Body: Not sure why it stopped working. All the documentation and code points to the function in question working the way it was already written in my applet, but I changed it anyway, and it seemed to fix the issue.

Name: [commandLauncher@scollins] notification with error
Comment_Body: Signatures of `GLib.child_watch_add` function are different in [Gjs](https://wiki.gnome.org/Projects/Gjs) and in [GLib C library](https://developer.gnome.org/glib/). In Gjs `function` is declared as the [3rd parameter](https://people.gnome.org/~gcampagna/docs/GLib-2.0/GLib.child_watch_add.html) and in GLib C library as the [2nd parameter](https://developer.gnome.org/glib/stable/glib-The-Main-Event-Loop.html#g-child-watch-add).

Name: Added DGS applet files
Comment_Body: Hi, the [file structure](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets#file-structure) needs to be ```UUID/files/UUID/```, so the extension can be extracted into a directory with the UUID as its name.  I noticed this warning:  ``` Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/dgs-bpivaty@gmail.com/applet.js line 44]: reference to undefined property this.myId ```  I think its because object properties can't be initialized without assignment, like variables can.

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23: Wrong Network Monitoring
Comment_Body: I'm half way tempted to just set the author to none, I don't really want anyone to not feel welcome to submit a PR. Its a pretty hefty applet, and the code has some issues, and bad workarounds the original author documents.  ![screenshot from 2017-08-29 11-21-38](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6859057/29832080-a4b17fee-8cac-11e7-92b0-38d9ed403b45.png)  For reference, the tooltip data for networks is accurate for me, but I notice the graphs show a steady line near the top, and they're all white. One thing I tried to address was the author adding keyed strings to arrays, and treating it like an object, so I had to redo the iteration inside the network data provider.  I think if you're going to open an issue on something entirely hardware dependent, you should be a _little_ willing to provide more info. Are you using NetworkManager? Try typing ```systemctl status NetworkManager```.

Name: ioDisk@ctrlesc: Disk Utilization applet not working
Comment_Body: I'm on Linux Mint 18.2 with Cinnamon 3.4. I installed sysstat and this applet. It shows always 0% for me. Also it doesn't pop up to show my two hard drives.  So I think it's not a Debian or Cinnamon 3.2 specific issue.  To clearify a little bit. The applets on the Cinnamon spices website are 3rd party applets. This means they are created by guys, which do not belong to the Linux Mint Team. Since all the applets from the old website have been migrated to this repo for the new website, a lot of broken and abandoned applets have been migrated as well. Some guys of the Linux Mint team have reviewed, fixed and deleted a lot of those applets. And they try to help where they can.  The author/developer of this applet has abandoned it. Some applets are easy to fix and others are difficult, especially if you are not familiar with the code. Since the guy, who is most familiar with the code, namely the author, has abandoned it, this won't be easy to fix.  If you're lucky, somebody who has time and skills sees this and might fix it or wants to maintain it. This can take some time.  The issue has been reported on the spices website 3 weeks ago. Bugs should be reported best here on GitHub. Unfortunatelly we don't get any notifications, when somebody makes a comment or reports a bug in a comment on the spices website. And nobodys clicking through hundreds of applets pages to see, if somebody wrote a new comment somewhere. So an issue is seen on GitHub faster. We know about this issue and try to improve it in the future.  That said I took a quick look at the logs and I don't see anything related to this applet. So I'm not sure what causes it. And right now I don't have much time to spare to look any further into this.

And that under Mint (some versions, since the 18.2 live usb applet works, I just tested) And that under Debian no matter the version (Stretch, Buster) impossible to operate (symptoms described in the 1st message)  There may be a necessary dependency that works in parallel with sysstat.?? Installed on Arch, Fedora, Mint 18.2, but not on a Debian in netinstall.?? Name: ioDisk@ctrlesc: Disk Utilization applet not working
Comment_Body: > The applet is abandoned.??  If an applet has an active author/developer, than he's mentioned on the website, e.g. [this applet](https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/applets/view/105) says `by jamesmorgan`  And the [Disk Utilization](https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/applets/view/161) applet has no author, therefore there is no `by ...` mention. Looking at the [old website](http://web.archive.org/web/20160603031840/https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/applets/view/161), the [author](http://web.archive.org/web/20150914160308/http://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/users/view/3319) has been active last time on 2014-09-23 04:40:47  There's no notification for comments on the spices website yet. That's why nobody noticed your comment there.  > But it was updated 3 weeks ago, so it's recent abandonment.  Looking at the history/changelog of this applet by pressing on  **Last commit:** [0fe19dc01d806dbcb5bf61594087c01ca6a1ee70](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/commits/master/ioDisk@ctrlesc)  the updates on this applet have been only translations from people, who like to help out with translations. The last update was adding a Danish translation (da.po).

Name: ioDisk@ctrlesc: Disk Utilization applet not working
Comment_Body: OK I can see what's wrong.  It actually works for me here... the reason I get 0% is because I'm on an SSD and it's actually almost always 0% or close to it (in the file too).  Now, the reason it doesn't work in Debian is because iostat doesn't return the same data there than in other distros. I can see in your Arch pastebin that it returns 13 values... the 13th being the percentage usage. Same thing in Mint. But looking at your pastebin in Debian I see 15 values instead...   The code is designed to run iostat -dxh 1 2 and to gather the 13th value... so if that value isn't there but in 15th position instead, it won't work.  So the applet needs to be adapted to either run iostat in a way that works in both older and newer versions of iostat, or get the value some other way.  There. Analysis done ;)

Name: ioDisk@ctrlesc: Disk Utilization applet not working
Comment_Body: Ha yes indeed well seen for difference. So we know where the problem comes from. So it is insolvent. Debian will not change its iostat so it will be like those of Fedora, Arch etc  Very annoying of the blow :/

Name: ioDisk@ctrlesc: Disk Utilization applet not working
Comment_Body: The code uses a bunch of regular expressions. It relied on the fact, that iostat output has only numbers. But the output from Debian has also stuff like `305,4k` and `5,4%`, so it uses `k` and `%` signs and not only numbers.  I don't have the time right now. Maybe I'll look in a few weeks into it or somebody else is faster than me. (Now that the reason of the bug is found.)

The only thing that does not work is the rendering of the settings in applet settings window, and I don't figure why.  The only possible options I find are:  - Something has changed since Cinnamon 3.4.6 in xlet-settings. - Something is missing in pot files.  I have recreated pot file and Spanish po file and the problem persists.  That NoneType error in xlet-settings is really strange. Name: Icing Task Manager : High Idle CPU Usage since last few updates
Comment_Body: Backing up a little bit, what would help me to understand this is: - What percentage of CPU resources is consumed by the Cinnamon thread - What you were doing when you noticed the high CPU usage. - Does it always have high usage from initialization to the point its noticed?  @Piiit This particular issue could be caused if you were dragging or pinning something, ```insert_child_at_index``` is used in the drag handlers. If you noticed there's a correlation there it might be somewhere to look. I can't reproduce it in VM or on my laptop though.  ``` (cinnamon:2690): Clutter-CRITICAL **: clutter_actor_insert_child_at_index: assertion 'child->priv->parent == NULL' failed  (firefox:3124): Gtk-WARNING **: Attempting to read the recently used resources file at '/home/pemoser/.local/share/recently-used.xbel', but the parser failed: Datei »/home/pemoser/.local/share/recently-used.xbel« konnte nicht geöffnet werden: Keine Berechtigung. Cinnamon warning: Log level 16: Attempting to read the recently used resources file at '/home/pemoser/.local/share/recently-used.xbel', but the parser failed: Datei »/home/pemoser/.local/share/recently-used.xbel« konnte nicht geöffnet werden: Keine Berechtigung. Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/main.js 1231]: reference to undefined property Meta.KeyBindingAction.PANEL_MAIN_MENU Cinnamon warning: Log level 8: Source ID 2066 was not found when attempting to remove it Cjs-Message: JS LOG: About to start Cinnamon ```  @Protarios This part of the log looks like Wine is causing issues:  ``` QXcbConnection: XCB error: 3 (BadWindow), sequence: 2178, resource id: 96468997, major code: 4 (DestroyWindow), minor code: 0 Gtk-Message: GtkDialog mapped without a transient parent. This is discouraged. Schreibtischdatei /usr/share/applications/caja-browser.desktop konnte nicht für Leistenstarter geöffnet werden Schreibtischdatei /usr/share/applications/mate-terminal.desktop konnte nicht für Leistenstarter geöffnet werden  (nm-applet:1678): Gdk-CRITICAL **: gdk_window_thaw_toplevel_updates: assertion 'window->update_and_descendants_freeze_count > 0' failed  (blueberry-tray.py:1879): Gtk-WARNING **: gtk_widget_size_allocate(): attempt to allocate widget with width -8 and height 1 Cjs-Message: JS LOG: About to start Cinnamon ```  The last error is from network manager before your crash, and there's no telling what Wine is doing here.  Some of these issues are fixed on Cinnamon's master branch.

Name: Icing Task Manager : High Idle CPU Usage since last few updates
Comment_Body: I went ahead and logged every single method in ITM, to be sure nothing is continuously being called. There appears to be a loop getting stuck when its reloaded via Melange from a recursive actor.get_stage call, but adding, moving, removing the applet, or other applets doesn't trigger this. I also ran this in a 3.4 VM, and did some typical things like pinning apps and reordering them. The Cinnamon thread eventually idles at 0% on my host and the guest, from a range of 2-28% usage.  Here's the file if anyone wants to provide their glass.log, it may help identify what's getting called too much, or confirm my suspicion about the reload issue.  [IcingTaskManager@json-debug-1.zip](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/files/1268790/IcingTaskManager.json-debug-1.zip)

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23: Unable to show on multiple panels

The same is not true for some other applets such as the Icing Task Manager, Calendar, or Menu, of which I can add multiple instances onto even the same panel.

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23: Unable to show on multiple panels
Comment_Body: I looked at the code. You can have only one instance of this applet.  Some apps have issues, when you allow them to add more than one instance. I'm not sure if it's one of those applets.  The author of this applet is @jaszhix, he surely knows it.

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23: Unable to show on multiple panels
Comment_Body: Yeah, it doesn't have the ```max-instances``` property set in metadata.info. The applet makes use of libraries that are a bit on the heavier side, so I am reluctant to make it available for multiple panels. Its doing a lot for just one instance, it is gathering system info and updating four graphs in real-time. I would say this isn't likely to happen until I get more refactoring done, and fix some [usability issues](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20is%3Aopen%20multicore).

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23: Unable to show on multiple panels
Comment_Body: I'm going to skip this for now because the applet is a little CPU demanding since it runs a series of functions on a timer indefinitely. If more people become interested in this feature, I can re-open this and consider it again.

Name: bumblebee@pdcurtis: bumblebeed executable wrong location
Comment_Body: @KickerTom @jaszhix I will have a look at this.   On my machine bumblebeed is in /usr/sbin which is where I would expect and PATH includes /usr/sbin and /sbin and this was checked on Mint 18 and 18.1, 18.1 and 18.2. Is this a feature of LMDE ? If necessary I will remove the check altogether as there is already a check of the contents of /proc/acpi/bbswitch which catches the error of bbswitch not running and hence bumblebee not being installed.  @jaszhix @NikoKrause  @Odyseus Does anyone know better and more foolproof and elegant checks for installed programs and/or file presence which are checked to work on LMDE and Mint?

Name: bumblebee@pdcurtis: bumblebeed executable wrong location
Comment_Body: Take a look at menu applets. Specifically, the code handling building the categories also can handle fetching the desktop apps by iterating ```app_system.get_tree()```.

Name: bumblebee@pdcurtis: bumblebeed executable wrong location
Comment_Body: > On my machine bumblebeed is in /usr/sbin which is where I would expect and PATH includes /usr/sbin and /sbin and this was checked on Mint 18 and 18.1, 18.1 and 18.2. Is this a feature of LMDE ?  Looks like this really is a difference between Ubuntu and Debian (thus also between Mint and LMDE). Debian just does not add /sbin and /usr/sbin to the path of any other user than root. E.g. here is a related comment: https://unix.stackexchange.com/questions/232782/is-there-a-reason-i-would-not-add-usr-local-sbin-usr-sbin-sbin-to-my-path-o  > Take a look at menu applets. Specifically, the code handling building the categories also can handle fetching the desktop apps by iterating app_system.get_tree().  Isn't get_tree() being obsoleted in recent gtk? But mainly, will this return also programs which have binaries not in path, and not in the menu system? Bumblebeed is not an desktop app...  Personally, I do not see much reason to check for bumblebeed binary at all, it is not being executed by the applet. It's the /proc/acpi/bbswitch which is used, and which should be (and already is, as you stated) checked for existence, correct? So maybe doing explicit check for the bbswitch file in place of the binary check and displaying the error if not found would make more sense.  Anyway, thanks for your fast response and your time you spend on this.

Name: bumblebee@pdcurtis: bumblebeed executable wrong location
Comment_Body: @KickerTom I had already started to remove the check as a short term fix. The logic in the extra check was to give a warning which included an indication of what to do before the applet loop started to run. I can do the same with a check of the presence of /proc/acpi/bbswitch at the start but my current code lacks elegance at present.   The check for a daemon/program by GLib.find_program_in_path("program") is also used in other applets (including another of mine and 7 others) and in fact I was advised to use it to ensure dependencies were met in applets. Your input is valuable as I had no idea that Debian and Ubuntu differed in this important aspect.   @mtwebster You may be interested or even wish to take part in this conversation!

Name: bumblebee@pdcurtis: bumblebeed executable wrong location
Comment_Body: Huh I didn't know that about LMDE.    This is sort of an ugly area - I hate snooping around files from an applet, but it's unavoidable.  Definitely for executables, g_find_program_in_path is best - as mentioned the app sys works from our menu tree, which is populated solely via desktop files.  For normal files, I'd use g_file_test - *don't* use g_file_query_exists (it blocks).  Using g_file_query_info, you can construct an asynchronous version of checking whether a file exists, but I'm not sure it's worth it here, g_file_test should do the trick.   It does make me wonder if we would benefit from a nice rolled-up function that any applet could use - an  asynchronous file existence check.

Name: bumblebee@pdcurtis: bumblebeed executable wrong location
Comment_Body: @mtwebster I had found GLib.file_test and was looking at something like    `this._isFileInstalled = GLib.file_test('file', GLib.FileTest.EXISTS);` but had not though about the issue of synchronous and asynchronous but I have got as far as finding it is used in quite a number of applets so it looked a good bet.  How does one know if functions are asynchronous?  Your idea of a nice rolled-up function that any applet could use - an asynchronous file existence check seems sensible or a well tested example for people to follow when checking for 'dependencies' being met for an applet.  Is there actually anything against using try and catch with a file read as an alternative if one has to eventually read a file's contents as I do in my bumblebee applet?  One of the major problems I find with use of the synchronous functions is that it trips the dangerous flag and associated warnings which puts people off using applets regardless of whether it is a real problem or not - do we need a mechanism for reviewing applets so that the warnings can be removed or at least tone down if problems are unlikely?

Name: bumblebee@pdcurtis: bumblebeed executable wrong location
Comment_Body: @KickerTom I think I have found a very simple fix for the applet which is to check for the presence of optirun instead of bumblebeed as optirun is in /usr/bin and should be just as good a check that bumblebee is installed.  ``` @@ -144,8 +144,8 @@ MyApplet.prototype = {                 this.textEd = "xed";              }   -            // Check that Bumblebee Daemen is installed  -            if (!GLib.find_program_in_path("bumblebeed")) { +            // Check that Bumblebee is installed by presence of optirun +            if (!GLib.find_program_in_path("optirun")) {                   let icon = new St.Icon({ icon_name: 'error',                   icon_type: St.IconType.FULLCOLOR,                   icon_size: 36 });  ``` Can you confirm that solves the problem under LMDE and I will generate the Pull Request.

Name: bumblebee@pdcurtis: bumblebeed executable wrong location
Comment_Body: I am sorry for late reaction. Tested it now (update from oficial repo, now you merged it) and it works perfectly. Thanks a lot for such a fast fix.

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: Heyo,  thanks for adding the other redshift features! Looks nice.  But there are some small things I'd propose to change before merging. If you get around to look into them, feel free, else I'll give it a shot one of these days. - The order in the applet menu is now a bit confusing. Maybe there should be a redshift-one shot section and then a redshift-automatic change section. Right now it's a bit mixed up and I think not clear what the two buttons do. - The two buttons don't interact well. For example if you have both on and turn off the night change, the one-shot is not activated. I guess one should be set to off if the other is activated - when changing the one-shot settings on the sliders there is now a flickering that I think wasn't there before - the brightness can be displayed as 57.9999999999% which should be rounded I guess - nice to have the changing icons! But since my original intention was to imitate a sun-set maybe we could have a day-sun and a sunset-sun? Or a sun and a moon? Opinions? - also I'd update the Readme to include the new features  That's it for now. Do you agree? Cheers, Marvin.

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: The Material Design Icon has a lot of icons to choose from: https://materialdesignicons.com/  You find the license of those icon here in the README: https://github.com/Templarian/MaterialDesign

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: I agree with your proposals.  Only a notice: @Marvel4U says that only one checkbox (change on night or Redshfit) should be enabled at time. My idea is different: Redshfit checkbox starts or stops Redshift at all, if Change on night is enabled then Redshift is started with transition between day and night, otherwise Redshift is started in one-shot mode.  It's true that now when you disable Change on night mode, Redshift does not start in oneshot mode. This is a bug and I'm going to work in fixing it.  Another notice: I think that sun and moon or similar icons are not properly because they could be confused between Change on night and enabled modes. I will search properly icons.  When changes have been finished I will comment again!  Thanks and regards.

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: Hello!  I have finished all changes. Below are the changes:  >     The order in the applet menu is now a bit confusing. Maybe there should be a redshift-one shot section and then a redshift-automatic change section. Right now it's a bit mixed up and I think not clear what the two buttons do. Configuration menu is divided in three sections now. Also, Redshift switch has been pushed just before day/oneshot settings. Hence, in the applet each switch is the separator of each section: general brightness on top, enable/disable Redshift marks Redshift options and Transition on night switch marks night options. It could be a bit confusing that day brightness and colour values are also used in oneshot mode, but I think that adding two more sliders would be weird and the applet too much big. So, oneshot mode is like saying that it is always daylight.  >     The two buttons don't interact well. For example if you have both on and turn off the night change, the one-shot is not activated. I guess one should be set to off if the other is activated when changing the one-shot settings on the sliders there is now a flickering that I think wasn't there before Bug when changing applet modes have been fixed. Now, one or two seconds happens between changing modes but this is the time lapsed on killing old Redshift transition mode. Flickering has also been fixed launching redshift -x command only on disabled mode. However, in transition mode a bit of flickering happends because Redshift reset temperature and bright to the maximum and then gradually changes color to the corresponding time.  >     the brightness can be displayed as 57.9999999999% which should be rounded I have not seen never brightness with decimals, and in the code I see rounds in all functions. Could you please fix it if you detect it?  >    I guess nice to have the changing icons! But since my original intention was to imitate a sun-set maybe we could have a day-sun and a sunset-sun? Or a sun and a moon? Opinions?  I think you will love the new icons! Now a black light bulb is used for disabled Redshift, a red light bulb is used for oneshot mode and a red sunset is used for transition mode. Icons have been modified from Material icons.  >     also I'd update the Readme to include the new features Readme has been updated   I hope you like all the changes!  Below, the TO-DO tasks: - I have updated pot file and Spanish po file, but german and chiness translations should be done. - In spite of regenerate pot file and translating to Spanish, I only can see translated the 'brightness' string (that come from the forked applet for you). I have never worked with pot, so I don't know if something more has to be done for translations appear.  And lastly a notice: as settings schema has been changed, you have to delete your ~/.cinnamon/configs/redshift@marvel4u folder to reload the new schema and see the changes. I suppose that Cinnamon will do it when the applet be installed in users computer using Cinnamon applet settings.   Thanks and regards.

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: Hello, looks really nice, thanks for fixing the issues! The changed order makes it much more understandable. That the day-sliders have a kind of double role is indeed a bit strange but I think people will figure it out. The flickering is gone and at least for now I don't get the decimals any more. And thanks for the new icons, I think they are very clear and mark the differences in state nicely.  About the Language: the translations also don't work for me but I don't know what the issue is here. Running the makepot didn't change anything. And the dangerous flag is there again. Could it be that it's added automatically somehow?  Anyway these are somewhat minor issues... and since this pull request is marked as such: Approval by author given ;) Cheers.

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: About translations: Here's a tutorial I wrote some time ago. It explains how to update existing translations and how to test them, when changed. https://github.com/NikoKrause/CinnVIIStarkMenu/issues/19  I'd have a question and a suggestion for the applet: (1) The Brightness slider at the very top doesn't seem to do anything for me. (2) It would be nice to see the current/detected location and the current color temperature.

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: Hello @NikoKrause.  The brighness slider does also not work for me, but why the Cinnamon-settings-daemon crashes on startup in my system. If you see an error similar to this in ~ /.cinnamon/glass.log, probably this is the cause: Error getting Cinnamon backlight power settings true,,Error: GDBus.Error:org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.ServiceUnknown:.  About your suggestions, I think that the applet should not be more saturated. However, having **in the tooltip** current location and max and min brightness and color temperature (only current in one-shot mode) would be nice. I think that current color temperature doesn't worth, since it requires executing Redshift in verbose mode and saving constantly the standard output (I think that Redshift-gtk does it this way, and Redshift has not another option for doing it).  About language, I think that it has to be related with some cache, since I have fully uninstalled the applet and installed from Cinnamon Settings and not I see configuration window translated (though the applet remains in English). @Marvel4U, when you do something more with translations, I have just discover a bug: 'ongitud' must be 'Longitud' in Spanish es.po.  In any case, I think that one issue should be opened for translation fixes and another one for your suggestions, since they are a bit out of scope of this pull request and it has already be merged.   Thanks and regards.

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: My personal view (please feel free to ignore, I don't want to tell you how to design your applet, the following is my opinion only): Right now all the sliders and switches, which pop up, when you click in the applet are also available in the settings. Once I set up the color temperature, I don't want to change them anymore very often. Also I don't want to change them by accident, which can happen very fast, since the sliders are in the pop up. I would just show the needed infos about color temperature and location and the switches. And I would show the sliders only in the settings. It's hard to adjust them anyway. They jump with steps of 50, i.e. it's hard to set a temperature of exactly 6500. You have to type it in the settings.

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: I think that it is good being be able to change values in applet, for instance if the current day is specially cloudy you could want to change color and brightness values fastly. Another example is people that don't use transition between day and night and want one-shot mode in their way. In addition, maybe not all people know applet settings.  Initially the applet had not settings, they are specially useful for remember user values instead loading defaults in each system startup.  It's true that setting the exact value in the applet is not easy, but I think that many people would play with values until get a confortable set of values, and this is difficult in changing values in settings.  In conclusion, although a bit replicated, settings in applet and applet settings are complementary. I think that it would be very useful having a fast summary in applet tooltip but, as I commented in my previous comment, this is not so easy (specially current Redshift calculated value, the rest of values are feasible with a bit of work).  What do you think about all these questions, @Marvel4U? If you agree maybe I begin this change soon.  @NikoKrause, I appreciate your advises.  Thanks and regards.

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: OK. Valid points. Then just ignore my comments. I don't change values that often.

Name: redshfit@marvel4u: Applet settings and optionally night value changes
Comment_Body: Just as a final comment on this merger... I super agree with @Martin1887 . Actually the main reason to make this applet was so I can change the temperature quickly on the panel without opening any settings or a terminal to run redshift. I'm exactly the kind of person who uses the one-shot and changes the temperature every half hour depending on how late it already got.

Name: Inbuilt panel launcher applet: ended up with a duplicate when I should not have
Comment_Body: > I moved the file the applet runs.  Why? You're not supposed to do that. If you move it to where Spices applets are located, it will override the other applet in /usr/share/cinnamon, unless you change its uuid. In any case, I don't think what you're doing is a normal use case, or should be considered a bug because it takes a lot more man hours to workaround that in code, when you can simply not move system files around.  > hard to tell, because something else seems to be filling that log  You should paste the log.  Stock applets shipped with Cinnamon need to have their issues opened in the [correct place](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20launcher).

Name: Inbuilt panel launcher applet: ended up with a duplicate when I should not have
Comment_Body: I seem to have been unclear. The file that I was moving was _not_ a system file. Rather, it was the file that is run by the launcher in question.  I will post a clearer version of this bug report, with a log, in the correct place.

Name: CODEOWNERS: try ** instead of * so that it has infinite depth
Comment_Body: Hello, @NikoKrause.  It seems that there is no indication that the CODEOWNERS file is actually working in this repository (?). Have you seen any change after you added the *"double asterisks"* to it? I followed your tests on your own repository and also didn't see any signs of it working.  On the other hand, I scanned GitHub for repositories (I looked at hundreds of them) using the CODEOWNERS file and in all of them it seems to be working as expected.  Maybe the *default owners* needs to be specified at the beginning of the file? Maybe the repositories that belong to an organization works differently? Or maybe this new feature hasn't propagated to all of GitHub yet? But I think that before continuing to speculate and doing more tests blindly, it might be time to contact GitHub support to shed some light in the matter.

Name: CODEOWNERS: try ** instead of * so that it has infinite depth
Comment_Body: Hey @Odyseus ,  I've already contacted GitHub support a few times. The results of the contact was: 1. The tests on my own repo didn't worked, because "the automatic review will only happen if the author of the pull request is not the code owner". "This happens because you can not be a reviewer on a pull request that you authored." 2. Another reason why it didn't worked was, "that CODEOWNERS file [wa]sn't working for directories with the @-symbol in its name". "This bug with the `@` in the directory name [...] has now been fixed." 3. After I got the mail, that the bug has been fixed, I observed, that it still doesn't work. So I contacted GitHub support again. I got an answer from Laura (@lecoursen) to "try using `**` instead of `*` here, so that it has infinite depth". But that didn't worked. Now I'm waiting for an answer.  I wonder, which requirements the CODEOWNER feature has. A thought experiment: You create a CODEOWNER file in one of your repos and add some user, who has nothing to do with the repo. He gets everytime a notification to review a PR, and has no chance to turn those off.  So I'm not sure how it works properly. Hoping to get an answer soon.

Name: Spices Repo Itself: add CODEOWNERS file
Comment_Body: Hello, @NikoKrause.  I think that it would be better to use a script that would generate the **CODEOWNERS** file automatically. That way, it would be easier to maintain and keep up-to-date.  I made such a script yesterday when I found out about this new GitHub feature (in Python, I completely suck at BASH).  [Give it a try if you want](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/files/1132691/codeowners_creator.py.zip). It has to be executed from inside the **.github** folder and it will overwrite an existent **CODEOWNERS** file. it also ignores xlets whose authors are set to **none** (It's just pointless to add a reference to a nonexistent GitHub user).

Name: Spices Repo Itself: add CODEOWNERS file
Comment_Body: I commented the @none lines out.  I don't think we need a script for that. This file should be changed as often as the info.json files, i.e.  * If an applet is deleted * If an author changes * If someone uploads a new applet   this file should be edited. And that doesn't happen that often.

Name: Spices Repo Itself: add CODEOWNERS file
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause If we edit it manually, there is more likely to be mistakes. I know, for example, that I'm going to forget once in a while. And the author shouldn't be expected to edit the file themselves. In fact, I'm not sure we want them to touch anything outside the folder of their own applet. If we automate it like @Odyseus suggests, we can just run it periodically when we think of it, and it should catch anything we might have forgotten.

Name: Spices Repo Itself: add CODEOWNERS file
Comment_Body: Well idc.

Name: Spices Repo Itself: add CODEOWNERS file
Comment_Body: @Odyseus  Your python script works here. Do you want to open a PR?

Name: Spices Repo Itself: add CODEOWNERS file
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @NikoKrause: I can do that. But that script was just a practical example (it doesn't have *safeguards* and it's slow as heck (LOL)). I created an *improved* version ([can be seen here](https://gist.github.com/Odyseus/5010cfbbc517fb5b5b6297594bd59e47) and [this is how the resultant file would look like](https://gist.github.com/Odyseus/5010cfbbc517fb5b5b6297594bd59e47#gistcomment-2145023)).  Before publishing it, I would like some input from you all.  - At the beginning of the generated file is a comment that specifies that the file shouldn't be edited manually and how to generate it. - The xlets without author are grouped at the end commented out. So it's easier to see them at a glance. The comment that separates these xlets reads *"The following xlets have no author assigned to them."*. Maybe add some more details to this comment? - I used the word *xlets* so the script can be used in the 4 Spices repositories without the need to edit it.

Name: Spices Repo Itself: add CODEOWNERS file
Comment_Body: Looks good to me

Name: sysmonitor@orcus: GTop.glibtop.get_netlist is not a function
Comment_Body: I've installed LMDE 2 Betsy in VM and was able to reproduce the issue. For some reason, get_netlist function is not exported through GObject introspection (its gir file contains "introspectable=0"), although netlist structure is, but it can't be used for anything without that function. I am not sure where this problem comes from and if something can be done about it, since I don't understand GObject introspection that well.  Older versions of this applet used network manager to retrieve a list of network interfaces. Not everyone uses network manager, so I dropped this dependency in favor of glibtop's netlist feature. I can add fallback to either network manager or use directly /sys/class/net to retrieve the interfaces. I think the latter is better, because it doesn't create any additional dependency.  I've modified the applet to use /sys/class/net if netlist fails, could you replace providers.js with this file and test if it works for you? https://github.com/OrcusCZ/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/sysmon-netlist/sysmonitor%40orcus/files/sysmonitor%40orcus/providers.js

Name: sysmonitor@orcus: GTop.glibtop.get_netlist is not a function
Comment_Body: Oops, I forgot to follow up on this until now. I downloaded your updated version, diffed it against mine, replaced it, and re-added the applet. After I re-enabled it, the network graph reappeared, so I guess the fallback you implemented is working ;)  Thank you for fixing this so quickly!

Name: sysmonitor@orcus: GTop.glibtop.get_netlist is not a function
Comment_Body: Hi, thanks for letting me know it works now. I am glad to hear that :) I will create pull request with my patch so the fix should be live soon.

Name: temperature@fevimu: Applet doesn't start after Upgrade to Sonya 18.2
Comment_Body: You need to update the applet. SystemSettings->Applets->AvailableApplets(online)->Resfresh List-> Apply updates  You are using an old version. Your log says `No JS module panelMenu found`. This has been fixed a month ago https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/commit/7b0f57c4f83e0c12449230afc5aaf59e609b3e68

Name: temperature@fevimu: Applet doesn't start after Upgrade to Sonya 18.2
Comment_Body: Being that this is LinuxMint's own tracker, etc.  "You are using an old version." isn't a VALID answer, @NikoKrause to be blunt about it.  If it got broke on an update to 18.2 (Mine did...), and 18.2's been out for HOW long?  (July...this is SEPTEMBER) then someone's screwed it all up.  Closing it when it's been "fixed" and yet not is the same mentality that systemd's bunch has that earned them a Pwnie this year.  I don't consider this a good thing.  FIX IT in updates for 18.2 and DON'T close it until the updates go out.

Name: temperature@fevimu: Applet doesn't start after Upgrade to Sonya 18.2
Comment_Body: This isn't like windows where this is a separate program and ran as a separate update system- this is part of MINT.

Name: temperature@fevimu: Applet doesn't start after Upgrade to Sonya 18.2
Comment_Body: The applets have to be updated manually. The `panelMenu` module has been removed in 18.2 and the applet has been fixed on 25 April. Which means that the update of this applet is available since 25 April (for all Cinnamon/Mint versions) If you upgrade from 18.1 to 18.2 and had the applet already installed, it won't get updated automatically. You have to refresh the list and apply the updates.  Spices are not part of MINT. They are only available for/through Cinnamon. They are 3rd party applets/desklets/extensions/themes. This spices repo and the review process of the spices is pretty new (since January 2017).  Right now there's no option to update applets automatically. But the Mint team is aware of this issue. For now all I can do, is to tell you how to update your applet manually. If it's still broken for you after you updated it, let us know.

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 stops working after upgrade from mint 18.1 to 18.2
Comment_Body: I just upgraded Linux Mint from 18.1 to 18.2. Multi-core-system-monitor stopped working. Tried following @jaszhix recommendation of deleting the applet from the panel settings, removing the two folders, and re-installing from the applet settings. After deleting the applet from the panel settings, I could no longer see the two directories mentioned. It seems like they were removed when the applet was deleted from the panel settings. I then went ahead and installed the applet again. It downloaded the applet anew and installed it. All of that did not work, I continue to get the same error message. So there is at least one case (mine) where the instructions are not working to fix the issue. How to proceed?

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 stops working after upgrade from mint 18.1 to 18.2
Comment_Body: Make sure you are refreshing the applet list in xlet settings after removing the applet.  Is it creating ```~/.cinnamon/configs/multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23```, and if so is prefs.json located there?  Do you see any errors in ```~/.cinnamon/glass.log``` or ```~/.xsession-errors```?

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 stops working after upgrade from mint 18.1 to 18.2
Comment_Body: Ahh.. refreshing the applet list prior to reinstalling it did the trick. Thank you. The matter is now resolved.  For reference, the full steps when upgrading from Linux Mint 18.1 were  1. Go to applet settings and remove/delete the multi-core-system-monitor applet 2. Verify that the two directories mentioned above are already removed when the applet is deleted. This was the case for me, but I guess if they are still around, they can be deleted manually 3. Go the the applet list and refresh 4. Reinstall.  Thank you very much :)

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23 stops working after upgrade from mint 18.1 to 18.2
Comment_Body: On my 2 Ubuntu 16.04 systems at home I followed @jaszhix's advice to delete the directories and reinstall, and it worked great. However on my similar system at work, it failed no matter what I tried, saying it couldn't find applet.js. I finally figured out my stock 16.04 system had a downrev version of Cinnamon. I upgraded by adding the [unofficial PPA](https://launchpad.net/~embrosyn/+archive/ubuntu/cinnamon) and that did the trick: ``` sudo add-apt-repository ppa:embrosyn/cinnamon sudo apt update sudo apt full-upgrade ```

Name: Cinnamenu@json: Update to 2.0.0
Comment_Body: Nice.  Very fast and snappy in use, and looks better, to me anyway.  Not sure about the bookmarks at the top, but I guess that's personal taste. Can this show Opera bookmarks?  I get the Firefox bookmarks with Gir1.2-gda-5.0. Still munches up memory though, I am on about +200MB over typical Cinnamon memory usage right now

Name: Cinnamenu@json: Update to 2.0.0
Comment_Body: Thanks! The bookmarks for me still cause unresponsiveness for a couple seconds when hovering over them (I have 300+), so I moved them to the top so people with tons of them like me don't keep accidentally triggering the loading of them. If I can figure out an optimization for adding hundreds of actors to a parent, I can move that back down.   I'm currently working on code that checks if an actor is visible using position, width, and height on ```scroll-event```, so it only adds actors to the parent if they're visible (or perhaps hides them if they're not). ```Clutter.Actor.is_visible()``` is unfortunately assuming anything on the stage is visible. This is a trick I use in web app projects for rendering huge lists, but still not sure I can get it working in Clutter.  I haven't tested Opera on this install - I'll see if that's working.

Name: [window-list@zeripath.sdf-eu.org] Rebase to version 3.4.3 of window-list@cinnamon.org
Comment_Body: This seems fine to me, though I'm not sure what differences there are between this and the default window list applet.  One small issue however is the directory structure, applet files should be placed in ```window-list@zeripath.sdf-eu.org/files/window-list@zeripath.sdf-eu.org/```.

Name: [window-list@zeripath.sdf-eu.org] Rebase to version 3.4.3 of window-list@cinnamon.org
Comment_Body: Hi! I didn't create the file-structure but if you'd prefer a different file structure I'd be happy to move things to that.  The main difference between this and the original window-list is that:  * Clicking on the Window List Button for a focused Maximized window will   Unmaximize it. Clicking once again will Minimize it. * Clicking on the Window List Button for a Minimized window will Restore the   window, clicking once again will Minimize it. * Double-clicking on the Window List Button for a Maximized window will   Minimize the window. * Double-clicking on the Window List Button for a Minimized or Unmaximized   window will Maximize the window.  These features are very helpful if you wish to turn off titlebars for maximized windows and have a flipped menu bar. I use this with a modified theme which removes the titlebars for maximized windows.

Name: Zeripaths Window list: applet is broken
Comment_Body: Hmm... interesting. It appears to be working fine for me (I'm currently on version 3.4.1 but I guess I've been through 3.2.7 at some point and I've not had to change the code in 3 years!)  OK let's try to work out what's going on.   * What is the result of: `(dconf read /org/cinnamon/enabled-applets | grep zeripath > /dev/null) && echo "enabled" || echo "disabled"` (This will let me make sure that it's actually enabled - if it's not then have you run the `install.sh` script and have the `dconf` program from the `dconf-tools` package?) * Do you have any logs that I can look at to see where the problem is? Take a look at `~/.cinnamon/glass.log`  Is there anything helpful in there to explain what's going on? Or could you give me a copy of it?  If it is *enabled* and there is nothing in the logs to explain why it's not working then we should take a look at the geometry of your panels.   * Could you show me the results of:  `dconf read /org/cinnamon/enabled-applets` * Does running the `uninstall.sh` script restore a working original window-list applet? If not there is definitely something screwy going on with your panels. (The `install.sh` can be run to replace/reinstall my applet to the correct place as necessary.)  HTH

Name: Zeripaths Window list: applet is broken
Comment_Body: Happens for me too. After a cinnamon restart, all windows are there, so it seems it doesn't correctly load existing windows, when it's added to the panel

Name: Zeripaths Window list: applet is broken
Comment_Body: Ah! That's to be expected. As per the Readme file:  > 1. Install dconf-tools: `sudo apt-get install dconf-tools` > 2. Extract the zip into a temporary directory > 3. `cd` into that directory > 4. `chmod +x install.sh` > 5. `./install.sh` > 6. Press `ALT-F2`, type `r`, and press `ENTER` to restart cinnamon. > > The install script will replace the default cinnamon window-list with my version of the applet.  The `ALT-F2 r` is needed to ensure that the list-applet gets told about the running programs by cinnamon. When I wrote the applet there was no way of querying cinnamon to get this list on applet addition and cinnamon wasn't properly resizing panels to fit the applet - so it seemed like the correct thing to do was to require an restart through `ALT-F2 r`.   I can take a look at seeing if there is a way to avoid having to restart with `ALT-F2 r`.

Name: [some applets] show a warning message in system setting
Comment_Body: It means these applets use API calls that can change files on your system and do I/O. They're not *dangerous* as long as the author of the applet is careful, and applets are now reviewed for security and quality before being published. The dangerous flag is set on a number of applets, and the Cinnamon repo would be a better place to discuss whether or not these applets are being flagged appropriately.

Name: [some applets] show a warning message in system setting
Comment_Body: >applets use API calls that can change files on your system and do I/O I'm not sure that your comment is correct because the message pop-up does not say anything in that direction. I think this message it is misleading (and probably useless). And why do you think that this is an discussion for the Cinnamon repro? Does Cinnamon has a "list" of "flags" of all applets and controls this flag central?

Name: [some applets] show a warning message in system setting
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @kmkom: A more correct description of what that message informs about is "*API calls that made synchronous operations, regardless if they do I/O operations or not*".  What that flag really informs about is the existence of the `spawn_sync`, `spawn_command_line_sync`, `GTop` and `get_file_contents_utf8_sync` strings in the xlets code. It doesn't matter if those strings are actual function calls or if they are inside a comment. The xlets will be flagged regardless.  The use of the previously mentioned function calls can cause slow downs and freezes due to their synchronous nature. The message that you see informs exactly about that, so is not misleading nor useless at all.

Comment_Body: Plesse remove the "dangerous: true" line in the metadata.json file.  I assume this PR fixes #930?  If you add the line  Fixes #930 in the pull request message then the issue will be closed, when the PR is merged.

Name: sysmonitor@orcus: Using Cinnamon settings API now and fixed a few bugs.
Comment_Body: Since I use Fedora, I wasn't sure that my fix was Fedora specific or not. I just tried Mint in VM and my fix works, so I'll assume it works everywhere.  I also noticed that there was missing Array.prototype.fill() in Mint, so I replaced it with normal loop. It should work well now. And "dangerous:true" is removed now.

Name: stevedore@centurix: Add a Docker applet to the Cinnamon Applet Spices repository
Comment_Body: Structure seems OK to me. You can create a symbolic link `stevedore@centurix/README.md`, which has the target `stevedore@centurix/files/stevedore@centurix/README.md`.  This way you don't have to always copy the README.md file, if you change it.

Name: stevedore@centurix: Add a Docker applet to the Cinnamon Applet Spices repository
Comment_Body: Cool. I think this issue has to do with Cinnamon 3.4 using a newer JS interpreter. I am seeing strict mode warnings in .xsession-errors.  It looks like in [newContainer](https://github.com/Centurix/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/d6afc1f4650db5ee704131c106a7db250da5b250/stevedore%40centurix/files/stevedore%40centurix/docker.js#L114) you are using arguments as a string, but arguments is a [reserved keyword](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Functions/arguments) holding an array of the function's arguments. It doesn't look like you're trying to alter the function's arguments, so I would define a variable for that string.

Name: stevedore@centurix: Add a Docker applet to the Cinnamon Applet Spices repository
Comment_Body: Ah, OK, I'm not currently on Cinnamon 3.4, but I've added the correct scoping for newer Javascript, removed keyword re-use and a minimum Docker version check. I'll probably setup a 3.4 install and give it a test, but this commit should get it there. Thanks for the feedback @jaszhix  @brownsr @NikoKrause
