Name: stevedore@centurix: Add a Docker applet to the Cinnamon Applet Spices repository
Comment_Body: Well as far as I can tell knowing nothing about docker it appears to be generally working now.   I did trigger some log errors, I think the snippet below was when I deleted an image ```shell (cinnamon:2580): Cjs-WARNING **: JS ERROR: Exception in callback for signal: activate: TypeError: GLib.spawn_command_line_async(...)[Symbol.iterator] is not a function Docker.prototype.removeImage@/home/simon/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/stevedore@centurix/docker.js:86:40 Stevedore.prototype.removeImage@/home/simon/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/stevedore@centurix/applet.js:672:9 _emit@resource:///org/cinnamon/cjs/modules/signals.js:142:27 PopupBaseMenuItem.prototype.activate@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/popupMenu.js:177:9 PopupBaseMenuItem.prototype._onButtonReleaseEvent@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/popupMenu.js:150:9 ```  I would suggest sorting out those stevedor/stevedore inconsistencies if possible.  I'm tempted to merge it now, but it's the sort of applet that a lot of people will want to try out I suspect, so best make it bulletproof first to avoid generating a number of minor issue reports.  @jaszhix As you know docker well, perhaps you could see that all looks fine to you ?

Name: stevedore@centurix: Add a Docker applet to the Cinnamon Applet Spices repository
Comment_Body: It loads for me now as well, and lists all of the images and containers in use on my system. When expanding items under the containers section, there doesn't seem to be any sub-menu items, the arrows just point down. I saw this stack trace repeat several time before the applet did launch, I'm guessing it still worked because it was caught in a try-catch block.  glass.log:  ```sh trace t=2017-06-23T19:53:53.782Z  <---------------- Docker.prototype.IPAddress@/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/stevedore@centurix/docker.js:195:13 Stevedore.prototype.refreshMenu@/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/stevedore@centurix/applet.js:577:1 Stevedore.prototype._init@/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/stevedore@centurix/applet.js:476:9 Stevedore@/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/stevedore@centurix/applet.js:433:5 main@/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/stevedore@centurix/applet.js:803:12 createApplet@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/appletManager.js:409:18 addAppletToPanels@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/appletManager.js:298:22 finishExtensionLoad@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/appletManager.js:60:18 loadExtension@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/extension.js:451:17 onEnabledAppletsChanged@/usr/share/ ``` .xsession-errors:  ```sh Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [resource:///org/cinnamon/cjs/modules/tweener/tweener.js 547]: reference to undefined property properties[istr].isSpecialProperty Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/stevedore@centurix/docker.js 195]: reference to undefined property container.NetworkSettings.Networks.bridge Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/popupMenu.js 2025]: reference to undefined property actor._delegate Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/stevedore@centurix/docker.js 195]: reference to undefined property container.NetworkSettings.Networks.bridge  ```  I could see this being really useful. Are the menu items supposed display some of the data you would see in ```docker ps```? I would remove all the try-catch blocks and see if you can get it working without them. Good job so far, I like where its going. :)  Edit:  It loads the menu items now after restarting Cinnamon. I still get notified that a startup issue occured, even though the applet loaded.  ![screenshot from 2017-06-23 15-01-54](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/6859057/27498539-25086cfa-5825-11e7-8782-f81013a6cdbc.png)

Name: stevedore@centurix: Add a Docker applet to the Cinnamon Applet Spices repository
Comment_Body: @centurix What would you prefer ?  We can iterate this a little more before merging, or we can merge and let the minor issues get sorted afterwards.  As I suspect quite a few people will want to try this, then the cleaner you get it up front the fewer issues are likely to get raised.  But merging it also makes it possible for others to put their own PRs in to fix bugs, which you may think is useful to you.  So any preference ? From my perspective we've checked it over for malicious or destructive code, it fits the naming and file structure, and it appears to function and doesn't break Cinnamon, so it can be merged.

Comment_Body: The author is @OrcusCZ, he responded in the #668.

Name: sysmonitor@orcus: libgtop-2.0.so.10: undefined symbol: glibtop_init_s trace
Comment_Body: I'm the author. Honestly, I've no idea why it happens. It happens only after Cinnamon init if I use network related functions from glibtop. Removing/adding the applet once the Cinnamon is running throws no error. If I call those functions from glibtop, that error is thrown in some part of Cinnamon initialization, but if I call string match() function right after glibtop init, the error is thrown by match() (which can be caught with try-catch) and then everything works fine. It makes no sense to me, but for some reason this workaround works, at least in Fedora 25. I am working on a patch fixing this and also using Cinnamon xlet settings api instead of gjs/cjs program as now. It should be updated soon.

Name: sysmonitor@orcus: libgtop-2.0.so.10: undefined symbol: glibtop_init_s trace

Name: [hideable-applets@cardsurf] Add a new applet
Comment_Body: @cardsurf This sounds like a cool applet. Though I must say, I thought it was more like the [Windows 7 like arrow](https://www.sevenforums.com/attachments/tutorials/328687d1407639595-notification-area-icons-hide-show-system-icons-notifications-notfication_area_icons.png). But it isn't. After trying it, I must say, I would wish it would be more like the Windows 7 arrow. I.e. concrete things that I'd like to see improved (in my opinion): 1. When I press the applet, a popup menu appears, with all applets listed in it. If I press those icons in the popup menu, I expect, it opens the applet, but all it does is toggling visibility of those applets. (But I thinks that's not the intention and would be hard to implement.) Just irritated for the first few minutes, because I expected something else. So forget about this point ^^ 2. If I hide applets and restart Cinnamon, the hidden applets are no more hidden. I.e. your applet doesn't remember, which applets are hidden. 3. It's not visible in the popupmenu, which applets are hidden and which ones are not. That's an issue imo. You should highlight, if an applet is hidden and unhighlight, if it's visible. (Maybe using pseudo style class "hover" or "focus" or something like that) 4. You use other/bigger icons in the popup, than those on the panel.  Some applets have the same icon or just a "? question mark" as icon. Therefore it's irritating at first to see, which icons belongs to which applet. It would be better, if you would use the same (symbolic) icons as in the panel. (I think it's hard to get them?). I would at least change the following: * Use smaller icon size by default (size 22 or what is the default? Since it's possible in the panel settings to "allow cinnamon to change the icon size depending on the panel size", maybe it's also possible to get the icon size of the icons in the panel. Then I would add an option, "Use same size for icons as the panel does" by default and add an option to set custom icon size.) * The systray@cinnamon.org uses a question-mark as icon. But it definitely has a icon. 5. The icon of your applet is white. It should use the same color as the other symbolic icons in the panel.

Name: [hideable-applets@cardsurf] Add a new applet
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause  Thanks for the feedback and ideas. Regarding the mentioned remarks: 1. The applet toggles visitbilities of applets in the popup instead of opening them or simulating a left click. 2. The applet saves information about last used values to the CSV file located in: `~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/hideable-applets@cardsurf/values/last_values.csv`. If a user hide/unhide an applet and immediately restart Cinnamon the changes will not be retained. A saving interval can be configured in the settings under the `Save every` option. Is there a better way to save many values using Cinnamon built-in settings without high CPU usage ?  3. Sounds like a nice improvement. 4. A default icon size is 40 pixels. This can be customized under the `Icon size` option in the configuration.     There could also be a button that sets the icon size to match a panel size.    Right now the applet looks for applet icons in the: `/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/` directory or in an applet metadata. If an icon is not found it displays the question mark icon. The applet could also check if an `icon.png` file exists in: `/usr/share/cinnamon/applets` to show more applet icons. 5. Is there any good small arrow up symbolic icon that could be used ?

Name: [hideable-applets@cardsurf] Add a new applet
Comment_Body: 2. Not sure. I think you better ask Cobinja or Odyseus for that. 4. You find icons of (official) spices in `~/.cinnamon/spices.cache/applet`. Then you can check `~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/` for applets, which are not in spices, and `/usr/share/cinnamon/applets` for applets, which are preinstalled with Cinnamon. 5. You can copy `/usr/share/icons/Adwaita/scalable/actions/pan-up-symbolic.svg`

Name: [hideable-applets@cardsurf] Add a new applet
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @cardsurf  > Is there a better way to save many values using Cinnamon built-in settings without high CPU usage?  You could simply use a **generic** type of setting ([See the settings reference](http://developer.linuxmint.com/reference/git/cinnamon-tutorials/xlet-settings-ref.html) and search for "generic"). You can save any type of data in those. By doing so, you can get rid of all the code in your applet that handles the **last_values.csv** file. Also, by doing so, your applet will remember those values every time it is updated by the user.  **About the applet icon:** I think that you can safely use the **pan-up** icon as suggested by @NikoKrause without actually copy it into your applet. This icon (along with the **pan-down**, **pan-end** and **pan-start**) *seems* to exists only on the **Adwaita** and **Hicolor** icon themes and these two icon themes *seems* to exists in all distributions (not the emphasis on **seems**, I cannot be entirely sure).  **About the icon for applets inside the menu:** You could also look for an applet icon on the applet's metadata. You could just check if the **icon** key exists and also you could check if that icon exists in the current icon theme.

Name: [website-notifier@cardsurf] Add a new applet
Comment_Body: I agree with MrElectroNick, it seems like a cool applet. I didn't notice any problems with CPU or memory usage. I did see a few warnings, but nothing really stopping the functionality.  ``` Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/website-notifier@cardsurf/appletGui.js 136]: assignment to undeclared variable last_char Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/website-notifier@cardsurf/appletGui.js 137]: assignment to undeclared variable semicolon Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/website-notifier@cardsurf/shellUtils.js 170]: Too many arguments to function GLib.spawn_async_with_pipes: expected 5, got 6 Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/website-notifier@cardsurf/shellUtils.js 203]: Too many arguments to function GLib.child_watch_add: expected 3, got 5 ``` The ```ShellOutputProcess``` class is probably not needed, and could be replaced with Cinnamon's utilities for launching processes in ```imports.misc.util```.  I'm not sure if its intended, but I have to click the applet to get a notification. Its not automatic.  Its also not clear to me what the separator option is for under Scripts. Anyway, nice work, it looks handy. :+1:

Name: [website-notifier@cardsurf] Add a new applet
Comment_Body: @MrElectroNick Thanks.  @jaszhix * The `ShellOutputProcess` class is used to get a standard error. If a script file does not exist and a user clicks on the applet there will be a message in a Cinnamon log. I have not found a function that returns a standard error in the `util.js`. * Left click refreshes a website on demand. By default the applet checks a website for updates every 60 minutes. This can be configured in the settings. * A script returns a couple of values as a string. A separator is customizable in case one of the values contained the separator. If a website title was `:::::Cinnamon Applets:::::` then the separator could be set to `|`.

Name: weather@mockturtl: Added option to show high temperature first in forecast

Name: weather@mockturtl: Added option to show high temperature first in forecast

This should improve experience for many users.  :+1: Looks good, thanks!  > Note, this is my first public contribution and I'm not quite sure how the versioning works. I read the semantic versioning document, but I'm not sure if this counts as a minor or patch update.  I'd call it a feature, and bump the minor version as you've done.

Name: Argos for Cinnamon (0dyseus@ArgosForCinnamon) update
Comment_Body: Interesting. I didn't know, that animated PNG are possible. The screenshot won't change, till the @clefebvre cleans the cache manually. So you'll need to be patient. You can see that it has changed, if you add `?bliblablub` at the end of the screenshot page, e.g. https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/git/applets/0dyseus@ArgosForCinnamon/screenshot.png?afa

Name: Argos for Cinnamon (0dyseus@ArgosForCinnamon) update
Comment_Body: Hello, @NikoKrause.  > Interesting. I didn't know, that animated PNG are possible.  Yes, I found out about animated PNGs (APNG) very recently. This is the first time that I created one. I created it with [this site](https://animatedpngs.com/). And here are the [basic differences](https://animatedpngs.com/#vs_Animated_GIFs) between APNGs and GIFs. I forgot to optimize the individual PNG files, otherwise, the size of the image would have been even smaller. I had to choose an animated PNG because of the *hard coded* name of that image (screenshot.png). It worked pretty well.  > The screenshot won't change, till the @clefebvre cleans the cache manually.  I already can see it live on the Spices website. I just had to reload the page bypassing the cache (press the reload button while holding the <kbd>Shift</kbd> key on Firefox).

Name: network@brownsr : Add Scrollbar in each section if list exceeds screen height
Comment_Body: @deepsidhu1313 I'd be grateful if you could give a screenshot of the problem.  This is an incredibly simple applet, which is designed to give the same result as the network desktop icon, so that desktop icons can be turned off and this applet used instead - for those that like an empty desktop.  As such it triggers - or should trigger - the standard display you will see when clicking on the desktop network icon, or if in nemo selecting  Go Network   or else typing network:/// into the bar.  So unless something very weird is happening, any issue will lie somewhere other than in this applet.  A screenshot of the problem you see will help to get to the bottom of this. And it will also help me clarify that you are really talking about this applet, and not the standard 'Network Manager' applet. Right clicking on either applet will bring up its name, if in doubt.    Regards  Simon

Name: network@brownsr : Add Scrollbar in each section if list exceeds screen height

Name: bumbleebee@pdcurtis Update to Version 3.2.0
Comment_Body: @pdcurtis I know you have the README.md file in UUID/files/UUID for offline reasons.  So you have the README.md file twice. It's double the work to have those both changed. I suggest, that you create a symbolic link called README.md, which has the README.md in UUID/files/UUID as target. Open terminal and `cd` to the UUID and then `ln -s files/UUID/README.md` should create the symbolic link. In theory this should work.  With the new changes of the spices website, there is a new feature. The website now shows CHANGELOG.md files as well like the README.md files. See https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/applets/view/282  I suggest to rename changelog.txt to CHANGELOG.md and add a symbolic link as well like with the README.md file.  After this has been merged, the plan was to remove the (abandoned) Bumblebee applet, right? If yes could you create a PR, which deletes it?

Name: bumbleebee@pdcurtis Update to Version 3.2.0
Comment_Body: I have just removed a horrible mistake where several metadata.json files had been uploaded with dangerous flags added. This resulted from already having symbolic links on my local machine for testing which, of course, work both ways and my final commit picked several up without my noticing. i have forced up a correction.  @NikoKrause I wondered about using symbolic links for README.md  but I was not sure how they would work on Github and I note you only say "in theory this should work". I think an experiment on something unimportant might be sensible before I change them all. It only takes a few seconds to do an extra save after the changes have been made.  I will now start to change my changelog.txt files to CHANGELOG.md and copy so they are visible on web site. They may need to be simplified on the view on the website as they go back a long way and may not be consistent with the way others display them. Is the example above with last changes at top the format to follow?  I will leave the [WIP] while I have a look at what to do.  > After this has been merged, the plan was to remove the (abandoned) Bumblebee applet, right?  I was giving time for @marmistrz to respond but I believe that is now the right thing to do.

Name: bumbleebee@pdcurtis Update to Version 3.2.0
Comment_Body: I'm not totally sure, if the symbolic link would work right. If you want to take the risk and it doesn't work, I would fix it for you.  There is no standard for changelog. And as far as I know, there won't be any. You can write Ingo your changelog what you want to. You can even drop it if you want to. Just wanted to let you know about it, since I saw you use changelogs.

Name: bumbleebee@pdcurtis Update to Version 3.2.0
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause I have added a CHANGELOG.md as you suggested as 3.2.0.1 and the symbolic link as 3.2.0.2 so they can easily be reverted if required.  It looks as if Git handles the symbolic links as a test of switching branches and returning left it in place but it looks odd if you do a diff eg `git diff HEAD~1` shows the folder address with no indication it is a link.  If you are prepared to try this out and see if the web site picks up the link correctly please take off the [WIP] and merge this PR. If it does not work the main part should still be OK and you should not even need to revert the extra two commits.  I have limited Internet at present so I will not be able to respond quickly to messages in the next couple of days.

Name: bumbleebee@pdcurtis Update to Version 3.2.0
Comment_Body: @pdcurtis  Merged! It works. The changelog is shown on your spices website correctly.

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23: Net panel with docker unscrollable
Comment_Body: My 2¢ on how it could be solved:  Have a list of regular expressions (plus implicit `.*` last), put every NIC into the first group it matches. Then basically work with those groups instead of separate NICs.  I think it's the easiest, yet sufficient, solution for autogenerated NICs and NIC grouping in general. I would be happy with having regex list as a single plain text input field, but it could be fancier if someone had time to implement a reorderable list with editable name, regex and 2 colors for each row.  Need to scroll NIC list should never arise with such implementation, since it's inconceivable that one could want a few dozen unmarked overlayed graphs in their tray: too hard to distinguish that many colors and remember which is which.  And while we are at it, that implementation could be copy-pasted for disk IO too when it's done.

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: Not sure if you've had the chance to test it on Cinnamon 3.4, but the applet loads, but doesn't collapse the tray. It also is using the vertical arrow icon on a horizontal panel.  May be related to these warnings:  ``` Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu/applet.js 171]: reference to undefined property this.verticalCollapseIconName ``` ``` Cjs-Message: JS WARNING: [/home/jason/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu/applet.js 168]: reference to undefined property this._direction ```

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: Cinnamon 3.4 hasn't been pushed to the Manjaro repos yet, unfortunately. But I'd be surprised if that was the reason for the warnings. Do these problems persist if you use the applet release from my repo? https://github.com/Feuerfuchs/Collapsible-Systray-Cinnamon-Applet/releases/tag/v1.7

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: Is that version any different? I am testing the version in this PR. Alternatively you can add ```"cinnamon-version": ["3.2"]``` to your metadata.json, along with any other versions the applet supports since its probably not likely you can fix it without running 3.4.

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: No, it should be identical. I'm just trying to understand the problem and want to be sure this isn't caused by some GitHub/git wonkiness. It's baffling because the warnings you posted here point to a basic logical mistake in my applet, i.e. that this._orientation and this.verticalCollapseIconName aren't set. But, I set those right during the initialization. That means, if this fails for you due to compatibility issues, there should be tons of other variables that shouldn't be known as well and the whole applet wouldn't work in the slightest. So what this looks like to me is that some of my changes weren't applied, especially the ones in the applet's initialization stage.

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: Cinnamon 3.4 has a newer JS engine based on mozjs38, so I'm thinking its a 3.4 issue. We have been patching applets so they run again in 3.4.  As for the warnings, maybe there's no access to ```this``` from those getters' scope?

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: Ah, I was just about to amend my comment. ^^ I took a closer look at the whole initialization phase and I think I know what the problem is: The collapse button fetches the icon during its initialization, i.e. it calls the getter function "collapseIcon" in applet.js. At this point, the settings and several variables haven't been initialized yet. The old engine wasn't bothered by that, but it looks like the new one is. :)  So I'll change that behavior and if I still can't get it working for you, I'll just update the metadata as you said earlier.

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: Cool. I also had Cinnamon crash when removing the default system tray applet after loading yours. Log is [here](https://pastebin.com/ktCu7NeE). You may want to add that to the install notes that they should unload the default applet before adding yours to the panel. Also, if you copy/move the readme file from ```/collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu/files/collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu/``` to ```/collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu/```, it will display on the Spices website.

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: I updated the readme, thanks for the heads-up!

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels

Comment_Body: So the update to Cinnamon 3.4 was published for my distro and I installed it. No issues whatsoever with my applet so I'm not sure what to do now. Are you absolutely positive you tested it with 3cf5fe8 included?

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: This is going to be confusing for some, but Cinnamon uses CJS 1.48. When Michael rebased GJS, he made it so it can depend on both mozjs24 *and* mozjs38. Right now most users on 3.4 are using the mozjs24 JS engine, but when Mint 18.2 rolls around (and presumably users on Ubuntu 17.04+), they will be on 38, which does change how the applets are run because it uses a newer version of EcmaScript that handles a lot of syntax errors differently. This is something you can more reliably test by compiling Cinnamon from source for now, but the change will happen for a lot more users later.

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: When you open terminal type `cjs` and then `typeof Symbol` and it says `undefined` you are on mozjs24. I learned that from jaszhix. ```bash user@mint ~ $ cjs cjs> typeof Symbol "undefined" ```

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels

Name: collapsible-systray@feuerfuchs.eu: Add support for vertical panels
Comment_Body: Okay. I never could get the tray to collapse and saw warnings. You can open another PR and I can test again if you want.

Name: Custom settings applets should move its settings to ~/.cinnamon/configs: MyLauncher@markbokil.com
Comment_Body: Your configs are located in ```~/.cinnamon/configs```. If there are multiple JSON files per applet, and only one panel, you can lose track of your settings. You can try deleting which ever one is newest and restart Cinnamon (ALT+F2 -> r) - assuming you don't have multiple instances of the applets.

Name: Custom settings applets should move its settings to ~/.cinnamon/configs: MyLauncher@markbokil.com
Comment_Body: Thanks for the quick reply. Some are located in ~/local/share/cinnamon/applets/ (maybe those that don't follow the new guidelines?) And well, of course I can save the JSON and restore them after an update with a good check to see if nothing changed in the structure, but I wouldn't exactly call that user friendly.

Name: Custom settings applets should move its settings to ~/.cinnamon/configs: MyLauncher@markbokil.com
Comment_Body: Multi-Core System Monitor is the only one I consistently lose settings on, which is annoying because it works so well otherwise!  I just wish my colors would remain when it updates. :(

Name: Custom settings applets should move its settings to ~/.cinnamon/configs: MyLauncher@markbokil.com
Comment_Body: For most applets I'm using the default config so I cannot say if there is a problem, but at least there is also MyLauncher@markbokil.com and timer-notifications@markbokil.com, so maybe these are individual bugs? This is what I was wondering.

Name: Custom settings applets should move its settings to ~/.cinnamon/configs: MyLauncher@markbokil.com
Comment_Body: The problem is this applet uses its own settings app, and it works independent of Cinnamon's handling of xlet settings. I was going to keep it how it was, but now I think maybe we should switch it over to Xlet settings like every other applet.

Name: Custom settings applets should move its settings to ~/.cinnamon/configs: MyLauncher@markbokil.com
Comment_Body: It's funny - if you didn't keep it up to date so often (which is commendable), then it wouldn't be a problem, since it wouldn't revert your settings so frequently. :)

Name: Check Authors of Spices (Applets, Desklets, Extensions)
Comment_Body: Since the spices have been ported to GitHub, it it still unclear for a lot of spices who the author is. So I go ahead and notify every single author here. This way we'll see, which GitHub user names don't exist, which ones are active, and which ones are abandoned. A lot of active authors have been already spotted here. But some haven't responded at all.  * If you are an author of an applet/desklet/extension for Cinnamon and still active, please answer to this issue with a +1 or something similar. * If you are an author but are no longer active, let us know, if you want your applet to be removed or if you want to donate your applet, i.e. setting the author to none and your name as original_author. * If you are an author, but your (GitHub) name is not listed here or it's wrong, let us know.  The authors, which responded, will see that the check box besides their name will have a check mark (asap). For spices, which authors can not be detected, the author will be set to none or the spice will be deleted.

Name: Check Authors of Spices (Applets, Desklets, Extensions)
Comment_Body: @appdevsw  If your applet won't be deleted, the `author` would be set to `none` and the `original_author` would be set to your name in the [info.json](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/CommandRunner%40appdevsw/info.json) file (<- in this file the original_author won't be deleted for sure, since this file is updated very rarely. Only when author/maintainer changes.) ([Example](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/672/files)) The UUID of the applet won't be changed (because users won't get any updates, if we would change that), so your name stays there as well.  But I can't promise, that your name in the code (applet.js etc.) will stay, if someone decides to take over the code. You can create a PR to change `author` to `original_author` in your code. This way it has at least more chance to stay there.  @SavageTiger @gnemonix  You set +0.5. It means you are no longer actively supporting your applet (new features, etc.)? Shall we leave your name as author? It means you will be notified, when somebody creates a PR, since your name is still there as author. If we set the author name to `none`, you probably won't be notified and maybe some other developer comes along and says he wants to maintain it.

Name: Check Authors of Spices (Applets, Desklets, Extensions)
Comment_Body: This thread is almost a year old now, and we've mostly garnered the information we needed from it. I'm sure many of the people tagged in this post are getting pretty sick of all the emails and notifications in this post, so I'm going to go ahead and lock this.  If you stumble on this post for the first time and you have an applet, desklet, or extension that was migrated from the old spices site, and haven't commented yet, here's what you need to do: * if you no longer wish to maintain your applet, desklet, or extension, at this point we've probably already assumed that your spice was abandoned anyway. In this case no action is required on your part. * If you do wish to maintain your spice first check the 'author' field in the file ```info.json``` located in the root folder of your spice. If it is set to none, this means that we have assumed that it was abandoned. In this case, simply submit a pull request changing the author field to your Github name and in the comments explain that you are the original author and wish to continue maintaining the spice. * If you wish for your code to be removed from the spices website, submit a pull request which removes the root folder of your spice from the repository. Please also explain in the comments that you are the original author and that you wish to remove the spice from the website and the repository.

Name: ScreenShot+RecordDesktop@tech71 don't work
Comment_Body: Can you try localizing "Pictures" and "Videos" in applet.js? I.e. `"xdg-open " + _("Videos")` and `"xdg-open " + _("Pictures")`

Name: ScreenShot+RecordDesktop@tech71 don't work
Comment_Body: or maybe using `"xdg-open “ + GLib.UserDirectory.DIRECTORY_PICTURES`  Need to test. Not sure if it will work.

Name: ScreenShot+RecordDesktop@tech71 don't work
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  If you want to *kill three birds with one shot* (LOL), just use the following.  ```javascript // For the Pictures user folder Main.Util.spawn_async(["xdg-open", GLib.get_user_special_dir(GLib.UserDirectory.DIRECTORY_PICTURES)], null); // For the Videos user folder Main.Util.spawn_async(["xdg-open", GLib.get_user_special_dir(GLib.UserDirectory.DIRECTORY_VIDEOS)], null); ```  1. Use of an asynchronous function. 2. No need to localize anything. 3. No need to insert spaces anywhere.  BTW, the **_()** declared in this applet only return strings from the applet's domain. And neither "Videos" nor "Pictures" are localized.

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23: Convert to multi-version applet
Comment_Body: @jaszhix with multi-version you don't need a folder for every version. It will pick the folder with the latest version <= the actual Cinnamon version. For example, if you have folders for 2.8 and 3.2, Cinnamon 2.8 and 3.0 will use the 2.8 folder while Cinnamon 3.2 and higher will use the 3.2 folder. In addition, any version before 2.8 will use the main folder if possible, so if you only need 2 versions of everything, you really only need a subfolder for 3.4 and later, you can place the old version in the applet directory, and just create a 3.4 subfolder.

Name: multicore-sys-monitor@ccadeptic23: Convert to multi-version applet

Name: weather@mockturtl: small fixes to ru.po
Comment_Body: I'm not sure. Длина is length and Горизонт is the horizon. And the string says, how many days should be shown. I'm not sure what this has to do with the horizon? ``` -msgstr "Длина прогноза" +msgstr "Горизонт прогноза" ``` I'm no native speaker though. @andreevlex What do you mean?

Name: weather@mockturtl: small fixes to ru.po
Comment_Body: Well, it is more specific term in Russian about weather forecast.  http://translate.academic.ru/%D0%93%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B8%D0%B7%D0%BE%D0%BD%D1%82%20%D0%9F%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%BD%D0%BE%D0%B7%D0%B8%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B2%D0%B0%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%8F/ru/  горизонт прогнозирования = forecasting time-frame  In Russian we also use literally: “forecast depth” or “forecast longitude”, not “forecast length”, because length is not property of Time.  But Horizon, instead, used for Time, such as “event horizon”  I'm sure, that “Горизонт прогноза” much better and well known for Russian speaking ppl, but “Длина прогноза” is not appropriate.

Name: weather@mockturtl: small fixes to ru.po
Comment_Body: Ah. Learned something New :)

Name: [brightness-and-gamma-applet@cardsurf] Add a new applet
Comment_Body: @cardsurf  There is a bug which you will want to address:  error t=2017-04-30T18:04:49.795Z redeclaration of let screen_name trace t=2017-04-30T18:04:49.795Z  <---------------- Extension.prototype._init@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/extension.js:155:13 Extension@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/extension.js:116:5 loadExtension@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/extension.js:449:25 onEnabledAppletsChanged@/usr/share/cinnamon/js/ui/appletManager.js:236:13 ----------------> error t=2017-04-30T18:04:49.795Z [Applet "brightness-and-gamma-applet@cardsurf"]: Error importing applet.js from brightness-and-gamma-applet@cardsurf error t=2017-04-30T18:04:49.795Z Could not load applet brightness-and-gamma-applet@cardsurf  I suspect this is coming from here in applet.js, though I have not checked to see if the same type of thing is found elsewhere. You can see that screen_name is declared (with let) two times with another line between.     _parse_screen_name: function (line) {         let matches = line.match(this.screen_regex);         let screen_name = matches[0];         let last_character_index = screen_name.length - 1;         let screen_name = screen_name.substring(0, last_character_index);         return screen_name;     },  We are just about to move over to a new javascript engine.  The current one will probably let this applet load with the redeclaration, the new one will not.  That error can be found in ~/.cinnamon/glass.log  Thanks for the new applet :)

Name: weather@mockturtl: Apply 3.4 fixes
Comment_Body: Cool!  I didn't know 3.4 was available.  Do I understand correctly that something will change in the parser, such that `weather` might exist, but `weather.item` not?

Name: weather@mockturtl: Apply 3.4 fixes
Comment_Body: Ah, no I'm running a nightly build with CJS running on mozjs38, so it has broken a lot of things. I'm not sure I understand what you mean by consume a boolean. The problem is the weather ajax data is not always valid because its being polled and the weather API likely has a throttling limit. So this returns when there is no weather data, after the polling is triggered again.  To be clear, it probably always worked out this way since we are getting an AJAX response every time, but the old interpreter (mozjs24) ignored these undefined TypeErrors.

Name: weather@mockturtl: Apply 3.4 fixes
Comment_Body: > I'm not sure I understand what you mean by consume a boolean  You `return false`, but none of the callers use the value.

Name: weather@mockturtl: Apply 3.4 fixes
Comment_Body: > the weather API likely has a throttling limit... the old interpreter (mozjs24) ignored these undefined TypeErrors  Ah!  I see now.  Thanks!

Name: weather@mockturtl: Apply 3.4 fixes
Comment_Body: > You return false, but none of the callers use the value.  Ahh, its just a CJS-specific thing where it will log a warning about functions returning undefined, so I do it in all applet code. In other JS projects I will just use ```return``` to end the function.

Name: weather@mockturtl: Apply 3.4 fixes
Comment_Body: @mockturtl is this ok to merge now?

Name: weather@mockturtl: Apply 3.4 fixes
Comment_Body: @jaszhix  >  it will log a warning about functions returning undefined   (╯°□°）╯︵ ┻━┻   @collinss   > is this ok to merge now?  Yes, thanks!

Comment_Body: Is this ready to merge?  Suggestions: 1.  `_("Sorry, the record can't start,") + "\n" + _("because you have incorrect crop settings!")` This is one sentence. I wouldn't split it into two translatable Strings. `_("Sorry, the record can't start,\n because you have incorrect crop settings!")` 2. If you want to create a template for translations, then you need a folder called `po`, where the metadata.json file is stored. Then open a terminal. Direct to the place oft you applet, where the metadata is störend: `cd ~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/YOURAPPLETUUID/` Then the command to create the template. It's also used to update the template: `cinnamon-json-makepot --js po/YOURAPPLERUUID.pot`

I realise that the information is redundant in the long term, it was just so you could evaluate quickly and without extra work. You had a diagnostic call to global.logError(e) in the previously version, I will comment it out unless you suggest otherwise.

Name: vnstat@linuxmint.com Patch 1
Comment_Body: @clefebvre Changes requested have been made, pushed and ready for approval.

Name: vnstat@linuxmint.com Patch 1
Comment_Body: @clefebvre Changes requested have been made, pushed and ready for approval.

Name: vnstat@linuxmint.com Patch 1
Comment_Body: Please hold this. There is still a possible issue with computers with several wifi adapters including a USB one I would like to check.  Edit: The problem is to do with vnstat which needs to have any interfaces not present when it was installed manually added. This is not an applet problem directly but might be worthy of note in a README.md when I have experimented further. I need to do the same for NUMA so it is not much additional work.

Name: vnstat@linuxmint.com Patch 1
Comment_Body: * This now fixes #152.  * I have improved the handling of various conditions such as no active device where the previous output is displayed. At no time should there be an empty display, there is always an error message, comment or image.  * Image storage location moved to $HOME instead of /tmp to give continuity through a restart.  * I have added an extra note in README.md about the need for extra devices such as Mobile Internet USB sticks to be added to the vnstat database configuration but not given details as it is difficult (issues with permissions).  * Removed change to async call as it gave occasional problems in timing @clefebvre Ready for your approval

Name: vnstat@linuxmint.com Patch 1
Comment_Body: @clefebvre  It's your applet

It can easily be undone if the author returns. Is there (or should there be) a mechanism to assign a new person(s) to be responsible and review any PRs short of actually making them the author? At a minimum they should be a willing continuous user capable of understanding the code.

Name: vboxlauncher - show machine status [feature]
Comment_Body: Notifying author @mockturtl

Name: vboxlauncher - show machine status [feature]
Comment_Body: I like the idea of the feature, but the applet essentially just [runs a shell command](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/vboxlauncher%40mockturtl/files/vboxlauncher%40mockturtl/applet.js#L213).  - Do you have design and/or implementation ideas? - Can you give a more specific description of your use case, or the problem it solves? (Personally, I rarely use  a VM -- I would never forget one is running)

Name: vboxlauncher - show machine status [feature]
Comment_Body: Hi, My use case is this: I use Vagrant with VirtualBox for developing web-projects. I configured the virtual machines with the same IP-Adress for automation-reasons. I often have to switch between Projects, so I have to stop the running machine and start another one (because running two machines with the same IP results in conflicts and unexpected behaviour). I mean I have to start/stop the machines with the vagrant-commands anyway but it would help a lot if I had an indicator what machine is running. I have now the VirtualBox Manager open all the time.  Maybe my use case is too special, but I think having little indicators for each machine and maybe also the possibility to start, stop, suspend, resume the machines directly from the tray would be very nice - for everybody using VirtualBox.  Using the status icons from VirtualBox would make sense for me. Looking at the tray from the external drives ... something like this. Status icon in front of each line and on the right like the "unmount-icon" some action icons like start, stop (and may some more)  Should be possible if I look e.g. at the tray from the sound-applet...  I never did something like this and and have sadly no time to dive into it, so I can give no help for implementing, but I could do a little design-shot if this helps.  Greetings from Germany

Name: vboxlauncher - show machine status [feature]
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause maybe tag this with FEATURE-REQUEST?

Name: vboxlauncher - show machine status [feature]

Name: bumblebee@marmistrz: resize and make icon square
Comment_Body: @marmistrz  As the original author of the applet you forked I am interested to know if you intend to continue to support this version as I am thinking of modifying bumblebee@pdcurtis to have a simpler mode for vertical panels and an option of just an icon to save space in the horizontal mode.

Name: bumblebee@marmistrz: resize and make icon square
Comment_Body: Sorry for the delay, I missed the PR. @NikoKrause I'm ok with changing the icon. It will basically be only displayed in the applet mgr @pdcurtis I'm no longer using Bumblebee since I switched to nouveau, so I probably won't be able to really test it. I may try merging your changes.  Anyway, I think it may be a better idea to integrate what I did my fork into upstream, so that the user can choose the UI flavor. For me, this UI was more visually appealing, but I think it's best to give the user a choice.

Name: bumblebee@marmistrz: resize and make icon square
Comment_Body: @pdcurtis @marmistrz  So what are the plans for this applet? Deleting or keeping? If pdcurtis wants to combine those and you don't want to maintain it anymore?

Name: bumblebee@marmistrz: resize and make icon square
Comment_Body: Hi,  My views are:  * The current situation is confusing as we have two aplets with the same icon and similar names, especially as one has no README.md to distinguish it, so something needs to be done.  * My original applet was written partially to satisfy my requirements which gave priority to the GPU temperature rather than a simple indicator which GPU was in use.  * My applet needs modification to work with a vertical panel and would then have to use a graphic indicator of the GPU in use (as per the fork) and the Temperature would be via the tooltip and left click menus. It could be a user choice to use the same on a horizontal panel.  * The fork by @marmistrz would also need changes to work on a vertical panel and needs Translation support etc as well as a README.md   * I intend to modify several of my applets to work with a vertical panel and Bumblebee and the Battery Monitor with Alerts and Shutdown (BAMS) are top of my list but on a time-scale of weeks not days.  In summary:  * In a month or two I should be able to offer a choice of the two UIs and the fork by @marmistrz would not be essential. I can also credit @marmistrz with the idea of adding the simpler GUI.  * If however @marmistrz wants to continue his applet I am prepared to check it works if he no longer uses Bumblebee. * I am also happy to receive any contributions to improve mine!  @NikoKrause  What are the teams view on overlapping applets bearing in mind small changes are a good way to introduce new blood into applet writers?

Name: bumblebee@marmistrz: resize and make icon square
Comment_Body: That's not confusing. There are a bunch of similar applets with similar names and even with the same name, e.g. System Monitor or Gmail Notifier. ;)  There are a few applets, which are very similar. Some are forks of applets, which were broken. If there are applets, which have just been created for fixing existing broken applets, but do not have any further changes, the working one is kept and the broken one will be deleted. E.g. Messaging Menu, Messaging Menu v2, Messaging Menu v3  Those have to be tested and it needs to be decided individually. If you detect broken applets, which can be deleted because of those reasons or because there are other/better options let us know.

It may also help identify abandoned applets. Great work but could end up with unintended consequences when you identify strings and create the .pot files rather than just an extra .po. Name: Add translation support for Cheaty - Cheatsheet keeper
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @Centurix: I think that it is possible to make translatable all the cheat sheets. The [cinnamon-json-makepot.py](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/blob/master/files/usr/share/cinnamon/cinnamon-json-makepot/cinnamon-json-makepot.py) file could assist you with the task. That file [has a function that extracts strings](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/blob/master/files/usr/share/cinnamon/cinnamon-json-makepot/cinnamon-json-makepot.py#L224) from JSON files (settings-schema.json and metadata.json). It comes to mind that you could create a Python script that scans the **refdocs** folder on your applet and then it extracts all the strings that would need to be translated (the "name" and "description" keys). The "sections" key could be a little more complex to *parse*, but I think that it could also be done. Then all the extracted strings can be appended to an existing .pot file.

Name: Add translation support for Cheaty - Cheatsheet keeper
Comment_Body: @Odyseus, thanks, that looks like a good way of solving this, I'll look into it!  On Thu, Apr 27, 2017 at 12:17 PM, Odyseus <notifications@github.com> wrote:  > Hello, everybody. > > @Centurix <https://github.com/Centurix>: I think that it is possible to > make translatable all the cheat sheets. The cinnamon-json-makepot.py > <https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/blob/master/files/usr/share/cinnamon/cinnamon-json-makepot/cinnamon-json-makepot.py> > file could assist you with the task. That file has a function that > extracts strings > <https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/blob/master/files/usr/share/cinnamon/cinnamon-json-makepot/cinnamon-json-makepot.py#L224> > from JSON files (settings-schema.json and metadata.json). It comes to mind > that you could create a Python script that scans the *refdocs* folder on > your applet and then it extracts all the strings that would need to be > translated (the "name" and "description" keys). The "sections" key could be > a little more complex to *parse*, but I think that it could also be done. > Then all the extracted strings can be appended to an existing .pot file. > > — > You are receiving this because you were mentioned. > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub > <https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/428#issuecomment-297592564>, > or mute the thread > <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABYMYAxKUlwF1Wf9LNtKjyzUaYQQHn4Yks5rz_rEgaJpZM4NGTSd> > . >    --  Chris Read centurix@gmail.com LinkedIn <http://chris.fipo.co>

It's used to create the pot file for translations. pt_BR file was waiting for possible changes regarding the minor differences between Portugal Portuguese and Brazilian Portuguese (believe me, we have bigger differences than color vs. colour), but it's probably not needed. Can be recreated if some Brazilian propose a different translation.

Name: printers@linux-man: use proper language ID

Name: printers@linux-man: use proper language ID
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause  Why in some spices cinnamon-json-makepot --js po/printers@linux-man.pot or cinnamon-json-makepot -i po/printers@linux-man.pot commands don't work. I try in this applet and I get error:  $ cinnamon-json-makepot --js po/printers@linux-man.pot xgettext (GNU gettext-tools) 0.19.8.1 Copyright (C) 1995-1998, 2000-2016 Free Software Foundation, Inc. License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <http://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html> This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it. There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law. Written by Ulrich Drepper.   Running xgettext on JavaScript files... Traceback (most recent call last):   File "/usr/share/cinnamon/cinnamon-json-makepot/cinnamon-json-makepot.py", line 275, in <module>     Main()   File "/usr/share/cinnamon/cinnamon-json-makepot/cinnamon-json-makepot.py", line 130, in __init__     tmp = tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(prefix="cinnamon-json-makepot-") NameError: global name 'tempfile' is not defined

Name: printers@linux-man: use proper language ID
Comment_Body: Not sure what happens. It works for me. Since you are running Cinnamon nightlies that's maybe a new bug. @Odyseus?

Name: printers@linux-man: use proper language ID
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @muzena: You have to provide a file name, not a path. The correct command is as follows:  ```shell cinnamon-json-makepot --js filename ```  The .pot extension also wouldn't be needed, it is automatically added. Although, it isn't an error to add it.  To install localizations you don't need to specify a location to the `cinnamon-json-makepot` command. Running the `cinnamon-json-makepot` with the `-i` argument from the xlet folder is enough.  ```shell cinnamon-json-makepot -i ```

Name: printers@linux-man: use proper language ID
Comment_Body: @Odyseus  A path worked for me. So that shouldn't be an issue.

Name: printers@linux-man: use proper language ID
Comment_Body: @muzena: It was an error on the cinnamon-json-makepot script. I just submitted a fix for it. You can temporarily fix it by editing the `/usr/share/cinnamon/cinnamon-json-makepot/cinnamon-json-makepot.py` file and add **import tempfile** to the list of imports at the beginning of the code.

Name: printers@linux-man: use proper language ID
Comment_Body: @Odyseus  Thanks, now it works.

Name: Add translation support for Countdown timer with notifications
Comment_Body: @giwhub One suggestion: Don't start or end translations with whitespaces. Not every translator does watch out for such details. Also try to include only the necessary Information in translations, e.g. you habe to translate "Minutes" 3 times. _(" Minutes and ") _(" Minutes ") _("Minutes: 0")  Try something like this instead: " " + _("Minutes") + " " + _("and") + " " " " + _("Minutes") + " " "_("Minutes") + ": 0"  That's a little bit ugly in the code, but the translator has less to translate and he has not to watch out for whitespaces.  Only a suggestion though.

Name: Rules violations for a lot of applets
Comment_Body: From my understanding of discussions I've seen, translations are treated as a bit of a special case. They provide a benefit to all spices users. They are being treated more as a bugfix than a feature.  Outside of that, up until now you've been quite clear about the fact that you want nothing to do with this new system. That's fine and it's your choice to make. I don't understand why then you feel the need to pop in here just to open an issue like this.

Name: Rules violations for a lot of applets
Comment_Body: That is not nice, i lost 5 years as a Cinnamon thrid-party dev, and all for what? @clefebvre decide fork all thrid-party extension and change it like he want. I will not stop this here, this is not right. This will go from the network.

Name: Rules violations for a lot of applets
Comment_Body: >  Reviewvers, yours are adding a translations to all extensions in cinnamon against yours owns rules. >  > "Pull requests from other people >  > In addition to the checks specified above, if the pull requests comes from somebody else than the author, the reviewer will need to check the nature of the changes. >  > If the changes represent a bug fix, the PR can be merged. >  > If the changes represent a change in functionality, or in look and feel, or if their implementation could be questioned and/or discussed, the reviewer should leave the PR open and ask the author to review it. >  > If the author is happy with the PR, it can then be merged. If he's not, it can be closed instead."  > That is not nice, i lost 5 years as a Cinnamon thrid-party dev, and all for what? @clefebvre decide fork all thrid-party extension and change it like he want. I will not stop this here, this is not right. This will go from the network.  I think the full discussion happened, and people decided whether to keep their applets here or not. Since everybody who wanted them removed had the chance by now, I don't think this disservices anybody by having people translate their applets for them. It brings more attention to a lot of applets that otherwise would be lost in obscurity.  I had my doubts at first, but I have come around to the idea of it after seeing how much better the quality is. Its allowed me to fix a bug in the weather applet that's annoyed me. I've seen more help with translations on my own applets. I think the whole point of writing these extensions is to improve Cinnamon. At the end of the day your applet is going to be on Github, whether its here, or on your account I think is a minor difference. You in particular GPL licensed your work, that is free software. Nobody has to get your blessing to fork it any way, it is just good conduct to ask - LM respected this by removing your applets.  Did you waste 5 years? It seems like any experience I get writing code, I grow as a developer. It seems a little bitter.

Name: Rules violations for a lot of applets
Comment_Body: @jaszhix wander-full if it's your decision.  I commented here because this is just the proved from where this come, before I had not prove and it was just my fear. **This is then only the broken promise of respect the author decisions about not modify the code without his authorization** So, this is the end of the chance to wait for a different implementation. This is then the death of all code that i make to work inside cinnamon only.  And finally this is the death of all the hopes I could have, that things were not where they certainly go. I can speak with base on facts now and not ex-peculations for an unclear things...  So, this is just only that i feel bad about who the things are now and i express my nonconformity with this.  Won't worried, the thing can not go more wrong for me here, as actually i removed all things, that also included the hope.

Name: Rules violations for a lot of applets
Comment_Body: > This is then only the broken promise of respect the author decisions about not modify the code without his authorization  How are PO files code? Honestly as an English only speaker this translation help is nice. Before I spent hours copying (probably) mediocre translations from Google Translate. Now more native speakers are doing it.  I could have removed my applets, maybe even build a mirror of Spices, and maybe continue work on your port of Cinnamon's JS. I'm not though because the Linux userland has way too much fragmentation as it is. It is my decision.

Name: Rules violations for a lot of applets
Comment_Body: So, you posted the issue, I responded, you deleted all your comments, and now some of them at least are back. This isn't going much further or it will be locked.  The spices site is run by Linux Mint and Linux Mint sets the rules for it. That means they can be changed by Linux Mint when it is felt necessary. You made it clear from the beginning you didn't like the idea. We respected your wishes and removed all of your stuff when you asked. You've chosen not to be a part of this or a contributor to it. Fine, that's your choice. Ranting and threatening things like "I will not stop this here, this is not right. This will go from the network" is going to get you nowhere. It will simply result in the issues being closed, locked, and/or deleted.

Name: Rules violations for a lot of applets
Comment_Body: https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/commit/48a642fdc2100256d8c6dc83acfb3c970d06b302

Name: Rules violations for a lot of applets
Comment_Body: @lestcape I wish you well in whatever you move onto next.  I enjoyed working with you on Mint code, you were knowledgeable and inventive, and you helped me solve some problems.  We are all part of a small community trying to move things forward and to do the right thing for those who use our open source software.  Adding translations would seem to be one of those things that is so obviously going to be of benefit to our users.  It's something that is fundamentally aligned to the open source ethos, with people from different countries contributing their language skills, so more people can use our code.  And with gettext tools it is largely independent of writing the application code. So although I can see you appear to be upset and angry, I don't really understand why. I am glad that @collinss has clarified how translations are handled, above. But anyway ... best wishes for your future work. Simon.

Name: Rules violations for a lot of applets
Comment_Body: @brownsr I know i'm difficult to understand the English is not my language. All my projects have translations, i was the first who ask to a way to do that. The translation are not the problem.  My problem is work with the rules of others in my projects. Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: I see you replaced every `_("translatable string")` with `_('translatable string')`.  The problem with that is, that if you create/update the translation pot file with `cinnamon-json-makepot` command, those strings won't be recognized.  You can try and compare. I don't know, if it's a bug or a feature.

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: That seems like a bug that should be fixed in cinnamon-json-makepot. Single quotes strings look a lot cleaner to me. When CJS uses mozjs38, you may also need to account for string template syntax which looks like  ```js `This string has a ${variable}` ``` https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Template_literals

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: Not sure about the variable stuff. Normally there's something like that: `_("Failed to launch '%s'").format(this.name)`  Also with `%d` for numbers.  Just saying, that for now, if you change " to ' you won't be able to update your pot file with the makepot script.  I saw @Odyseus fixed the script to be able to scan subdirectories (for multiversions). It's merged and will be available in LM 18.2. Not sure if he did a bugfix for that as well, though.

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: Looks like a typo maybe? https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/blob/cd180f074d5d450f3442613b4827f7aa4c987cd5/files/usr/share/cinnamon/cinnamon-json-makepot/cinnamon-json-makepot.py#L134  Shouldn't the language be set to JavaScript on xgettext? Unless there's a nuance I'm missing.

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: The convention that was established by gnome for js stuff was to single quote non-translatable strings and double quote translatable ones. It makes them easier to search. We don't always follow it but probably should.

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: Ah, it's a feature!

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: Ok, I'll revert it later today. It wasn't intentional, I just didn't diff the spices repo's version with what's on my own. I think it makes the JS look inconsistent IMHO.

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: You can make it look consistent. But then you loose the feature to autocreate the makepot.  And since it's a feature and not a bug in makepot it's unlikely to get changed.

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: Couldn't you accomplish searching for translated strings by searching for an underscore? As I understand it xgettext used to not have a JavaScript option when this line was added, so it seems like a bug.

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: > Couldn't you accomplish searching for translated strings by searching for an underscore?  Yes probably but many function calls use underscores. Essentially most introspected code. It's not a huge deal but just a convention, and imho, a sensible one. Just pointing out where it came from.

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: If you use an exact match (click the quote button in Sublime for instance), it will take you to those translated lines. Maybe this is the consensus in GNOME land, but I don't think its a very universal convention.

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: Maybe not. I think the idea though was to help find strings not properly wrapped by _(). In any case I don't feel strongly enough about it to fight for it :)

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @jaszhix: When I first started using the `cinnamon-json-makepot` command and saw the `--language=C` argument, I thought about changing that, so I investigated the reason behind its use. When I discovered the why, I simply desisted of the idea of changing it to avoid useless discussions and headaches. So I created my own version of the cinnamon-json-makepot.py script with the correct argument for js files (`--language=JavaScript`), plus I added to it support to scan Python files and to blacklist keys found on the settings-schema.json file.  Using the wrong language for the `--language` argument can bring unforeseen complications. It might throw warnings that shouldn't throw and **it will** insert wrong comments into the .pot files for one. Using the wrong language to scan Python files can throw actual errors, even from strings found inside comments. ¬¬  As for following conventions, we should be following Cinnamon's conventions, not Gnome's. [And Cinnamon uses `--language=JavaScript` argument for `xgettext` to scan JavaScript code for the generation of the cinnamon.pot file](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/blob/cd180f074d5d450f3442613b4827f7aa4c987cd5/makepot#L6).

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: Ah, I see. I would open a PR now and try to fix it but I'm not sure how to test things in other locales at the moment - I'd rather not push anything I can't test. If I were you I'd PR it and see what happens.

Name: Cinnamenu: Update to 1.2.0
Comment_Body: I accidentally reverted part of Niko's gettext changes, will reopen.

Name: 26 Applets: Remove dangerous flags
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause I always wondered why it had been added to some of my applets and I am glad the "dangerous" is removed. One of my applets also has a "last-edited": added to it at the same time and I note several of the applets also have that - should they also be removed?

Name: 26 Applets: Remove dangerous flags
Comment_Body: @pdcurtis Those are normally added to the metadata of an *installed* applet by cinnamon-settings.  The last-edited was a way to compare time stamps with the spices website and the one in the installed folder to determine if there was an update.  During startup of cinnamon-settings, that dangerous flag would be added by a one-time scan of the applet files.  I think when this repo was made, clem just installed all of the applets via the gui, so we got all of these modifications as well.

Name: 26 Applets: Remove dangerous flags
Comment_Body: @mtwebster Thanks for the information. Do you know what the criteria for dangerous was and are the applets likely to be scanned in the future - if so I would like to 'fix' whatever caused the flag to be set as I am sure it put people off loading my applet.

Name: 26 Applets: Remove dangerous flags
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @pdcurtis: You can't control wether the "dangerous" key will appear or not on an xlet metadata.json file. If you remove it, that key will appear again the next time an xlet manager is opened. And it will be set to **true** or **false** depending on the existence of certain strings (as of now "spawn_sync", "spawn_command_line_sync", "GTop" and "get_file_contents_utf8_sync") inside any .js file on your xlets folder.  As you can see, some of the "unsafe strings" could be replaced by simply using their async counterparts. But in the case of **GTop**, I would think that there is no alternative option.

Name: 26 Applets: Remove dangerous flags
Comment_Body: @pdcurtis: If a user installs an applet the first time, it gets scanned and the dangerous flag will be added. You can check it. Move one of your applets folders away from the .local/share/cinnamon/applets folder (so manually uninstall), restart Cinnamon and move the applet folder back (so install manually). Maybe restart Cinnamon again, not sure. The dangerous flag should be added.  When I work on an applet and it crashes, (i.e. when I get the popup info, that the applet couldn't be loaded) the flag is added as well, after I geht it back working.  Before I create a commit, I check with `git status` if metadata.json was changed. If I didn't changed anything in there I `git checkout metadata.json`.

Name: 26 Applets: Remove dangerous flags
Comment_Body: Thanks for the explanations. I have found one example of a `spawn_command_line_sync` which I have been able to change in code originating in vnstat@linuxmint.com which I have changed to `spawn_command_line_async` without any obvious problems. I think it was written by @clefebvre and it might be worth also changing in that applet if it does not cause any problems.  I also use GTop and any suggestions of how to get network statistics without use of GTop would be welcome. My use is  minimal namely:        ```  GTop.glibtop_get_netload(this.gtop, this.monitoredInterfaceName);         this.upOld = this.gtop.bytes_out;         this.downOld = this.gtop.bytes_in; ``` Why is GTop a problem? I could understand GLib as you can call script files which could be malicious. Now all applets are on Github wouldn't it be better to search and individually check the small number of applets using GTop and synchronous calls?

Name: netusagemonitor@pdcurtis (NUMA) Update to version 3.1.0
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause @Odyseus and others who might be able to help.  I am trying to harmonise my Applets with other Cinnamon Applets, (the purpose of this pull request) and I have one outstanding area with harmonising this applet where I would appreciate some help.  The right click (context) menu is recreated at various times as it contains a list of the current network interfaces and which are active.  This means that the three 'standard' entries for Configure.. About... and Remove are no longer added automatically and should be added in my rebuilds  of the context menu.  I have always replaced the Configure entry but I am have difficulty in finding how to make the About.. and Remove..   entries. I have only found a couple of examples and they were very specific and I have not been able to make them work probably because I am not correctly picking up the parameters required or adding the correct `const` entries.  Any suggestions on how to do this seemingly simple task would be welcome.    In addition how do the automatically added entries get translated and how do I make my replacements consistent.

Name: netusagemonitor@pdcurtis (NUMA) Update to version 3.1.0
Comment_Body: @pdcurtis There are a couple of options. The applet class has the function ```finalizeContextMenu``` that will add them automatically for you if they're not there already. If you are using the same context menu that is created by the api, it should be simple enough to implement this. A more "proper" solution would be to create a ```PopupMenu.PopupMenuSection``` in the context menu. You can than use that to hold your menu items and then just refresh that instead of the whole menu. This one might take a little more work, but still shouldn't be too hard.

Name: netusagemonitor@pdcurtis (NUMA) Update to version 3.1.0
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @pdcurtis: I would use a `PopupMenu.PopupMenuSection`, like @collinss suggested. It will allow you to keep your code almost exactly as you have it now with just some tweaks. The following code will add all your menu items to the applet context menu without touching the default items.  ```javascript     // Build right click context menu     buildContextMenu: function() {         // Not needed.         // this._applet_context_menu.removeAll();          if (this.myMenuSection)             this.myMenuSection.destroy();          this.myMenuSection = new PopupMenu.PopupMenuSection();         this._applet_context_menu.addMenuItem(this.myMenuSection, 0);          // Rest of buildContextMenu function.         // Items added to this.myMenuSection insted of this._applet_context_menu.     }, ```  Note that I used the index 0 (zero) to insert the menu section. When I add items to de context menu, the items are normally added at the beginning of the menu. But in the case of your applet, the menu section was added after all the default items. I don't know why that happened, that's why the forced insertion point. Maybe @collinss could shed some light on this?

Name: netusagemonitor@pdcurtis (NUMA) Update to version 3.1.0
Comment_Body: @collinss @Odyseus Thank you very much for the suggestions. I think it is going to take a little time to try these out and make sure I understand them fully and that there are no unforeseen problems so I will probably go ahead with the requesting pull request as it stands and implement the menu fixing in a separate branch.  I had no idea about the the function finalizeContextMenu and had expected to have to add separate 'calls' similar to what is in Odesius@window-list-fork. This looks a more elegant solution and one which may maintain consistence through changes in cinnamon versions better.  As far as the reasoning in that part of the code: I think that originated in a much more basic form in the original Network Speed Monitor (NSM) project by adreadec who discontinued the project in the days of cinnamon 1.5 (https://github.com/andreadec/cinnamon-applet-netspeed). Since then it has developed into a much more powerful and flexible tool and I put it onto github three years ago but some of the original thinking still remains and I have adopted the approach of "If it ain't broke don't fix it"

Name: netusagemonitor@pdcurtis (NUMA) Update to version 3.1.0
Comment_Body: @collinss @Odyseus Thank you again, your suggestion seems to have worked perfectly for the menu and sub menu - everything is retained during a refresh of the network interfaces.  I will run it for a couple of days just to make sure and also wait for #290 to be merged then upload as a new pull request

Name: feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com
Comment_Body: This is sorta a rhetorical question at this point since the work has been done, but what is the stance on python 2 vs python 3 vs supporting both?  I went ahead and continued to support both, however, its a serious PIA with handling encoding (utf-8) in python 2 vs python 3.  I would love to just support python 3, but will that make the applet unavailable for any users or does everybody have python 3 at this point?

Name: feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com
Comment_Body: @jake1164 Python 3 should be fine. Many of our apps have already been ported. Xlet settings uses python 3 for example, though Cinnamon-settings uses python 2. Bottom line - any system that uses Cinnamon should have python 3 installed.

Name: batterymonitor@pdcurtis Update to version 1.2.2
Comment_Body: The translation file looks OK. Just one little thing. Sometimes you are using more than one whitespace before and after a word. Also you have a whitespaces at the end of whitespaces.  You can't expect, that every translator would use the same number of whitespaces. E.g. ``` "    " + _("Wait") + "     " ``` if you really want them to be there.

Name: batterymonitor@pdcurtis Update to version 1.2.2
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause Thanks for checking so comprehensively, it has brought out the value of the new system.  I think all of the single spaces are required for layout but few of the multiple ones are essential as they just pad menus to look better so one or two more or less would not matter. The example you gave is an initial value until the first cycle is completed and will never be seen in practice.  In searching for examples I have also found a couple of strings which have not been marked for translation within composite strings of text and variables.   I think your comments here are sufficiently valuable they should go into your howto on translations so others avoid the problem.  **Can you hold the Pull for a day or two** until I have had a chance to do a more comprehensive check to see if I also need to take any spaces out of the translated strings and put them into fixed strings.  Am I correct that I can just commit and push any changes to the same branch and they are included in the Pull?

Name: batterymonitor@pdcurtis Update to version 1.2.2
Comment_Body: Yes, if you create a commit in this branch and push, it will appear here in the pull request. So it's good to create for each pull request an own branch.  You can change the title of the pull request. Just add [WIP] at the beginning of the title. WIP = Work in progress. This way it won't be merged. If you are ready remove the [WIP] prefix.

Name: batterymonitor@pdcurtis Update to version 1.2.2
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause Thanks, I have added the [WIP] to the title as suggested and will now be able to sort out the strings.

Name: batterymonitor@pdcurtis Update to version 1.2.2
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause I have done this with two commits as the changes are not only from your comments - is this acceptable or should I squash them and do a forced push.

Name: batterymonitor@pdcurtis Update to version 1.2.2
Comment_Body: I don't mind two commits in this case.

Name: batterymonitor@pdcurtis Update to version 1.2.2
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause Thanks again, I will remove the [WIP] and finally go ahead
