Name: color-picker@fmete: Dialogue does not appear
Comment_Body: The description says  > Click applet, after click a pixel, its color automatically copied clipboard. Required Packages: `sudo apt-get install xsel python-xlib`  Install the packages, choose a color with the applet, then open a text editor, rightclick, paste. The colorcode should appear.

Name: color-picker@fmete: Dialogue does not appear
Comment_Body: My comment says:  > **The dependencies are installed**: > > > python-xlib:all/trusty-updates 0.14+20091101-1ubuntu3~trusty uptodate > > xsel:amd64/trusty 1.2.0-2 uptodate  I _did_ install the dependencies, the 'packages'.  The [screenshot](https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/git/applets/color-picker@fmete/screenshot.png), however, did mislead me into expecting a dialogue, so thanks for that clarification.  But it's still not working. When I click the applet, and then click somewhere on the screen, it changes neither the select buffer nor the clipboard.  What else can I check?

Name: color-picker@fmete: Dialogue does not appear
Comment_Body: Ah, I've worked out what's going on. For it to work, I need to do one of two things:  1. Click the applet _before_ the mouseover/tooltip appears ('Click here to pick a color'). In other words, click the applet within about 250ms of moving the mouse over it. 2. If I don't click quickly enough, before the tooltip appears, I need to click three more times: once to get rid of the tooltip, once for the applet to see, and once to select the colour. _However_, I need to move the mouse cursor slightly before that second click; if I don't, it just won't work.  I would call this a bug, a frustrating one that's prevented me from being able to use this applet for years.  Let me know if I can provide more info.

Name: color-picker@fmete: Dialogue does not appear
Comment_Body: Try this: 1. Open the applet.js file of the applet: ``` xed ~/.local/share/cinnamon/applets/color-picker@fmete/applet.js  ``` 2. Remove line 66: ``` this.set_applet_tooltip(_("click here to pick a color")); ``` 3. Save and restart Cinnamon.  This will remove the tooltip.

Name: color-picker@fmete: Dialogue does not appear
Comment_Body: @mscheper Does this workaround fix your issue? If yes, I would create a pull request to solve it generally.

Name: Battery Applet with Monitoring and Shutdown (BAMS): Add an indicator for when the laptop is charging
Comment_Body: The spices website https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/applets/view/255 says by pdcurtis. So its not @AppletAuthor but @pdcurtis.

Name: Battery Applet with Monitoring and Shutdown (BAMS): Add an indicator for when the laptop is charging
Comment_Body: @mscheper The background colour of the applet already gave a quick indication of the state of charge and I am planning to enhance that by adding a red border to the 'normal' green background when it is discharging and above the alert level.   The applet will now show the percentage charge on a coloured background which is:    * Green when above the alert level (set currently to 1.5 times the 'shutdown' level.)   * Green has Red Border when discharging (Added in version v32_1.0.0)   * Orange between the warning and shutdown level   * Red and flashing at and below the Shutdown level (even when charging).     When the battery is Discharging the warning and shutdown regions also have a much larger flashing message in the applet which is difficult to miss.    I am also making some other enhancements including:    -  Adding a short fixed audible alert as well as a modal alert when the Alert Level is reached  which has been requested by @diviney.  The new version will remain under test on my machines for a few days before being made available.  @NikoKrause I am also thinking about adding translation support - can you assist if required with implementation and a German translation in due course?

Name: Battery Applet with Monitoring and Shutdown (BAMS): Add an indicator for when the laptop is charging
Comment_Body: @mscheper I am glad you are happy with the change.   Can you or @NikoKrause  close this issue now that the feature is included in the applet and is available from the Spices web site.

Name: Places applet (places-bookmarks@dmo60.de) only shows menu if positioned on top tray
Comment_Body: Hello, @szekeres2016.  It works perfectly for me in either panel (top or bottom). Restart Cinnamon after moving your entire panel to the bottom/top.

Name: Places applet (places-bookmarks@dmo60.de) only shows menu if positioned on top tray
Comment_Body: Hello, I even had several reboots but still not working for me. :S Any configuration files I should clear out maybe to have is reset somehow?  EDIT: I also checked my other desktop computer with panel positioned on top by default, I moved it top the bottom just to check and exact same behavior, the menu only shows if the panel is on top. I think some configuration file is forcing it to display like this. Once I get home from work will create another user and log in to see if new accounts are affected as well.

Name: Places applet (places-bookmarks@dmo60.de) only shows menu if positioned on top tray
Comment_Body: Hello, @szekeres2016.  You are right. I did my tests on Cinnamon 3.0.7, not on 3.2.x. In 3.2.x I see the same behaviour as you.  To fix it, just edit the applet.js file as follows:  Change the line (85) that reads: ```javascript this.menu = new MyMenu(this, orientation); ```  To this: ```javascript this.menu = new Applet.AppletPopupMenu(this, orientation); ```  And restart Cinnamon.  Ping to the applet author: @dmo60

Name: Places applet (places-bookmarks@dmo60.de) only shows menu if positioned on top tray
Comment_Body: It worked! Thank you!

Name: PDFManager@cinnamon.org: language bugfix
Comment_Body: Why did you remove all the semicolons? It is proper syntax to include them.

Name: PDFManager@cinnamon.org: language bugfix
Comment_Body: Because it doesn't change anything (I've looked other applet to check). It was the plugin I've created but languages were not supported anymore so I suggest this modifications. I will correct other bugs in few days and add more functionality.

Name: PDFManager@cinnamon.org: language bugfix
Comment_Body: I will rewrite all semicolons in a future update. I've checked and you're right it's proper

Name: PDFManager@cinnamon.org: language bugfix
Comment_Body: > languages were not supported anymore so I suggest this modifications  The problem why the languages are not supported anymore is, because of a wrong UUID in `Gettext.dgettext`, i.e. you can change this ``` function _(str) {    let customTranslation = Gettext.dgettext("PDFManager", str);    if(customTranslation != str) {       return customTranslation;    }    return Gettext.gettext(str); } ``` to this ``` function _(str) {    let customTranslation = Gettext.dgettext("PDFManager@cinnamon.org", str);    if(customTranslation != str) {       return customTranslation;    }    return Gettext.gettext(str); } ```

Name: PDFManager@cinnamon.org: language bugfix
Comment_Body: Yes, I understood so I changed that :) I'm a beginner of Github and I'm not an expert of programming so sorry for my mistakes (semicolons and the previous pull request)

Name: PDFManager@cinnamon.org: language bugfix
Comment_Body: No need to apologize. The semicolons are not a mistake. It makes no difference, if they are there or not.  Edit: I would merge it, if you don't want to have them. In the end it's your decision, what you like better in your applet.

Comment_Body: Can you change the author in the info.json file of your applet from `mickaelalb` to your GitHub user name `mickaelalbertus`?

Name: PDFManager@cinnamon.org: language bugfix
Comment_Body: Sure, I didn't have Github account when I've created this one. I do on the next pull request or I modify this one?

Name: PDFManager@cinnamon.org: language bugfix
Comment_Body: > I do on the next pull request or I modify this one?  It's up to you. You can create another commit in you branch `PDFManager@cinnamon.org.bugfix` if you want to. It will be added to the pull request here.  Should this be merged then?

Name: Printers(printers@linux-man): not display icon applet
Comment_Body: Couldn't replicate the bug. Maybe an icon is missing? Try to change the icon to non-symbolic and see what happens. The icon used is the system printer-printing-symbolic and printer-printing. You can find them at /usr/share/icons/Mint-X/status/scalable.  Update: It can't be a missing icon: you can see it in "Printers". When did this start to happen?

Name: Printers(printers@linux-man): not display icon applet
Comment_Body: @linux-man. Icons for found. The reason is that one of the calls to `Util.spawn_async` does not work and execution does not reach  `this.setIcon ('');` and the icon is not set.  I suggest before first calling `Util.spawn_async` write example `this.setIcon('printer-printing');` // default icon

Name: Printers(printers@linux-man): not display icon applet
Comment_Body: That explains what happens. My question is what call is failing? If you don't see the installed printer on the menu, it can be "python lpstat-a.py" (at the applet folder) or "/usr/bin/lpstat -d". The following calls are "/usr/bin/lpstat -o" "/usr/bin/lpq -a"  Can you try this commands at the console?

Name: Printers(printers@linux-man): not display icon applet
Comment_Body: The problem repeats when I delete all printers `/usr/bin/lpstat -o` nothing print `/usr/bin/lpq -a` print "No records" `python lpstat.py` print "lpstat:No added values"  I made a translation for an applet from a computer where there are no printers.  Created an error report.  I tried at work to do the same thing and after removing all the printers on the computer the problem was reproduced.

Name: Printers(printers@linux-man): not display icon applet
Comment_Body: I still can't replicate your problem, but if it only arise when there are no printers, the solution you proposed is feasible. Could you please replace applet.js with this one? [applet.js.zip](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/files/857933/applet.js.zip)

Name: IcingTaskManager@json: Libreoffice base no preview of forms and tables
Comment_Body: - Pastbin the outputs of:     - ~/.cinnamon/configs/IcingTaskManager@json/*.json     - ~/.cinnamon/glass.log     - ~/.xsession-errors   - Describe the steps needed to be taken in order to reproduce this bug.

Name: IcingTaskManager@json: Libreoffice base no preview of forms and tables
Comment_Body: When you launch LibreOffice from the start center Cinnamon will sometimes incorrectly identify the app ID. Since the recent fix I haven't had any issues except the wrong app showing under the app buttons when launching two different LO apps.   The default window list is using a different signal than I am for the window events, so that's possibly something that can be looked into, but in the end I'm getting application info through the same APIs. You may want to double check your version of ITM, the version listed on the website may not necessarily be what you have unless you upgrade in the applet settings.  Please see the other LibreOffice [issues](https://github.com/jaszhix/icingtaskmanager/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20libreoffice) on my repo.

Comment_Body: I do not start LO files from the start center I start with link,  e.G.  libreoffice5.2  ~/*/test.odb  If I start from the start center another strange behavior occurs:  Now I get 2 entries in the panel  1 entry with  database container only 1 correct entry with container and form  Am 15.03.2017 um 11:27 schrieb Jason Hicks: > > I don't think its a timing issue. LibreOffice will continue to be seen  > as |libreoffice-base| whenever you launch apps from the start center,  > and the apps are seen by Cinnamon properly when launched individually.  > I'm not sure what I can do about it, ITM has no way of knowing what  > apps are being launched from LibreOffice Base. > > — > You are receiving this because you authored the thread. > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub  > <https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/issues/214#issuecomment-286701367>,  > or mute the thread  > <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AZJah49Y-93EogF39pdiYS_wquQxCfevks5rl7z6gaJpZM4Mdt8p>. >

Since the recent fix I  > haven't had any issues except the wrong app showing under the app  > buttons when launching two different LO apps. > verifying the app ids with ps -aux | less gets always the same result.  Perhaps it could be helpfull to consider, what happens within the ITM  app, if preferences (title, app, focused, no) are changed.  In Libreoffice calc the behavior is little bit different. If i open 1.  file, ok, opening the 2. file, results in showing 1 item with 1. file  and another item combined with 1. file and second file.  Whenever I change the preferences, regardless of after having opened 1  or 2 files, the previews will be correct. E.g. I open File 1, then open file 2, I will get two main previews (File  1 and File2+1) I change preference The preview if file 1 disappears and the result is correct.  > The default window list is using a different signal than I am for the  > window events, so that's possibly something that can be looked into,  > but in the end I'm getting application info through the same APIs. You  > may want to double check your version of ITM, the version listed on  > the website may not necessarily be what you have unless you upgrade in  > the applet settings. > I downloaded and installed yesterday with the download button on  https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/applets/view/269. Files date is march, 7, 2017, I think that should be the latest version. > > Please see the other LibreOffice issues  > <https://github.com/jaszhix/icingtaskmanager/issues?utf8=%E2%9C%93&q=is%3Aissue%20libreoffice>  > on my repo. > > — > You are receiving this because you authored the thread. > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub  > <https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/issues/214#issuecomment-286719058>,  > or mute the thread  > <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AZJah_nKNEOukcgvIGeb5NFD28Pnp8ueks5rl9AfgaJpZM4Mdt8p>. >

Name: IcingTaskManager@json: Libreoffice base no preview of forms and tables
Comment_Body: Here another strange behavior: After having switched preferences in ITM sub windows are shown as declared, but in the wrong Libreoffice application (Sub window base is shown in calc) ![bildschirmfoto vom 2017-03-15 17-21-18](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/26368647/23959116/898217f0-09a4-11e7-991f-260c0612e57c.png) ![bildschirmfoto vom 2017-03-15 17-21-12](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/26368647/23959121/90478548-09a4-11e7-800a-9aeed02c1753.png)  Excuse if I am insisting on that issue. I am working with lot of libreoffice files and docs, different databases. Opening 5 or more documents at once can be very confusing in classic taskbar. But grouping wrong is even worse.  When I tested the former app "windows list with app grouping" I could "work around" that behavior by manually editing the libreoffice .desktop files and enter one single class name for all Libreoffice apps (base, calc etc.). But at the end I dropped "windows list with app grouping" because of some other hard bugs. Your app is wonderful, only I am LO Hard-Line-User, may be my problem is not really important for most of the other users.  So don't hesitate to tell me if it is not possible to solve the problem. Then I will close the issue.

Name: IcingTaskManager@json: Libreoffice base no preview of forms and tables
Comment_Body: Yes, it occurs when more than one LO app is open. I'm not sure how to work around it yet, and since ITM is getting bad results from the Cinnamon API, I will have to figure out a less easy way to handle it. I've been aware of this issue for a while, but I appreciate the additional info.

Name: IcingTaskManager@json: Libreoffice base no preview of forms and tables
Comment_Body: I think I found a 1. small work around more by coincidence. In the file  "/usr/share/applications/Libreoffice" I changed  "StartupWMClass=libreoffice-startcenter" to "StartupWMClass=libreoffice".  Consequence is: 1) The ODB is correctly shown with window and sub window                             2) All further LO docs (odb, ods, odt) are  shown in one group                             3) The name of the group is the name of the  last opened window After several restarts of cinnamon and also system, it seems to be stable.  For me personal this seems to be perfect.  But it is also a little bit "gamble solution". I am not really firm in  Linux systems (2014 XP changer). My thing is to do small productivity tools based on commercial and non  commercial software.  So please decide yourself, if I should close the item.  Perhaps my trial can help you finding a professional solution. Anyway I  would be glad to here if You found it.  kind regards Gert Hoffmann  Am 15.03.2017 um 19:57 schrieb Jason Hicks: > > Yes, it occurs when more than one LO app is open. I'm not sure how to  > work around it yet, and since ITM is getting bad results from the  > Cinnamon API, I will have to figure out a less easy way to handle it.  > I've been aware of this issue for a while, but I appreciate the  > additional info. > > — > You are receiving this because you authored the thread. > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub  > <https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/issues/214#issuecomment-286844994>,  > or mute the thread  > <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AZJah5VoPLvlOAEl5Oe2RtIg4mRTjsb3ks5rmDSigaJpZM4Mdt8p>. >

Name: IcingTaskManager@json: Libreoffice base no preview of forms and tables
Comment_Body: I think, my solution is not so far from the truth. Here another  interesting observation controlling the results  I. state of /usr/share/applicaions/libre*.desktop original StartupWMClass=libreoffice-startcenter StartupWMClass=libreoffice-base StartupWMClass=libreoffice-calc etc  I.a)graph1: result of previews and looking-glass after opening  odb file only: the 2 odb windows <untracked>, only one shown in preview  I.b) graph2: result of previews and looking-glass after opening  odb file an then 2  ods files 1 odb window <untracked>, 1 odb window (form) tracked to  libreoffice5.2-calc.desktop(!) all windows shown in preview but wrong alignment (logically)   To realise the following changes I had to restart the system    II. state of /usr/share/applicaions/libre*.desktop changed changed: StartupWMClass=libreoffice StartupWMClass=libreoffice-base StartupWMClass=libreoffice-calc  II.a) graph3: result of previews and looking-glass after opening  odb file only: the 2 odb windows tracked to libreoffice5.2.desktop(correct), both shown  in preview  II.b) graph4: result of previews and looking-glass after opening  odb file an then 2  ods files all windows tracked to libreoffice5.2.desktop(correct), all shown in 1  preview   Also from interest may be: the results of "xprop WM_CLASS" allways will asign correctly "WM_CLASS(STRING) = "libreoffice",  "libreoffice-odsorwhateverending" in all windows and in any *.desktop configuration.  Further: The preview alignment in the original configuration  "StartupWMClass=libreoffice-startcenter" only takes place at the moment, when a calc app is started together with odb. If I start  e.G. with a writer document, then odb all windows are <untracked>, nothing in preview. At the moment I open a  calc app, all windows are tracked and appear I tried several  alternative entries for StartupWMClass, but the only  one with acceptable result was "libreoffice"  I will not comment those observations. But I hope, it can help You.   Am 15.03.2017 um 19:57 schrieb Jason Hicks: > > Yes, it occurs when more than one LO app is open. I'm not sure how to  > work around it yet, and since ITM is getting bad results from the  > Cinnamon API, I will have to figure out a less easy way to handle it.  > I've been aware of this issue for a while, but I appreciate the  > additional info. > > — > You are receiving this because you authored the thread. > Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub  > <https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/issues/214#issuecomment-286844994>,  > or mute the thread  > <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AZJah5VoPLvlOAEl5Oe2RtIg4mRTjsb3ks5rmDSigaJpZM4Mdt8p>. >

Name: IcingTaskManager@json: Libreoffice base no preview of forms and tables
Comment_Body: I can confirm the workaround for my system. The problem mantained after upgrading to LO 5.2.6.2. Solution:  1) Search libreoffice X.X.desktop and libreoffice-startcenter.desktop  2) Open them and change " StartupWMClass=libreoffice-startcenter " to " StartupWMClass=libreoffice " 3) save and restart LO, problem solved

Name: No Context menu in Firefox 52.0 (64-Bit)
Comment_Body: > It's important to use a proper title when opening new issues. The title must be in the format spice name: simple description of the problem.  You tagged yourself @tcmger. You are obviously not the author of the applet. So to find out who this is you can read the spices website of this applet. https://cinnamon-spices.linuxmint.com/applets/view/269 It's said in the title.  The UUID is also there. You can use the UUID or the spices name. But you have to use it properly in the title, like it's said in the guidelines or like it looks on the other open issues.

Name: pa-equalizer@jschug.com: Not working b/c wrong access to `pulseaudio-equalizer` config files
Comment_Body: I'm confused. How do Cinnamon applets work on MATE?

Name: pa-equalizer@jschug.com: Not working b/c wrong access to `pulseaudio-equalizer` config files
Comment_Body: To make sure it's always compatible, you could check for the existence of the preferred directory, and then fall back to the other if it doesn't exist.

Name: pa-equalizer@jschug.com: Not working b/c wrong access to `pulseaudio-equalizer` config files
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause: I'm on the Mate Edition *GNU/Linux distribution* (which I guess is irrelevant here, I only have noted it for the sake of completion) but this bug report is about the Cinnamon *desktop environment*. Sorry about the confusion, I though that was obvious but I'm proven wrong. Hope this clarifies it ;-).  @collinss: Yeah, you're right. I guess checking first for `~/.config/pulse` and then fallback to `~/.pulse` if it doesn't exist would make more sense than any of the above. I wonder why I didn't think of that myself :-(. Thanks for the idea! I'll read how to make that check with Gio and get back with a PR.

Name: pa-equalizer@jschug.com: Not working b/c wrong access to `pulseaudio-equalizer` config files
Comment_Body:
Ok, this is a quick hack I've come up with, but I'm not happy about it, as it looks like an ugly one to me. Also, being a cjs newbie, I'm not sure I'm doing "the right thing" about error management (Should I `throw` instead of returning `undefined`? Or maybe something completely different?). Comments are more than welcome... ```diff @@ -1,6 +1,7 @@  const Lang = imports.lang;  const Signals = imports.signals;  const Applet = imports.ui.applet; +const Main = imports.ui.main;  const PopupMenu = imports.ui.popupMenu;  const GLib = imports.gi.GLib;  const Gio = imports.gi.Gio; @@ -9,7 +10,30 @@  const Gettext = imports.gettext.domain('cinnamon-applets');  const _ = Gettext.gettext;   -const CONFIG_DIR = GLib.get_home_dir() + "/.pulse"; +const UUID = "pa-equalizer@jschung.com"; + +const CONFIG_DIR = (function() { +    let homedir = GLib.get_home_dir(); + +    let paths = [ +        homedir + "/.config/pulse", +        homedir + "/.pulse", +    ]; + +    for (let i = 0; i < paths.length; i++) { +        let file = Gio.file_new_for_path(paths[i]); +        if (file.query_file_type(Gio.FileQueryInfoFlags.NONE, null) == Gio.FileType.DIRECTORY) { +            return paths[i]; +        } +    } + +    let e = "Pulseaudio's configuration directory not found! Applet won't work.
" + +        "Directories tried:
" + paths.join("
"); +    Main.criticalNotify(UUID, e, null); +    global.logError(e); +    global.logTrace(e); +    return undefined; +})();  const EQCONFIG = CONFIG_DIR + "/equalizerrc";  const EQPRESETS = EQCONFIG + ".availablepresets";  const PRESETDIR1 = CONFIG_DIR + "/presets/"; @@ -26,7 +50,7 @@      load: function() {          try {              GLib.spawn_command_line_sync("pulseaudio-equalizer interface.getsettings"); -            this._monitor = Gio.file_new_for_path(EQCONFIG).monitor(null, null); +            this._monitor = Gio.file_new_for_path(EQCONFIG).monitor(Gio.FileMonitorFlags.NONE, null);              this._monitor.connect("changed", Lang.bind(this, function(self, file, otherFile, eventType) {                  if (eventType == Gio.FileMonitorEvent.CHANGES_DONE_HINT) {                      this._configChanged(); @@ -42,7 +66,7 @@      },      save: function() {          try { -            let out = Gio.file_new_for_path(EQCONFIG).replace(null, false, null, null); +            let out = Gio.file_new_for_path(EQCONFIG).replace(null, false, Gio.FileCreateFlags.NONE, null);              out.write_all(this._rawdata.join('
'), null);              out.close(null); ```

Name: pa-equalizer@jschug.com: Not working b/c wrong access to `pulseaudio-equalizer` config files
Comment_Body: @faneca you could simplify it a lot more. Just do something like this:      -const CONFIG_DIR = GLib.get_home_dir() + "/.pulse";     +if (GLib.file_test(GLib.get_home_dir() + "/.config/pulse", GLib.FileTest.EXISTS) {     +    const CONFIG_DIR = GLib.get_home_dir() + "/.config/pulse";     +}     +else {     +    const CONFIG_DIR = GLib.get_home_dir() + "/.pulse";     +}

Name: pa-equalizer@jschug.com: Not working b/c wrong access to `pulseaudio-equalizer` config files
Comment_Body: `GLib.file_test()` is much simpler, thanks for that.  OTOH, well, as I said before, I'm not cjs expert, but I think I really can't do that: `const` is block-scoped, so after you exit the `if` block `CONFIG_DIR` would be `undefined` (didn't actually try, tho, so maybe I'm wrong about that). That's the reason I'm using a lambda (inline function). There are other options as well (defining it initially with `let` or `var` and, then, either assign it to a constant or just use it like that, for instance). I'll give it a spin and see what I find more appropriate.  I'm still looking for suggestions about what'd be the best thing to do with the error when no config directory is found.

Name: pa-equalizer@jschug.com: Not working b/c wrong access to `pulseaudio-equalizer` config files
Comment_Body: I've seen ```const``` used like that many times before. Unlike c, the only thing in js that's scoped is a function. [This](https://www.sitepoint.com/demystifying-javascript-variable-scope-hoisting/) explains it more.

Name: pa-equalizer@jschug.com: Not working b/c wrong access to `pulseaudio-equalizer` config files
Comment_Body: I'll try anyway when I find some time and let you know if it works ;-). But as of ECMAScript 2015 (6th edition), that article is no longer relevant. Extracted from there: > It’s worth noting that the upcoming [ECMAScript 6 will support block level scopes via the `let` keyword](http://www.sitepoint.com/preparing-ecmascript-6-let-const/).  More info also [here](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Statements/const) (see from lines 20 to 36 in the example).

Name: pa-equalizer@jschug.com: Not working b/c wrong access to `pulseaudio-equalizer` config files
Comment_Body: @faneca i just recommended you the usage of:  ``` GLib.get_user_config_dir() ```  instead of  ``` GLib.get_home_dir() + "/.config ``` https://developer.gnome.org/glibmm/stable/group__MiscUtils.html#gae517b931f4753abcd48adb2769a8fc48

I moved the changelog files back. You need to approve or decline my PR. The README file in your applets is now doubled. We can try to create a symbolic link. I notice that every one of my fetch and merges of upstream are showing up individually in the merge request. Is this a problem and is there a way of avoiding all this 'noise' whilst keeping everything up-to-date in my repositories? Is it worth producing some basic notes for those of us who are not full time users of Git and Github on the preferred way of using this repository?

Name: stopwatch@pcurtis.com Revert change that removed changelog.txt from applet folder
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @pdcurtis: I compiled in my repository's wiki some basic GitHub tasks. The section called [Contribute to someone's repository](https://github.com/Odyseus/CinnamonTools/wiki/GitHub-tips-&-tricks#contribute-to-someones-repository---source) is the method that I use to create pull requests for third party repositories. The section called [Working with big repositories](https://github.com/Odyseus/CinnamonTools/wiki/GitHub-tips-&-tricks#working-with-big-repositories---source) might also be of interest to you. It will allow you to check out just the parts of a repository that you want to work with and nothing else.

Name: stopwatch@pcurtis.com Revert change that removed changelog.txt from applet folder
Comment_Body: @pdcurtis   Don't worry too much about the effects of keeping up to date that you describe.  They can be avoided by rebasing, but also anyone able to commit to the repository in github has access to squash/merge facilities in addition to the standard merge.   That means a string of commits can be squashed down into just one commit when merging.

Name: stopwatch@pcurtis.com Revert change that removed changelog.txt from applet folder
Comment_Body: @Odyseus Thanks for sharing your documentation and to @brownsr for his information. Some of the information I already knew  but some of the ideas were knew and I will investigate and there were some additional insights on other areas.  I have also put together some documentation which I am happy to share but one should note it was mostly written before the changes to applet handling and is currently very egocentric as it was written for people starting to write applets and use use git to keep them under version control and for those who might want to contribute to my applets. It is at www.pcurtis.com/git.htm . Any comments or corrections are welcome.  @NikoKrause has also written a  a quick tutorial on How to add l10n/translation support to an applet at NikoKrause/CinnVIIStarkMenu#19 which may help fill in another missing area of documentation.  @ everyone: Where should discussions such as this and documentation be held - a closed PR is obviously not the ideal place! I have raised the problems of documentation several times before as the little that exists for applets is scattered and much is for earlier versions of Cinnamon with a few occasional words of wisdom in Segfault updating things and now the README.md for the spices repositories. I fear we are setting a barrier which is impossibly high for any new contributors and even existing authors.

Name: stopwatch@pcurtis.com Revert change that removed changelog.txt from applet folder
Comment_Body: In most cases the best place for Cinnamon documentation is here: https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/tree/master/docs/reference in Cinnamon itself. This is generally more up-to-date and can be viewed with Devhelp as long as you have the cinnamon-doc package installed. It probably would be a good idea to provide some docs here for working with, and submitting to, this repo.  In general your commits should not have all of those merge commits of upstream/master in them. If you want to pull upstream changes into a branch you are working on you should first update your master branch. `git checkout master` followed by `git fetch upstream` and `git merge upstream/master`.  Once you do that you can checkout your working branch branch and run `git rebase master`. That will cleanly add all of the upstream changes to your working branch without all the merge commmits.  Whenever you want to start working on a new branch you should first fetch and merge upstream master as described above before creating the branch.

Name: stopwatch@pcurtis.com Revert change that removed changelog.txt from applet folder
Comment_Body: https://github.com/NikoKrause/CinnVIIStarkMenu/issues/28

Name: stopwatch@pcurtis.com Revert change that removed changelog.txt from applet folder
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause Another nice tutorial. I am glad you show the mechanisms to ensure that the author is alerted to the PL and given the chance to comment.   Is it however better to tidy up the Branch after the Pull Request has been successfully merged and closed rather than keep every update in a separate branch by deleting it on the local copy and on origin? This can be done by:  ``` git push origin --delete <branch_name> git branch -D <branch_name> ```  Note1:  the forced delete is deliberate as it means that one does not need to merge the branch before deleting as it will eventually appear via the Pull Request from origin to upstream and then the pull from upstream to master. Note 2; For completeness I believe that when you are working on several machines you may need to purge the stale branch  on the other machines by something like `git fetch --all --prune` on each machine  This keeps your local master and upstream master looking more like upstream and it should have all your commits made to the branch in it via the successful PL including changes made during the merge cycle such as squashing which @brownsr indicated could take place.  This comment was placed here by accident and is now duplicated at NikoKrause/CinnVIIStarkMenu#28

Name: stopwatch@pcurtis.com Revert change that removed changelog.txt from applet folder
Comment_Body: @JosephMcc Thanks for the information on cinnamon documentation - I had not found that before and I have now installed cinnamon-doc and devhelp and the applet settings information is much more up-to-date on 3.2 than I had previously.   Some of the documentation and tutorials however need to be readily available especially if we expect to get any new authors - we are making it very difficult to get started. I would never have started if the situation had been like this a few years ago, even building on an existing applet as I did. I only started to use git when I had several applets and felt a formal version control was becoming essential and it was (and still is) a steep learning curve to climb.  I will explore the use of `git rebase` which I have largely ignored up till now, as a better way to clean up a branch prior to the PR.

Name: weather@mockturtl applet: [[Feature]] Added in the Functionality to Summon the Applet by Key Command
Comment_Body: Please change the commit message to include the name and/or uuid of the applet. This will help keep our history clean and easy to read. Also, you should include the same information in the title (we have about 200 applets) and reference the author's name in the main comment.  @mockturtl

Name: weather@mockturtl applet: [[Feature]] Added in the Functionality to Summon the Applet by Key Command
Comment_Body: I'm sorry about that, @collinss; that's a fair point. The mentioned changes have been done.

Name: weather@mockturtl applet: [[Feature]] Added in the Functionality to Summon the Applet by Key Command
Comment_Body: I'm ambivalent about this feature.  I don't think I would use it myself, but I don't oppose it.  How does it interact with Cinnamon's key bindings? _(Settings -> Keyboard -> Shortcuts)_  I worry a bit that an applet shouldn't silently override a setting there.  Maybe this feature belongs in Cinnamon itself?

Name: weather@mockturtl applet: [[Feature]] Added in the Functionality to Summon the Applet by Key Command
Comment_Body: The biggest advantage is for mouseless usage, which is what I tend to lean towards.  Understandable; it will favor the applet that the key is bound to and, if you don't quit the applet, launch the application likewise attached to that key binding in Cinnamon's key bindings. It's a really valid point I hadn't thought of and I'm all for Cinnamon implementing a way to call applets via keyboard command. There just isn't any way I'm aware of, currently, for Cinnamon and having to suddenly switch to the mouse only for applets (when the largest boon of them, to me and why I use Cinnamon, is the settings/info. being right at your panel and not in a separate window to open and then close) was aggravating.

Name: weather@mockturtl applet: [[Feature]] Added in the Functionality to Summon the Applet by Key Command
Comment_Body: @mockturtl Cinnamon does not currently have a mechanism to make sure these hotkeys do not conflict with each other, though it probably should. Still, this is the intended method for adding hotkeys to applets. If you're worried about key binding conflicts, you could always set the default value to nothing(```""```), and then the user can set their own. Anyway, are you OK with this being merged now?

Name: weather@mockturtl applet: [[Feature]] Added in the Functionality to Summon the Applet by Key Command
Comment_Body: > Still, this is the intended method for adding hotkeys to applets.  :+1: LGTM  Thanks @WammKD!

Comment_Body: Actually it's against the guidelines of contribution to create a pull request for so many applets. But since it's only adding translation files, I think it's okay.  The Readme of this repo says:  > If the changes represent a bug fix, the PR can be merged. > If the changes represent a change in functionality, or in look and feel, or if their implementation could be questioned and/or discussed, the reviewer should leave the PR open and ask the author to review it.  This PR does not change the functionality of any applet. Also it doesn't change the look and feel. It solves issues for Croation speaking people. So it's some kind of a bug fix.  If one of the authors of these applets has a problem with the translation, he can create a PR, which deletes the file.  @muzena  It's crazy (in a positive way) how many applets you translated at once. Out of curiosity, how long did it take you?

Comment_Body: @NikoKrause  43 applets, about 3 days. It's not so hard since many of the same translated strings are repeated and are similar. I simply copy translated strings from translation memory.  If I was going to create for each PO file PR, I think it would take longer than the translation.

Name: Croatian translation for: 0dyseus@CustomCinnamonMenu, 0dyseus@Desktop…
Comment_Body: This probably shouldn't have been merged into xlets with active developers without their approval. That is another good reason for not allowing a PR that affects so many at once. IMHO, a dev shouldn't be forced to make a PR to remove changes they don't want.

Name: Croatian translation for: 0dyseus@CustomCinnamonMenu, 0dyseus@Desktop…
Comment_Body: I think I agree because this means applet authors branches will all have to be re-merged with the base repo again, which adds more inconvenience. I have to resolve a merge conflict.   I think moving the technical upstream *is* the problem. Its one thing to use a repo as a back end to host the contents of zip files, but having to do everything through git and not a simple zip uploader increased the complexity a lot, means most will be juggling repositories. I would have done this differently.

Name: Croatian translation for: 0dyseus@CustomCinnamonMenu, 0dyseus@Desktop…
Comment_Body: @jaszhix @JosephMcc @NikoKrause  I do not believe that multiple changes or any changes other than those Essential for a critical security fix should be made without consultation with the author (if active). This is what is in the Readme although I think that should be changed to emphasize the requirement for it being a critical or security nature before a PR is merged without consultation when there is an active developer.   The problem is that and changes can have unintended consequences and apparently 'helpful' and well intended changes made to my applets have actually removed functionality from five applets of my applets - some have been reversed for me but 5 are outstanding and I will probably have to create PLs to reverse them. Worse still is that I only discovered the changes by chance! This is a matter of Trust. If I can not trust that my own applets work as I wrote them (and as their documentation indicates they should work) who else will trust them.   As @jaszhix wrote I would have done this differently but there was no consultation before this was brought in but we now have to live with it and ensure that we all get the benefits the new system should bring but without losing existing applet writers and inhibiting any new writers from starting.  I am putting together some further thoughts which I guess are best raised as an independent issue as this is actually a good example of how cooperation should work and nothing I have said is intended to detract from the valuable work by @muzena - many thanks.

Name: Croatian translation for: 0dyseus@CustomCinnamonMenu, 0dyseus@Desktop…
Comment_Body: I still think more services could be integrated into the repository to restore some of the simpler functionality the zip uploader had. There could be an authenticated way for xlet authors to update their xlet - through the Spices website, and it could overwrite any changes. To do that the server would need to extract the zip, and open an automated PR that would be approved manually for malware checks. Maybe they can update their model to add a field indicating a user is trusted, then it would be automatically merged. Then on approval, it could trigger an event that would overwrite the existing zip file. This would prevent the need for maintaining our own fork, and making sure nothing is conflicting.  It could give some control back to the authors that want it, and preserve this repo as a back-end.  An example repository that has a bot doing this would be [jsDelivr](https://github.com/jsdelivr/jsdelivr). Also see [jsDelivr bot](https://github.com/jsdelivr/bot).

Name: Croatian translation for: 0dyseus@CustomCinnamonMenu, 0dyseus@Desktop…
Comment_Body: Hi,  First I'd like to say I appreciate the help of people who add translations and fix bugs and I want them to continue to do so without requiring the approval from the author. I think that's important and bug fixers should be empowered, just like authors themselves.  That said, if a mistake is made, it's also EXTREMELY important, we're able (and that includes the author via PR) to revert it. That's not possible if a PR spans across multiple spices.  For this reason I think this particular PR should have been rejected. I don't see any reason to revert it.... but it is hard to review, and if there was anything wrong in it, it would be VERY DIFFICULT for an author to revert the changes on his/her applet without reverting the whole thing.. assuming that's possible.  Now, on the workflow itself... I've talked about it a lot already, both on github and internally.  > I do not believe that multiple changes or any changes other than those Essential for a critical security fix should be made without consultation with the author (if active).   Changes should be small and modular, I think we strongly agree on that.  Bug fixes in general, and that includes missing or outdated translations, or changes required as a consequence of changes happening in Cinnamon, or missing core features (highlighting, integration..etc) should be accepted.  > This is what is in the Readme although I think that should be changed to emphasize the requirement for it being a critical or security nature before a PR is merged without consultation when there is an active developer.  I disagree. If something is broken and a fix is provided, the interest of the user lies in it being merged.  > The problem is that and changes can have unintended consequences and apparently 'helpful' and well intended changes made to my applets have actually removed functionality from five applets of my applets - some have been reversed for me but 5 are outstanding and I will probably have to create PLs to reverse them.   That happens everywhere, but if we can help with that or if there's a case we don't understand, I'd like to know more about this so we can get the opportunity to think about it. Can you explain what happened in details here?  > Worse still is that I only discovered the changes by chance! This is a matter of Trust. If I can not trust that my own applets work as I wrote them (and as their documentation indicates they should work) who else will trust them.  That's a workflow issue is it? You can see the git history for your spice.. I don't understand how you wouldn't be able to see that.  In regards to trust, think of it from another point of view. We're the ones distributing that spice. People do not download it from you, they install a Cinnamon spice. When it doesn't work, they think Cinnamon doesn't work. If they report a bug and we think it's important we want to be able to fix it.  > As @jaszhix wrote I would have done this differently but there was no consultation before this was brought in but we now have to live with it and ensure that we all get the benefits the new system should bring but without losing existing applet writers and inhibiting any new writers from starting.  It's never nice to lose people and I completely understand your point of view. We've changed things from a real 3rd party collection of applets to something tightly controlling and which removes a lot of power from authors, and you said, it came out of the blue without consultation. I completely understand where you're coming from, and I also understand why some people prefer to leave.  This was necessary though and it's a huge improvement long term for Cinnamon and Cinnamon users, even if we lose quality spices in the process.  We're losing active devs who drive the development of their spices in isolation, some of them really good spices. We're also opening up and making it easier for other people to bug fix and contribute though. Look at all these translations, we'd never have seen that on so many spices before. And when the time comes to add new features into Cinnamon we'll be able to add support to all spices as well, ourselves, and that's a huge improvement as well.  In regards to consultation, it was brutal and I'm sorry and it had to be done in secrecy. You might remember that uploading was closed down temporarily before the new workflow was ready. We talked about it for weeks internally but I couldn't leak the info. I don't know if you're aware of it, but we're targeted specifically and in terms of security Cinnamon Spices were a huge Achilles Heel. We're quite lucky nobody used it to upload malicious code, it was a catastrophe waiting to happen. After we were targeted and this security hole was identified, this change of workflow had to happen urgently and it's a huge relief to see it implemented.

Name: Croatian translation for: 0dyseus@CustomCinnamonMenu, 0dyseus@Desktop…
Comment_Body: @clefebvre Thanks for the clarifications,in particular the reasoning behind the changes had to be brought in. As far as the changes to 5 of my applets, that was a multiple change #148 which was made to tidy up the placement of README.md and changelog files which in my case moved them all from the applet folder to a higher level. Unfortunately in my case I had my helpfiles and changelogs where accessible from within the applets from a sub-menu of the context (right click menu) so they could be read easily by the user without going to the repository or the cinnamon spices web site. I therefore have near identical README.md files in two places.  As far as not seeing the changes: That was because the Pull Request did not mention specific authors so I was not notified or the fact that it was moving changelog files as well as the README.md files which I had already put in the correct place so there was nothing to alert me to changes. At the time I was using expensive mobile or satellite connections so I was not looking in detail at the repositories unless there was a need so the first time I saw a problem was when I used the facility on my own applet and it did not work.   That sort of problem should not happen again as it is stressed in many places that the author must be mentioned by a @author to ensure he is notified and the dangers of multiple updates are now appreciated.  I like to think my applets are better documented than most but they also include a number of workarounds to get round some previous problems in cinnamon/mint/ubuntu which were beyond our control (for example see Cinnamon segfault issue 2835) where only those involved would understand the reasons for odd coding in my applet! There are many things I would do differently starting now but it would take a lot of time and testing to tidy up an old applet proven over many versions of Cinnamon and my fear is that risks outweigh the advantages. If it ain't broke don't fix it.  In my post above I also said I was putting together some further thoughts on Trust and I finally put some into your article on Segfault on Changes to cinnamon spices for developer and artists which I will repeat below.   I believe Applets need some form of score to replace the old user comments and ranking so a user knows he can trust that they will be useful, do what they say and not damage his system. I have put some thought into this over the last few weeks and to start discussion going I put forward the suggestion that some factors are * Author (identified and currently committed to development and maintenance – 3), * Documentation (description, rationale, help, version history etc – 3), * Status/Maturity (time available and number of releases, alpha, beta, released etc – 3), * Best Practice (Follows coding guidelines, commented or documented code so it can be followed and checked, consistency of interface with rest of Cinnamon, compatibility with a range of themes) – Difficult to give a max score as this will always be a moving target so say 2 * Independent Assessment/Support (Do other trusted people support, check code, test and vouch for functionality – ?? ). * Extra points perhaps for translation support (1) and other things I have not thought about.  The above are in approximate order of progression that a new author and applet might reasonably achieve. If the first five are given 3 points a score of over say 10 should give confidence for to any normal user to install and full house should be at least as trustworthy as system applet – lower scores imply that a user should do some preparation and be sure it is useful to them or wait until it is further developed. Who should do the initial scoring? Probably the author – I have found managing people they usually assess their own work lower than their managers and you need to trust the author in any case. Obviously the team would spot big anomalies and could ask the author to justify his score.  I also believe that _the first time_ an applet is installed it should be via the spices web site otherwise there is no information available to advise the user who may just experiment without realising that other software may need to be installed or that some applets are only relevant to certain hardware configurations.

Name: Slovenian translation for the Weather applet
Comment_Body: I started just recently. What was the LINGUAS file for?  It suffices to put the po files in a directory called po. The rest will be done automatically, when you install the applet from System Settings. Here's a small tutorial:  https://github.com/NikoKrause/CinnVIIStarkMenu/issues/19

Name: Slovenian translation for the Weather applet
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  I don't think that the LINGUAS file was ever needed. The Cinnamon code doesn't even contain any reference to a so named file (I searched only on linuxmint/Cinnamon repo and not on other packages).  For what I can grasp (barely) from [the documentation](https://www.gnu.org/software/gettext/manual/html_node/po_002fLINGUAS.html), the LINGUAS file is used to tell the system all available languages that will be installed. And then there is a [LINGUAS environment](https://www.gnu.org/software/gettext/manual/html_node/Installers.html#Installers) variable used to limit the languages that will be installed.  Anyway, Cinnamon doesn't care if there is a LINGUAS file or not (at least regarding xlets localizations). It will install all .po files found inside a po folder without exceptions.

Name: feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com: fix some variable warnings
Comment_Body: The merge is fine, I can just pull those changes before I create a pull with my current changes.   The updated settings would have been nice to know, I have been redoing the feed management stuff.   Question about the new settings api @collinss, and this is why I am currently limiting to 1 instance of the applet.   Currently, if you have multiple applet instances, when a user adds a new instance of the applet it creates a new "instanceid.json" settings file.   However, when you remove that instance the settings file goes away (including all the feeds). SO if you are on a laptop, and have the applet on a panel on a secondary screen and take the applet off, the applet no longer is visible (another bug, it really should move, temporarily, to a visible panel), and you remove that applet and then add it to the visible panel, all settings (feeds) are lost.  Will this be the same with the new settings api?  Reproduce using feeds as example:    1.  If you currently have any feeds back them up.   2.  Remove any instances of feeds   3.  Change max-instances to 3 (any number above 1) in feeds metadata.json   4.  Add feed to a panel   5.  Note that NNN.json is created in .cinnamon/configs/uuid   6.  Remove that instance   7.  Note that NNN.json is now gone, along with any feeds in it.  Note that if the panel on a detached monitor has the applet, you would have to either: 1. remove it and add it  2. add a new instance (which would have a new NNN.json file)   Moving is not an option without the monitor attached, as in the case of a laptop with a docking station.  So I have made upcoming changes to compensate for this current functionality.  ________________________________ From: Stephen Collins <notifications@github.com> Sent: Thursday, February 23, 2017 11:39 AM To: linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets Cc: Jason Jackson; Mention Subject: [linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets] feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com: fix some variable warnings (#154)   @jake1164<https://github.com/jake1164> Thought I'd run this by you before merging in case it interferes with your workflow.  FYI, I also submitted this pr<https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/pull/6303> to Cinnamon. When it's merged, it will allow you to move your feeds list to the settings api if you want.  ________________________________ You can view, comment on, or merge this pull request online at:    https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/154  Commit Summary    *   feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com: fix some variable warnings  File Changes    *   M feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com/files/feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com/applet.js<https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/154/files#diff-0> (18)   *   M feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com/files/feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com/feedreader.js<https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/154/files#diff-1> (6)  Patch Links:    *   https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/154.patch   *   https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/154.diff  — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub<https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/154>, or mute the thread<https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABv2K9pgkcAKrC0_JO1aPrQOPz3g7Xwkks5rfbZbgaJpZM4MKMpC>.

Name: feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com: fix some variable warnings
Comment_Body: I'm not entirely sure of the answer to your question without some testing, but I can tell you that I didn't touch that stuff when I reworked the settings. What you describe actually sounds like a bug that we saw before with settings being inappropriately removed for multi-instance applets. It was also causing some issues with my sticky notes applet. IIRC it was fixed within the last release or two.

The problem seems to be in the `_updateDevice()` function and errors show in the glass log file.  It looks as if it only worked if the interface was eth0 because that was set in the catch (e) at the end of the routine. It can be made to sort of work if the device is set to the interface one is using at that point. I will try to have a look over the next few days and in the limit I may be able to patch in the function I use in NUMA which does work and allows me to display the vnstati output.  I will also go back and checkout an earlier version from cinnamon-spices-applets.

Name: [scripts@paucapo.com] Added support for localizations, some minor fixes
Comment_Body: Hello, @muzena.  It looks perfect to me. :+1:  A couple of notes that will help you avoid errors in the future:  - Now that you created a new branch, you can create more branches to work on other applets if you need/want to. When you were working directly on master, you couldn't do that without waiting for a pull request to be merged. - After a pull request is merged, you can safely remove your branch (in this case, the *scripts@paucapo.com-added-localizations-and-fixes* branch). I repeat, **after the pull request is merged**. - Always create new branches from master. To make sure that you are in master, just `git checkout master` and then create your new branch.

Name: [scripts@paucapo.com] Added support for localizations, added Croatian localization, some minor fixes.
Comment_Body: Hello, @muzena.  I would like to suggest to you a couple of things:  - Do not create a pull request until you finished making all changes to your fork. - When you finished all changes, group all commits into one before making the pull request. - I see that you are working directly on the **master** branch of your fork. Long story short, do not ever work on master. Create a new branch and work inside it. [Here are detailed steps](https://github.com/Odyseus/CinnamonTools/wiki/GitHub-tips-&-tricks#contribute-to-someones-repository---source) on how to do so. It will save you and the reviewers in here a lot of headaches. - The reviewers in here will most likely ask you to *squash* all your commits into one. That's is done with an *interactive rebase*. [Here is an explanation by @NikoKrause](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-themes/pull/50#issuecomment-279250370) on how to do that.  If you need help *in real time*, you can contact me on IRC. I'm always connected to the #linuxmint-help and #linuxmint-dev channels. Just send me a private message.

Name: [scripts@paucapo.com] Added support for localizations, added Croatian localization, some minor fixes.
Comment_Body: @Odyseus   In 0dyseus@PopupTranslator applet, I don't understand function of these lines:  Indent translation history data It allows to save the translation history data with indentation.

Name: [scripts@paucapo.com] Added support for localizations, added Croatian localization, some minor fixes.
Comment_Body: Hello, @muzena.  It's an standard feature of the [JSON object](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/JSON/stringify). In short.  This code...  ```javascript rawData = JSON.stringify(this._translation_history); ```  ...will produce this JSON (**NO** indentation).  ```json {"en":{"Loaded":{"d":"2017-01-01 13:10:10","sL":"en","tL":"en","tT":"Loaded"}}} ```  And this code...  ```javascript rawData = JSON.stringify(this._translation_history, null, "    "); ```  ...will produce this JSON (**WITH** indentation).  ```json {     "en": {         "Loaded": {             "d": "2017-01-01 13:10:10",             "sL": "en",             "tL": "en",             "tT": "Loaded"         }     } } ```  As the section were that setting is placed says, that option is only usefull for the applet developer for debugging purposes. As such, it should never be enabled on normal usage.

Comment_Body: I'll let you guys decide if you want this removed. There's a bug where the categories repeat, and may have to do with the height calculation being changed. I'm just trying to budget my time, but I'm not against it staying on the repo if someone wants to try to fix it.

Comment_Body: It don't think there is any reason to keep it if you're not going to maintain it. Except for the extra layout settings there doesn't seem to be a lot of difference between this and the stock menu applet.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: Files should be in files/$UUID, not files/.  A lot of things don't work with many of the themes. Some labels aren't even visible.  I'm also worried because we have "menu: consider adopting this layout (https://raw.githubusercontent.com/The-Panacea-Projects/Gnomenu/master/Screenshot.png), same as ours/mintmenu, only better." in our roadmap, so although the work done here helps a lot... we might end up integrating this or something very similar into Cinnamon itself.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: Yeah, I saw that, it actually gave me the idea to port it over. I wasn't sure if that was tentative or not, so I did it anyway (for fun). I was assuming the work might benefit Cinnamon, and maybe the project would borrow a few things. Whether it does or not, I find the features helpful and think its worth publishing. If Cinnamon switches to this or something similar, I don't see it being any different than the many other forks of the current default menu applet.  Which labels aren't showing? I replaced most of the classes with the ones the default menu applet uses. I tested this on the Linux Mint theme, Minty-Y/Darker, and a handful of themes from spices.  Edit: I see the grid labels are getting cut off by the bottom pane when you scroll all the way down. I'll look at it later today.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: logout, restart and apps/places in listview.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: Hello, evrybody.  @jaszhix: Don't leave files/folders inside the **files** folder other than the actual xlet folder. It's known to break xlet installation. You should also change the folder structure of your other xlets.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: This is actually kind of confusing. When this repo was created that was the structure my applets were already in, and I haven't had anyone tell me their installation broke in this way. I see they just recently changed the documentation here. I will update those applets' folder structures when I need to update those applets again.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: The logout/restart buttons are icon-only, but their labels appear in the selected app box. In the apps/places - you mean the container for the list of apps? These are all St.ScrollView containers, and they can all be scrolled to reveal more of the list. If you, or someone else, could elaborate with a screenshot, maybe one that doesn't contain any sensitive files (this can read recent files if the privacy option is enabled in Cinnamon).  I have a busier weekend ahead, so I might not get to this as soon as I thought, but we'll see. I'll mark it [WIP] and Mint devs can feel free to amend this if it helps it get merged.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: > The presence of this UUID directory, inside of files/ isn't actually needed by Cinnamon (as Cinnamon creates it if it's missing), but it is needed to guarantee a proper manual installation (i.e. when users download the ZIP from the Cinnamon Spices website).  @NikoKrause This is the line that confused me...  > The UUID/files/ directory has to be "empty", which means that it should contain ONLY the UUID directory. Else the spice won't be installable through System Settings.  It seems like cinnamon-settings installations don't suffer from this and its only for manual installations - which seems like its normally for developers anyway. I haven't had any trouble explaining this to people on the ITM repo as far as manual installation.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: If you have all your files in the files folder there's no problem. But if your metadata.json and applet.js files are in files/UUID and you have some files in the files folder except UUID, then you get the install problem.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: Good going, a very interesting looking applet.  My immediate thought on opening it was 'what are these additional entries in the column on the left'.  I soon realised that they are similar to the favourites bar in the standard menu, with additional mode switching buttons above.  That made me realise just how well the standard menu hid complexity by using a few icons in contrast to the list format of the main menu categories.  You might like to think about how to reduce visual complexity for the user. What is in a favourites bar in the standard menu appears to be broken up into three here, with mode switches above, a list of favourites, and a second list at the bottom for power and lock functions.  It would be better to my eyes if these three elements were combined visually, perhaps. It wasn't hard to find the odd issue, but for a work in progress that's to be expected.  All in all this looks promising.  If you can make the complex twiddles in the user interface disappear and so simplify it visually then that would be even better.  I liked the way that the favourite apps can appear as a category.  But using this gives the same information as in the column to the left, which looked odd. If you have the favourite apps as a menu category do you also need them listed to the left ? I imagine there is an icon missing, as the mode switch button to the left of the list/grid mode switch came up blank for me.  Happy to do some more detailed testing when you would find that helpful.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: Yeah, this is mostly a representation of Gnomenu in its current state, with a few features reliant on GNOME Shell APIs either removed (workspace thumbnails based on Main.overview), or commented out (frequently used app list).   To me as a developer and power user, this currently suits my needs. I could see the UX for most people being improved in the ways you suggested, which is definitely interesting to think about. I agree the current default applet is very good, and I've used it for a long time. I think condensing some of these elements and making the interface's features more obvious is a good first step in that direction.  As far as Cinnamon integration, if it makes you feel better, I ported it with a less opinionated work flow and use of libraries, in case it is used as a base for other projects. Its not exactly adhering to Mint's style guide, but its basically there if you format it to four space indentation.  Edit:  > If you have the favourite apps as a menu category do you also need them listed to the left ?  The default option for the left column is Favorites, but I switched it to Places - for some reason I thought it was the default option. It could be, and I goofed up the conversion of the schema to JSON settings. (Edit: Yep) My guess is one feature (toggling the left column between favorites/places) came before the other when the original version was being developed, and the redundancy happened.  As for the missing icon on the startup apps display toggle, I haven't experienced that. The screenshot I posted represents what it looks like for me consistently.  > Happy to do some more detailed testing when you would find that helpful.  Thanks! Anytime is okay, and I will catch up with you later if I'm busy.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: Changes:  - Change default value for shortcuts-label to false. This setting toggles whether or not the far left column shows labels alongside the places or favorites icons. This will default to false for now so there is less text clutter.   - Edit note: This is an option I added myself because I like seeing a labeled list of my filesystem bookmarks and drives. - Re-comment places/favorites button, as it was only uncommented from the original version for experimentation. - Remove toggleCategoryWorkspaceMode  …Reimplementing this feature in Cinnamon would require including several versions of files from GNOME Shell's imports.ui, which would involve hacking global objects - out of this project's scope. - Remove hide-panel-menu setting as it is reliant on a removed feature over an unsupported API - Fix list/grid toggle button not re-rendering the app list view - Revert menu-favorites-box class on PanelMenuButton.bottomPane - Revert changing of default for shortcuts-display  Edit: In case you're curious, GNOME Shell uses [this](https://developer.gnome.org/shell/stable/shell-shell-app-usage.html) to query frequent apps.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: [This line](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/pull/132/commits/034f9eb7de1244179814dd69553be39aa5b88565#diff-3d760011bd6bd4759c1811b03baf0b5fL4219) was removed because it caused an extra gap on the right of the menu button on the panel.   The menu in PanelMenuButton (subclassed from PanelMenu.Button) is [overridden](https://github.com/jaszhix/applets/blob/034f9eb7de1244179814dd69553be39aa5b88565/Cinnamenu%40json/files/Cinnamenu%40json/applet.js#L1016) with the menu from its parent callee class, CinnamenuButton (subclassed from Applet.TextIconApplet like the default applet), so PanelMenuButton's actors are being added to the stage that way.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: Issues with the latest version:  - The places/bookmarks to the left are coming up with very small icons.  The only place I can see what each corresponds to is at the bottom right of the whole menu.  That's a long way to look across for a description and makes mouse control a bit awkward.  - Not sure what the criteria to appear in the places/bookmarks list are.   - There are missing icons for toggle startup apps view, restart, logout user and preferences (bottom right) - Some of the favourite apps are coming up with '-' on the line underneath them - I can't see what the 'Bookmarks' button does.  All I can see it doing is blanking out the menu when I press it. - There is a lot of space to the right in list view. Perhaps the control toggles and search bar can be moved left to allow this to be closed down ? - The search functionality appears to be searching the applet names fine, but is not bringing up things using the description.  The word 'document' gets very different results in this menu compared to the default menu, for example - 'startup apps view' is strangely titled. It appears to toggle between all applets and the favourites. I'd be tempted to remove it, as the way that the favourites appear as the first category makes them easy to locate, so I can't see that a way to reduce the applet list to just the favourites adds anything.  The main menu functionality seems to work really well. Performance is nice and snappy.  I'm not convinced about the design choice to put a variable length list of places/bookmarks to the left, the way the default menu adds it as a category seems more intuitive as it means that the location and the full description are visually nearby.    Progressing well :)

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: > The places/bookmarks to the left are coming up with very small icons. The only place I can see what each corresponds to is at the bottom right of the whole menu. That's a long way to look across for a description and makes mouse control a bit awkward.  Yeah, that's why I gave them labels. You're right, we may want to kill that column and move it to the category list.  > Some of the favourite apps are coming up with '-' on the line underneath them  This is actually a feature, but its not obvious what it means. It indicates the app is running. I couldn't find a class for a small indicator dot so its just hard coded at color #FFF for now.  > There is a lot of space to the right in list view. Perhaps the control toggles and search bar can be moved left to allow this to be closed down ?  I like that idea.  > The search functionality appears to be searching the applet names fine, but is not bringing up things using the description. The word 'document' gets very different results in this menu compared to the default menu, for example  I carried over Icing Menu's search method over (uses [this](https://github.com/miguelmota/knuth-morris-pratt/)), because I found sometimes I would get the wrong results when searching the default way. Like searching for "settings" brings up everything but settings. What I think is needed though is prioritizing the name in the order of the search results, and give exact matches a higher score, and concatenate the remaining results matched by description behind it.  > 'startup apps view' is strangely titled. It appears to toggle between all applets and the favourites. I'd be tempted to remove it, as the way that the favourites appear as the first category makes them easy to locate, so I can't see that a way to reduce the applet list to just the favourites adds anything.  I agree, it seems a bit unnecessary and there's a bit of a lag if it opens with "All applications" because it has to render the biggest list on init, which isn't likely what the user will be wanting to see, looking through a huge list (not me anyway).   > There are missing icons for toggle startup apps view, restart, logout user and preferences (bottom right)  This is not what I'm seeing. So to make sure we're on the same page, I created a quick diagram.  ![menu_diagram](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6859057/23101192/200e444c-f653-11e6-8a45-f91a31acd11c.png)  In case its not clear on the small icons issue, I am going to increase their default size. Or maybe purge some of these settings.  Thanks for the feedback.  Edit: Another thing I want to do is re-add the context menu, and I'm wondering if there's a way to fake a popup on a popup with the z-index property? If not, any suggestion on an intuitive way to do this in a grid?  Edit 2: What do you guys think about creating a column right of the application list, that displays the context menu options when an app is right clicked? This would be after removing the far left column so it doesn't get too wide. We could either expand the menu when this happens, or shrink the app list container.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: I suspect the missing icons are simply because you have additional icons on your computer that are not in the standard set, perhaps you have installed various additional  gnome packages in the course of the development.  The restart button may not be necessary, as pressing shutdown calls up the dialog that chooses between options.  Logout in your app uses 'user-logout-symbolic', logout in the standard app uses 'system-log-out'.  I imagine I would find the same if I investigated the other missing icons. The standard applets are in the Cinnamon repository under files/usr/share/cinnamon/applets if you want to search them for the icon names they are assuming to be there.  I hadn't spotted the right click menu was missing.

Subclass CategoryListButton, GroupButton with PopupMenu.PopupBaseMenuItem Remove height on cinnamenu-categories-workspaces-scrollbox Remove startup apps display Move recent and bookmarks buttons to category list  Icon issue is fixed.

But the main menu stuff is fast, clean and uncluttered.  Nice.  I've limited time during the working week to test things, but I'll do my best if you put further changes through.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: Thanks for the help. I cleaned up some of the CSS so its more cross-theme compatible on my repo. I'll push more changes here when I have more, so there's not a ton of commits from me here. Or I could close this and reopen it with a squashed commit. I'm still thinking about how I want to handle the context menu - I copied over the base context menu class from the default applet, but seems like it will have to be integrated differently because I'm using different kinds of actors for the menu items.  Edit:  I think I fixed the category button getting stuck with the CSS update yesterday. The bookmarks work like the other category buttons, it just needs to be hovered over to show its contents. I noticed it will only index bookmarks at the root level of the bookmark tree structure in each browser, so if you neatly organize all of them in folders none will show. This can possibly be fixed, or maybe even list the folder structure of bookmarks, but would probably take some work.  ![menu_bookmarks](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6859057/23193710/ecffd6c8-f86f-11e6-8914-1b6c01a75d83.png)

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: Seeing this image makes me realise a little more about why I am not seeing the bookmarks.  I had been assuming bookmarks as in the nemo bookmarks, but I think those are actually covered by 'places' above.  From the image and the original link I can now see that browser bookmarks are what is intended to show up.  I saw nothing.  That made me assume there must be some other indexing package you have installed in order for this to work. The link you posted to gnomenu seems to indicate that gir1.2-gda-5.0 is what is needed, so I tried that, and it worked albeit somewhat partially. It showed firefox bookmarks, and Chrome bookmarks.  It seems not to show Chromium or Opera bookmarks. I've only tried these four browsers. I needed a full restart for the bookmarks to be indexed, logout and in was not sufficient.  A really helpful facility though.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: @brownsr Ah yeah, that's a good point. I forgot about the Gda requirement - ITM uses it as well for Firefox bookmarks. I still need to test Chromium and Opera, and maybe I'll track down the problem.

Name: Add Cinnamenu@json
Comment_Body: Changes:  Add autoscroll, grid icon size scaling, theme compatibility fixes Create unique bookmark arrays Add a spacer to pad the toggle button from the search box Fix chromium bookmark indexing, recurse bookmark structures Add category icon size setting, theme introspection Fix context menu behavior Add overlay context menus for grid view Add context menu functionality Add context menu functionality Move CinnamenuButton, CinnamenuPanel, buttons classes into separate files Rename PanelMenuButton to CinnamenuPanel Fix list view app labels not appearing on LM theme, fix category button hover CSS, narrow container width  I tested it on 20+ themes and I'm not seeing any issues. I think its good to go for a 1.0 release, unless someone finds a crippling bug.  * Todo:     * Add keyboard support.     * Clean up and organize existing localization files, and add new translations.

Comment_Body: This isn't a bug in the applet. It's the way cinnamon handles fullscreen notifications. Hiding notifications when fullscreen is intentional at the moment. Playing the sound effect when they don't show probably shouldn't happen though.   https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/issues/1646
