Name: SpicesWebsite - Can we add a Downloaded (or maybe Installed) statistic like other app stores
Comment_Body: I think there's something planned to use something different than stars.  But you should file this issue here https://github.com/clefebvre/cinnamon-spices/issues

Name: SpicesWebsite - Can we add a Downloaded (or maybe Installed) statistic like other app stores
Comment_Body: @jake1164 the problem with number of stars is that you have to have an account with the spices website to rate. This means that a relatively small number of people are actually rating them. Also, having any sort of ranking system like that means that any new applet that might be better gets buried under the older applets that have accumulated stars over a much longer period of time. These have been problems for quite a while. Using social media to track recent likes solves both of those issues. In the end, I think it will be much more helpful than the stars ever will be.  Downloads would be good, though.

Name: localipswithsettings@edaubert: new applet
Comment_Body: A few things.  You should add an icon.png besides info.json.  The description in metadata is quite long. It should be a short description of what the applet does. The Rest can be added to README.md, e.g. that It's a fork of an applet, etc.  Regarding your issue. I think there's a function  `on_applet_removed_from_panel` Maybe that's something you searched for. It's used for example here https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/CinnVIIStarkMenu%40NikoKrause/files/CinnVIIStarkMenu%40NikoKrause/3.2/applet.js

Name: localipswithsettings@edaubert: new applet
Comment_Body: Hi,  Thanks for you remarks. I have tried to take them into account.  I have added the missing icon, and create a README.md.  Thanks for ```on_applet_removed_from_panel``` I had missed it before. I update the code to take it into account.  Regards.

Name: localipswithsettings@edaubert: new applet
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @edaubert: In the future, a better way to "clean up" the functions is as follows:  First, declare a property on applet **_init** that will be used to "store" the function:  ```javascript this.myFunctionId = 0; ```  Then "store" the function:  ```javascript if (this.myFunctionId > 0) {     Mainloop.source_remove(this.myFunctionId);     this.myFunctionId = 0; }  this.myFunctionId = Mainloop.timeout_add_seconds(this.settings.getValue("refreshInterval"), Lang.bind(this, function refreshTimeout() {     this.refreshLocation(); })); ```  And then add the code to do the "clean up" on applet removal:  ```javascript on_applet_removed_from_panel: function () {     if (this.myFunctionId > 0) {         Mainloop.source_remove(this.myFunctionId);         this.myFunctionId = 0;     } } ```  By the way, you can simply use **this.refreshInterval** instead of **this.settings.getValue("refreshInterval")**. The **Settings** module takes care of that.

Name: localipswithsettings@edaubert: new applet
Comment_Body: I understand the use of `source_remove` but I am not sure this is enough.  What about concurrency ?  Are you sure that it is not possible to have concurrency on the execution of `refreshLocation` and `on_applet_removed_from_panel` ?  Because otherwise, it may happen that the `source_remove` is applied on the running function and so a new one will be added.

Name: localipswithsettings@edaubert: new applet
Comment_Body: @edaubert concurrency is not an issue within Cinnamon. For better or worse, Cinnamon is single-threaded, and so there is only one piece of code running at any given time. The Mainloop.timeout_add_seconds will wait the specified time, and then try to run as soon after that as possible, but it will wait until the current line of code has finished executing first.

Name: localipswithsettings@edaubert: new applet
Comment_Body: Ok. Thanks for the explanations.  I made the changes proposed by @Odyseus.

Name: localipswithsettings@edaubert: new applet
Comment_Body: @edaubert Sorry, I've got a few more things. * README.md is in uuid/files/uuid/. In order for this to show in your applet page on the spices website, it should be in uuid/ along with your info.json, icon.png, and screenshot.png * Line 101 in applet.js uses a synchronous call. This is usually not a problem as most such commands finish very quickly, but it does freeze Cinnamon while it is running (that's how synchronous calls work). If the command takes longer than normal for some reason, the freezes will become noticeable to the user and could even hang the ui indefinitely if the script fails to terminate. You should change this to an async call instead. If you need an example of how to do this, I did the same thing with one of my applets [here](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/commit/9d81d620befd5f757aae30f0a8af35caecef6f5d). * In metadata.json, you have an extra argument ```"dangerous": true``` which probably shouldn't be there. It is autogenerated by Cinnamon when the applet is added, and is used to identify to the user any applets that have calls that are potentially "dangerous" (have been known to cause freezes/crashes/etc). In your case it is set to true because of the synchronous call I mentioned in my previous point. It would probably be best to just remove that argument from your pr entirely.

Name: Icing Task Manager: Update to 4.3.3
Comment_Body: Since we talked about binaries in another pull request. `.mo` files are not really binary files, but you can't really check/view them and they are created from `.po` files, so no need for them to be there actually. Can you remove them please? We'll also remove them from other applets as well.

Name: Icing Task Manager: Update to 4.3.3
Comment_Body: No, those binaries are not executable. I'm sorry, that doesn't make sense. They're needed for localization to work.

Name: Icing Task Manager: Update to 4.3.3
Comment_Body: they are created automatically from .po files,

Name: Icing Task Manager: Update to 4.3.3
Comment_Body: This applet [manually handles them](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/blob/master/IcingTaskManager%40json/src/applet.js#L471). We've been over this before already, this was written before the language tools were available, and I don't want to use them at the moment.

Name: Icing Task Manager: Update to 4.3.3
Comment_Body: I think this should be merged, because I think opinionated handling of localization would represent a shift in policy, and should require communication to developers ahead of time. ```mo``` files are binaries in the same sense that images are binaries. The other applet you reference was using ```GLib.spawn_sync``` on its included binaries. So, not comparable at all.

Name: Icing Task Manager: Update to 4.3.3
Comment_Body: I'm not speaking for Linux Mint, but for myself. I as a reviewer can't see what's in the .mo file. I can look at an image file though.  Your manual way of handling this is way too complicated. All you have to do is to store the .po files in a directory called po. Done. Nothing else.  If you install your applet through System Settings, Cinnamon checks for the po directory and creates the .mo files in the needed path.  I don't know what's the opinion of others. Better ask @collinss

Name: Icing Task Manager: Update to 4.3.3
Comment_Body: Its a small update, and I think if this is a requirement we should update it when you remove the ```mo``` files from all the other repos, but until then I think it should be merged.

Name: Icing Task Manager: Update to 4.3.3
Comment_Body: By the way, if you cd into ```src/locale```, run ```msgfmt -cv -o ./mo/ru.mo ./ru.po```, the mo binaries will be identical. The de.mo file was supposed to be included in the last release, and I accidentally only committed it into the src directory. I agree your suggestion sounds more ideal, but perhaps for next time.  Edit: To be clear, I was confused at first because mo binaries were being compared to executable binaries. I don't think they are a security risk. If it was presented as a suggestion and not  a rule breaker, I probably would have been less firm about it.

Name: Icing Task Manager: Update to 4.3.3
Comment_Body: I think it is a good policy to have nothing in this repository that cannot be reviewed on Github - not just for security reasons, but for maintainability. Applet developers are a particularly transient bunch (as a whole, not individually). We never know who will decide to abandon their applets, and we need to be able to maintain it if that happens. We can't afford to have exceptions, either.  Now I realize that .mo files are a little different than an executable binary, but since we have a mechanism to generate the .mo files at install time, I would prefer to use that moving forward.  That being said, I agree that we can't just implement new rules without warning and expect everyone to bend over backwards to comply immediately. I don't think it's unreasonable to give some time before this policy on .mo files needs to be enforced. In the mean time, I will add this to the readme, and we'll be cleaning up the other applets that have binary data. I will also merge this PR, but please look into making the change at your earliest convenience. If you need some help, or guidance, don't hesitate to ask either.

I close issues, if they don't have the applets name in the title at first place. I don't know if we need to be strict, if the applets uuid is in brackets or not.

And the not: You are storing .mo files in the localization. Probably for the localization script, which copies the .mo files to the needed directories? It's not needed to store these files. If you need a script I would suggest to change it. The command `cinnamon-json-makepot -i` used in the same directory as metadata.json does create .mo files on the fly out of the .po files.  I think you have to rename the `locale` folder to `po` for this. But I'm not sure about that.

Name: Update ITM to 4.3.2, add README.md and ES2015 source files to Icing Menu, Icing Window Saver #26
Comment_Body: I've used jsgtk, its a really neat library. It works for CJS as well after I submitted a PR, and the author implemented it. It does however only fake the Node environment, and any code that needs to be modified to run for CJS, won't work with it either - it adds the module system, and syntactic sugar.   I also have made a few Electron apps for work and as side projects - its a really convenient way to create standalone apps if you are familiar with browser and node JS. The main thing Node and G/CJS have in common is they're wrappers for native C bindings, and you can do a lot of powerful things natively with them. I think if more distributions installed Node by default like they do Python, you would see more Node integration in the Linux free desktop ecosystems.

Name: axos88@countdown-timer: add timer notifications applet
Comment_Body: A couple of notes: 1. The name seems long to me. That's no problem per se, if you want to have it this way. But if somebody adds an issue or pull request, the title will probably contain only your uuid ;) I'd suggest timer-notification@axos88, because it's obvious that this is an applet and that it is for Cinnamon. But it's up to you. 2. The loadOptions function looks strange. Is it on purpose? 3. Last-edited in metadata.json is added automatically as far as I know. I don't know, if this will cause problems, when you add it manually. 4. What's the purpose of "repo" in info.json? Is it used somewhere? Haven't seen it before. You can use "website" in metadata.json instead, to link to your applets website.  And last but not least: My biggest concern is the uuid you are using in metadata.json. It should match with the directory name of the applet. Else it will fail to load, if I remember correctly.

Name: feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com: cannot update
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause.  It seems to work normally now. I can install and update the feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com applet from System Settings.  It's worth noticing the following: - In my Cinnamon 3.0.7 LM 18 system I had the feeds@jonbrettdev.wordpress.com applet installed manually. It was still impossible to update it from the applets manager. I had to remove the applet and delete its settings folder and then I was able to install it from the applets manager. - In my Cinnamon 3.2.8 LM 18.1 system I hadn't this applet installed. After refreshing the applets cache, the applet installed at once without any errors. I removed it and re-installed it several times to test, and still no errors.  @jake1164  There is a typo inside the metadata.json file. It reads **max-instanceso** instead of **max-instances** (note the letter "o" in the former). This forces the applet to only allow one instance of it to be placed in a panel.  **P.S.:** Since the .gitignore file has been moved one level up, its content should be edited to point to the correct path (if needed).

Name: vboxlauncher@mockturtl - VMware VMs unable to start
Comment_Body: i have found the error it's located at the line 218 : Util.spawnCommandLine(CMD_VMPLAYER + " " + path) if the VM name has spaces it wont work as the command wont run due the termenal does not accept spaces in name, so i had added single quote before and after the path to be : Util.spawnCommandLine(CMD_VMPLAYER + " ' " + path + " ' ") now every thing runs smoothly :100:

Do you have any thoughts?

Name: StarkMenu: broken after update
Comment_Body: Either way, the StarkMenu is not maintained anymore. As far as I know it's broken since Cinnamon 2.6.   I forked it, but have not uploaded it on spices yet. You can install it manually in the meantime, if you want to: https://github.com/NikoKrause/CinnVIIStarkMenu

Name: StarkMenu: broken after update
Comment_Body: Well, the StarkMenu was working for me for some time. I don't know which version of Cinnamon I was using when I installed it first. (I was moving my /home folder with me since then, and I was occasionally doing updates of the applets).  So, what happened here: 1. I've read about how Cinnamon is stepping in, to do an intermediary between applet developers and users, to protect the users, etc. 2. I decided to update my applets. I have downloaded all the updates (they were automatically installed). 3. I restarted the cinnamon after that (ALT+F2, write 'r' and hit Enter) 4. StarkMenu started to be distorted (see 1st screenshot) 5. I downgraded the StarkMenu via my local backup & restarted cinnamon. It was again working now (see 2nd screenshot).  Here's the diff of the `old`(working) and `latest`(distorted) version (ignore the dates, please): ```diff --- old/applet.js	2016-03-19 19:13:16.000000000 +0100 +++ new/applet.js	2017-02-01 17:43:32.478946555 +0100 @@ -247,7 +247,7 @@ function TransientButton(appsMenuButton,  }    TransientButton.prototype = { -    __proto__: AppPopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype, +    __proto__: PopupMenu.PopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype,        _init: function(appsMenuButton, pathOrCommand) {          let displayPath = pathOrCommand; @@ -590,83 +590,8 @@ function TextBoxItem(label, icon, func,      this._init(label, icon, func, parent, hoverIcon);  }   -function AppPopupSubMenuMenuItem() { -    this._init.apply(this, arguments); -} - - - -AppPopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype = { -    __proto__: PopupMenu.PopupBaseMenuItem.prototype, - -    _init: function(text, hide_expander) { -        PopupMenu.PopupBaseMenuItem.prototype._init.call(this); - -        this.actor.add_style_class_name('popup-submenu-menu-item'); - -        let table = new St.Table({ homogeneous: false, -                                      reactive: true }); - -        if (!hide_expander) { -            this._triangle = new St.Icon({ icon_name: "media-playback-start", -                                icon_type: St.IconType.SYMBOLIC, -                                style_class: 'popup-menu-icon' }); - -            table.add(this._triangle, -                    {row: 0, col: 0, col_span: 1, x_expand: false, x_align: St.Align.START}); - -            this.label = new St.Label({ text: text }); -            this.label.set_margin_left(6.0); -            table.add(this.label, -                    {row: 0, col: 1, col_span: 1, x_align: St.Align.START}); -        } -        else { -            this.label = new St.Label({ text: text }); -            table.add(this.label, -                    {row: 0, col: 0, col_span: 1, x_align: St.Align.START}); -        } -        this.actor.label_actor = this.label; -        this.addActor(table, { expand: true, span: 1, align: St.Align.START }); - -        this.menu = new PopupMenu.PopupSubMenu(this.actor, this._triangle); -        this.menu.connect('open-state-changed', Lang.bind(this, this._subMenuOpenStateChanged)); -    }, - -    _subMenuOpenStateChanged: function(menu, open) { -        this.actor.change_style_pseudo_class('open', open); -    }, - -    destroy: function() { -        this.menu.destroy(); -        PopupBaseMenuItem.prototype.destroy.call(this); -    }, - -    _onKeyPressEvent: function(actor, event) { -        let symbol = event.get_key_symbol(); - -        if (symbol == Clutter.KEY_Right) { -            this.menu.open(true); -            this.menu.actor.navigate_focus(null, Gtk.DirectionType.DOWN, false); -            return true; -        } else if (symbol == Clutter.KEY_Left && this.menu.isOpen) { -            this.menu.close(); -            return true; -        } - -        return PopupMenu.PopupBaseMenuItem.prototype._onKeyPressEvent.call(this, actor, event); -    }, - -    activate: function(event) { -        this.menu.open(true); -    }, - -    _onButtonReleaseEvent: function(actor) { -        this.menu.toggle(); -    } -}; -  TextBoxItem.prototype = { -    __proto__: AppPopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype, +    __proto__: PopupMenu.PopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype,        _init: function (label, icon, func, parent, hoverIcon) {          this.parent = parent; @@ -674,7 +599,7 @@ TextBoxItem.prototype = {          this.icon = icon;          this.func = func;          this.active = false; -        AppPopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype._init.call(this, label); +        PopupMenu.PopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype._init.call(this, label);            this.actor.set_style_class_name('menu-category-button');          this.actor.add_style_class_name('menu-text-item-button'); @@ -682,7 +607,6 @@ TextBoxItem.prototype = {          //this.removeActor(this.label);          this.label.destroy();          //this.removeActor(this._triangle); -                 this._triangle.destroy();          this._triangle = new St.Label();          this.label_text = label; @@ -776,10 +700,10 @@ function AllProgramsItem(label, icon, pa  }    AllProgramsItem.prototype = { -    __proto__: AppPopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype, +    __proto__: PopupMenu.PopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype,        _init: function (label, icon, parent) { -        AppPopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype._init.call(this, label); +        PopupMenu.PopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype._init.call(this, label);            this.actor.set_style_class_name('');          this.box = new St.BoxLayout({ style_class: 'menu-category-button' }); @@ -966,13 +890,13 @@ function ShutdownMenu(parent, hoverIcon)  }    ShutdownMenu.prototype = { -    __proto__: AppPopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype, +    __proto__: PopupMenu.PopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype,        _init: function (parent, hoverIcon) {          let label = '';          this.hoverIcon = hoverIcon;          this.parent = parent; -        AppPopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype._init.call(this, label); +        PopupMenu.PopupSubMenuMenuItem.prototype._init.call(this, label);          this.actor.set_style_class_name('menu-category-button');          //this.removeActor(this.label);          this.label.destroy(); ```

Name: StarkMenu: broken after update
Comment_Body: @deekej  You must have "fixed" StarkMenu by yourself some months ago. This looks exactly like this Pull Request https://github.com/mintystark/starkmenu/pull/11, which has never been merged into StarkMenu.  > I've read about how Cinnamon is stepping in, to do an intermediary between applet developers and users, to protect the users, etc.  The change to the spices is pretty new. It will need some time, to get rid of most of the bugs. So far we haven't been able to test and fix all applets. There are over 200 applets. A lot of the applets are abandoned or doubled and some need to be fixed or removed. There's still some work to do. We still have to see, which applets are still in development by their authors. Which authors are still active or willing to jump on the bandwagon. E.g. Odyseus, jaszhix are very active. Others as mintystark are gone a long time ago.  As for StarkMenu it is abandoned quite some time. As I mentioned above, I suspect that you have fixed it on your own, by adding the pull request manually. It was never updated on spices though.  For example: The checkboxes "Show bookmarks and places" and "Show recent files" in the menusettings of your fixed/working StarkMenu are broken, right?  I would recommend CinnVIIStarkMenu. It will be available here very soon. Or you can test it manually, if you can't wait. I don't think StarkMenu will be fixed, if we have a working fork of it. Unless mintystark happens to reappear and fixes it (I doubt it).  So a lot of work is still to do. Help is always appreciated.  And thanks for the feedback. It helps to know, which applets are actually used and need to be fixed in priority :)

Name: StarkMenu: broken after update
Comment_Body: I recommend to use CinnVIIStarkMenu. It's a fork of the StarkMenu with many bug fixes and new features. It's now available on Cinnamon Spices Website, which means that it can be installed through System Settings > Applets > Available Applets (online)

Name: StarkMenu: broken after update
Comment_Body: > For example: The checkboxes "Show bookmarks and places" and "Show recent files" in the menusettings of your fixed/working StarkMenu are broken, right?  Yes, you're right. I just checked it, and I'm unable to disable those.  > I recommend to use CinnVIIStarkMenu. It's a fork of the StarkMenu with many bug fixes and new features.   Actually, I didn't know about the fork. Thanks for the info. I will try it whenever I have time. :)  Anyway, seems like the number of applets will be growing really fast soon (if it isn't already), because of all the abandoned applets and new forka appearing. Here I would suggest, sooner the better you should come up with some policy on how to deal with applets where developer is inactive and updated/active fork of it exits.  My suggestions would be to implement a way the old/inactive applets would be deprecated/obsoleted, and at some point removed from your "applets repository".

Name: weather@mockturtl: use correct function for custom css class
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  Using the **setCustomStyleClass** function directly as used by this PR will break the applet in all Cinnamon versions older that 3.2.x.  I use that function as follows to make it retro-compatible.  ```javascript if (typeof this.menu.setCustomStyleClass === "function")     this.menu.setCustomStyleClass("menu-background"); else     this.menu.actor.add_style_class_name("menu-background"); ```

Name: No colors on panel icons in weather@mockturtl
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @vpal & @NathanSalapat: Try enabling the symbolic icons option, wait a few seconds and disable it again. The same error happens if you use colored icons and want to switch to symbolics.  The problem is that, every single time that any of the applet's settings is modified, the weather data is downloaded from internet and the entire menu is re-built. And sometimes, the line 390 of the applet's code throws the following error:  ``` error weather@mockturtl#: TypeError: json.get_object_member(...).get_object_member(...) is null ```  That error *halts* the correct re-build of the weather menu.

Name: Added applet timeout@narutrey
Comment_Body: Hello, @NaruTrey.  Check your .pot file. Its header is malformed.  **Edit:** I see that you use custom scripts to generate your .pot files. In case that you didn't know, Cinnamon provides the command called **cinnamon-json-makepot** for that purpose. Run it from inside the applet's folder like this `cinnamon-json-makepot --js name-of-pot-file` and it will extract all strings from .js files, metadata.json and settings-schema.json

Name: Added applet timeout@narutrey
Comment_Body: I did not know about the utility `cinnamon-json-makepot`, thanks

Name: Added applet timeout@narutrey
Comment_Body: As Odyseus said. You don't need `generatePOT.awk` and `generatePOT.sh`. Open a terminal and go to the directory, where your `metadata.json` file is stored. Then type `cinnamon-json-makepot --js timeout@narutrey.pot` The pot file will be stored besides metadata.json and you can move it in the po directory. Or you can type `cinnamon-json-makepot --js po/timeout@narutrey.pot`. In this case the pot file in the po directory will be overwritten.  If you have updated your pot file, you can update your `ru.po` file with poedit.  1. Open your localized (translated) .po file in poedit. 2. Under “Catalog” top menu, select “Update from POT file…” menu item. 3. Select the newly downloaded .pot file and click Open in file dialog box. 4. Your files will merge and you will be shown a dialog with new and obsolete strings. 5. Proceed to translate the newly translatable strings. 6. Save and exit, your updated .po file is ready.  If you want to test your translation, then type in the same terminal (location of terminal must be again besides metadata.json) `cinnamon-json-makepot -i` This will install the po files in "~/.local/share/locale/"  Why is this line in your metadata: "localedir": "~/.local/share/locale"  And the title of this pull request says timeout@libnaru.so. Shouldn't it say timeout@narutrey?

Name: Added applet timeout@narutrey
Comment_Body: > And the title of this pull request says timeout@libnaru.so. Shouldn't it say timeout@narutrey?  You have a keen eye.  I made the necessary changes, now everything should be OK.

Name: Added applet timeout@narutrey
Comment_Body: What's the purpose of `localedir": "~/.local/share/locale` in metadata.json?  Everything else looks good to me. But I'd like, if someone else confirm this as well, since the whole process is still pretty new. I hope you'll understand.

Name: scripts@paucapo.com
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @NikoKrause & anyone that is willing to fix this applet.  The problem resides in the **filechooser** setting. In Cinnamon 3.2.x this setting type returns a file URI, not a path like it used to. The applet's code always expects a path.  I use a simple fix like the following: ```javascript if (/^file:\/\//.test(path))     path = path.substr(7); ```

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: I think we could add a CONTRIBUTING file, which says: # Reporting Bugs  It's important to use a proper title when opening new issues. The title must be in the format `spice name: simple description of the problem.`  Issues that don't follow this format will be closed.  https://help.github.com/articles/setting-guidelines-for-repository-contributors/   And add an Issue/pull request template, which reminds the user to notify the author: @AppletAuthor

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: I added a CONTRIBUTING template. It works for issues. Haven't tried with pull requests. Let me know.  @JosephMcc Do you think, we should also add an Issue/pull request template, which reminds the user to notify the author: @AppletAuthor  You can try the CONTRIBUTING template and let me know, if we should add this to the other spices repos.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: @NikoKrause You can add one for PR's. I haven't ever tried them. The best way to enforce it is to quit merging PR's that don't follow the commit message rules we lay out. You can ask for them to be fixed and only merge once they are.  With all the applets in one large repo some sort of organization should be enforced, imho.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @NikoKrause: The CONTRIBUTING.md file isn't a template *per se*. The CONTRIBUTING.md file is a file that should contain contribution guidelines. The *real template* for pull requests is a file called [PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md](https://help.github.com/articles/creating-a-pull-request-template-for-your-repository/).  The PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md file is *half useful* in my opinion. While the pull requests messages are important, the amount and organization of the commits in a pull request are even more important. Knowing this, the content of the PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md file will appear **after** all the commits where committed (pun intended) and **after** the contributor or author did the possible mess. This leads to reviews harder than they need to be and may even force contributors and authors to learn advanced GitHub methods (to fix the possible screw ups).  On the other hand, the [ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md](https://help.github.com/articles/creating-an-issue-template-for-your-repository/) file **it is absolutely needed and useful**. Because we can have super detailed guidelines on how to report errors, but the *bug reporters* are mostly end users. And the end users that [RTFM](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/RTFM) are an endangered species and counted with the fingers of one hand (LOL).  Speaking about guidelines. The current CONTRIBUTING.md file on this repository reads:  > The title must be in the format `spice name: simple description of the problem`.  It shouldn't be *only* xlet name the one specified, but the xlet UUID also. Why? Because there are several applets with similar name or even the exact same name. So, in my opinion, it should read:  > The title must be in the format **Spice name (Spice UUID): simple description of the problem**.  In my opinion, the ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file should be created ASAP and with the following content:  ```markdown     The title of this issue must be in the format **Spice name (Spice UUID): simple description of the  problem**.      @applet_author      ### Issue description     Describe your issue in detail.      ### Steps to reproduce     1. Step one.     2. Step two.      ### System information      ```     Paste here the output of the following command run on a terminal: inxi -xxxSc0 -! 31     ``` ```  With a *fed spooned* template like this, all of you can close issues on sight with absolute zero remorse.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: One problem with requiring the uuid is that the end user is (almost) never going to know the uuid or the author's name. It's not really something they should as a general rule. If we are going to require the uuid in the title and/or the author referenced in the description, we will need to provide instructions on how to find that information. Those instructions need to consist of more than just ```right-click -> about``` because at least some of the issues are going to be the applet not loading in the first place, which in turn means they can't open the about dialog.  On top of that, many of the people who report issues probably will not be repeat reporters (and may not even be familiar with github and bug reporting), so they will not be aware of the proper procedures, or how to obtain the necessary information.  Pull requests, on the other hand, will almost always be by someone who contributes regularly, so we can reasonably expect a lot more from them than the average end user.  Finally, I think it will be extremely valuable to use tags to organize the issues so that a developer can quickly check what issues are open against a particular spice. I know it will be a little extra effort at first, but I'm willing to put that effort in, and once it gets moving I think it will be much easier to maintain.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: > It's not really something they should as a general rule.  Its on the same page of the spice's page on the website. If they find their way on Github, the least they can do is know what they're reporting about.  Honestly, I am not liking the execution of this whole applet repo experiment. You guys at least need Github services tied into the website. It seems like you guys overhauled the CSS of the spices site, but didn't do anything about its technical issues.   Why not have the same functionality of the old site, but using this repo as a back-end? Then extend the UI features based off of a service interfacing with Github. I'm sure its not impossible to isolate a list of libraries that can cause damage like Gio, GLib, etc, and use regex to flag applets for malware checks. I think this whole process could have been more developer friendly, but wasn't because it was easier for Linux Mint.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: > It seems like you guys overhauled the CSS of the spices site, but didn't do anything about its technical issues.  Which technical issues are those, exactly?  > Why not have the same functionality of the old site, but using this repo as a back-end?  Sorry, I'm not really understanding how that will be any different from what is already happening. What functionality are you referring to?  > I'm sure its not impossible to isolate a list of libraries that can cause damage like Gio, GLib, etc, and use regex to flag applets for malware checks.  The problem is that many of those libraries are used extensively and are indispensable to many applets. As for auto-flagging malware, that is not really realistic. There are so many ways that someone could insert malicious code into an applet that could circumvent whatever checks were put in place. Consider anti-virus software - no matter how good it is, it still needs the virus definitions updated regularly because it is impossible to identify all malware through algorithms alone.  I know the current setup is not ideal from an applet developer's standpoint (many of the applets and desklets here are mine so I get it), but I don't really see a better solution.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: I think Lester made a good point in Cinnamon's [issues](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/issues/6130). This repo does rob developers of a degree of technical ownership. When I'm waiting for a prolonged period just to get a bug fix and some generic tooling boilerplate through, it seems a little absurd.  This is an overreaction to [security issue scares](https://www.reddit.com/user/flakka_mint) occurring earlier last month, and taking it out on developers is lame. LM didn't offer developers a way to upload new versions for two weeks. Then to go through this process feels like a chore, and an annoyance.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: > Sorry, I'm not really understanding how that will be any different from what is already happening. What functionality are you referring to?  What you did was add manual intervention on submission. That is not an "application". That is unnecessary bureaucracy.   > As for auto-flagging malware, that is not really realistic.  Google uses selenium tests for this kind of thing in Chrome. I think what would have been more appropriate is having two tiers of applets - "trusted" and "untrusted". Like, because I'm new I would be "untrusted" for a while, but then after a period of time my updates could be pushed through automatically.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: > This repo does rob developers of a degree of technical ownership.  If developers want to develop their applets outside of the Linux Mint organization, there is nothing stopping them. Having their work hosted on the spices website and available for download in Cinnamon settings has been a service that Linux Mint has offered for both the users and the developers. Unfortunately, over time the lax policies governing the use of that service have led to multiple complications, not and not just security issues, and so the policies had to be changed. If you wish to use those services, you should be prepared to live with the policies surrounding them. If you can't, or don't want to, you are always free to stop using the service, and have your code removed from this repo. Some have already (including Lester).  Part of the problem is that these applets are being offered through Linux Mint products and websites. From and end-user perspective, it's still coming from Linux Mint, and there are consequences to that. One is that the user will tend to trust what is downloaded because it comes (in their mind at least) from Linux Mint. Another is that when half the applets don't work, and some aren't even installable, that reflects badly on the organization.  > I think what would have been more appropriate is having two tiers of applets - "trusted" and "untrusted". Like, because I'm new I would be "untrusted" for a while, but then after a period of time my updates could be pushed through automatically.  That is actually how it works now, except that it's the developers who are 'new' or 'trusted'. There are some applet developers who have been around for quite a while, and are trusted enough that their code doesn't really need a review before being merged. Some of them have even been given push access to this repository, and I expect that that number will grow as time goes on.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: > Having their work hosted on the spices website  Github.  > From and end-user perspective, it's still coming from Linux Mint  I think this is what I disagree with most though. You guys assume users are not seeing that the software they are using is not coming from Mint. Published technically? I think anyone above an elementary level of cognitive abilities can see that Cinnamon spices is hosting third party content. Every applet ends with "by ____".

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: > Another is that when half the applets don't work, and some aren't even installable, that reflects badly on the organization.  This is 100% Linux Mint's fault. Your website never had filters by version, so the user experience suffered. I offered to help with the website development (would have for free), but was ignored. So really stop blaming the technical failures on applet developers - this is failure at the distribution level. And failure to provide an API that doesn't account for compatibility. This is why you guys forked from GNOME years ago, right?  > There are some applet developers who have been around for quite a while, and are trusted enough that their code doesn't really need a review before being merged  Look at the 71 issues I've closed on my ITM repo, because people need a groupable window list. All because of API breakage, or I wouldn't have even spun the project up. Then when you guys continue to act like the developers are the problem, its simply wrong. There should be more metrics to "trust" than time. That's not really fair.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: I'm don't want go any further into this discussion. Just a couple of notes. I won't reply to any comments to my comment.  > offered to help with the website development (would have for free), but was ignored.  clefebvre is in charge. He has a lot of projects going on simultaneously (KDE, Xfce, MATE, Cinnamon, Spices, etc.) and a lot of channels to contact him (EMail, IRC, GitHub, LinuxMint blog, Segfault, Slack, etc.) It's hard to catch, follow and remember every single comment. I don't think your offer was ignored on purpose.  > And failure to provide an API that doesn't account for compatibility.  In my experience Cinnamon is a DE, which doesn't break stuff with easy heart. They still use the old Mint-X theme by default! Some applets still work after 2-4 years. Some of the broken apps I saw were just broken, because they imported stuff they never used (e.g. binary clock desklet imported Calendar stuff and never used it). But at some point it's inevitable to break stuff (e.g. removing box pointers) without bloating your stuff. GNOME for instance seems to break their API with every release. Don't judge on that. I don't have much experience with other DE, so I don't have much to compare ;) Failures were made. That is obvious. And that's why it has been changed now. The whole process is very new to everyone. And there are sure things, which could be improved. And there are still things to come (OAuth) and will be improved. But it will grow and develop with time. New mistakes will be made as well. That's unavoidable. With every big change you have people, who say they liked the old system better or would have done this or that differently (e.g. as Ubuntu moved to Unity, Microsoft moves form Windows version to Windows version). That's naturally.   > You guys assume users are not seeing that the software they are using is not coming from Mint. Published technically? I think anyone above an elementary level of cognitive abilities can see that Cinnamon spices is hosting third party content. Every applet ends with "by ____".  A few years ago, when I started with Cinnamon (I was very new to Linux), I saw available applets online. And I thought they were from LinuxMint. Because the website said as well linuxmint.com. Only later I realized, that all this people offering those applets are not from LinuxMint, but pretty much everyone could upload there. As I said I was very knew to Linux per se. And I didn't knew, who belongs to LinuxMint and who not. And it's kind of frustrating, that stuff didn't installed or crashed. Also not everybody does understand English. They have to play Point&Click with the applets, if they want to know what those are doing.  > if LM is unwilling to compromise on features and developer input then I'm done donating to and using Linux Mint  LM is open to feature requests and improvements in my experience. But you can't expect every feature request to be implemented and done (immediately). (http://www.bartleby.com/17/1/62.html) They decided to do it this way on GitHub. It's knew and has some flaws. They have reasons to do this simple for several reasons. Having enough people to do spices as well is one of them. Spices is now a thing that needs more time to spend with than before. Time the developers would usually spend for one of the other projects or Cinnamon itself. Also you have to keep in mind. Even if you have enough people now, you don't know how long they stay. If some of them step back, you need other people do step in. (Looking at the long run.) I'm not saying that this is ideal as it is. I wasn't happy either as I heard at first, that I have to fork the whole repo with all it's applets to upload my applet. And there have been many complains since. But in the meantime I closed peace with this fact right now. (As a sitenote: Users asked for years to implement vertical panels. Now this is possible. Users also ask for years to have a Desktop grid in Cinnamon. It's something on the list for a while, but it needs time. Step by step.)  > I'm never taking my applets down though because you'll just fork them back up like you did with Lester's. Which is fine, but you're still hosting his code. So you only took his name down.  As far as I know Lester removed all his applets on spices. And I haven't seen anybody uploading them since. Let me know if I'm wrong with this.  > There should be more metrics to "trust" than time. That's not really fair.  Trust is a very complicated thing and very hard to define (speaking of setting "metrics" to trust). You can't set up a checklist and expect someone to trust you, if he checked everything on this list. (<- a lot of stuff can discussed about this topic and it can get very philosophical. Another reason, why I don't want to reply to answer comments to the lines I write right now)  Now to getting specific. Your last Pull Request was over 5000 lines (you squashed 3 applets in there). Even with a quick glance over it, you need some time for that. That's what I meant with "it's pretty knew to everyone".  We need to work out some rules. One of them will be, that it should be only 1 applet per Pull Request. That way most stuff will be merged faster. As clem said the beginning is rough and slow, but it will get faster with time.  I hoped I didn't offended or attacked anybody with the lines above. If somebody feels offended, it wasn't my intention. I'm sure every one of us (including me) is curious how this project will grow in the long run.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: No offense taken. I don't mind my code being reviewed - I think the main thing that triggered my rant was the stance of blaming developers, and defending the lack of efficiency. If there's an ITM issue opened here with missing information, I'm just going to ignore it.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: I never said, nor have I ever heard anyone else from the Linux Mint team say anything that would place blame on the applet developers for the situation that we're in. I'm sorry if my comments were taken that way. All my comments above were to try to explain why the decisions were made, and why it is the best course to take. The team certainly took the applet devs into consideration, and we tried to accommodate them as much as possible in developing the policies and procedures going forward, but at the end of the day, the needs and concerns of the end user take precedence.  > If there's an ITM issue opened here with missing information, I'm just going to ignore it.  I don't blame you. One of the issues we've been focusing on heavily is how best to handle bug reports and feature requests so that we can get the right information to you, the developers, without all the extra stuff that you don't need to worry about.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: That's good to hear then. Thanks for the clarification.  > at the end of the day, the needs and concerns of the end user take precedence.  I agree. It does seem odd though to develop policies over a malware concern that has no precedent for Cinnamon and to do it this aggressively. I remember the very next day after the security scare I mentioned above, applet upload functionality was disabled. It just seems like you guys wanted to prove the FUD spreaders wrong and went too far in the direction of control. That's fine for now, but I don't see it as being tenable long term - so I hope the team considers some of the suggestions as far as the website goes.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: @collinss  > Finally, I think it will be extremely valuable to use tags to organize the issues so that a developer can quickly check what issues are open against a particular spice. I know it will be a little extra effort at first, but I'm willing to put that effort in, and once it gets moving I think it will be much easier to maintain.  :heart:  Please do.    (I wrote a [client for the Labels API](https://github.com/mockturtl/squint) to help reduce this busywork.  Feature requests welcome!)

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: @jaszhix There were actually several reasons the applets were moved to Github. Security was certainly a big one. When the spices website was first created, security was not a big issue. Cinnamon was fairly unknown, and the potential payoffs of an attack based on Cinnamon technology weren't worth the effort. However, Cinnamon and Linux Mint are now very popular, and quite well known, and that makes them a target. The hacking that you refer to is evidence of that, but I believe there were other reasons Clem was worried about security as well. It also wasn't as knee-jerk a reaction as it seemed from the outside. There have been discussions about doing this for a while, but they couldn't be made public until action was taken because it would basically be an open invitation for someone to exploit the weakness in our applet system.  Another big reason for the move is that over time, the spices website has become bloated with old abandoned applets and themes that no longer work. This makes it much harder for people to find the good working ones, and reflects poorly on the applet developers, the spices website, and even Cinnamon itself. We could, of course, have taken the time to clean it all up, but if we just left the same system in place, it would have ended up in the same state all over again, but this time, it probably would happen even quicker.  On top of that, any time one of us wants to make a cool addition to Cinnamon, we've always had to weigh the risk of breaking api for existing applets against the value of the change we want to make. Sometimes we decide that it's not worth it, and the users miss out on the feature. Other times (vertical panels and removing the boxpointers were two recent examples) we decide the need or benefit outweighs the potential downsides of changing the api. In still other situations, we find a way to implement the feature, while still maintaining compatibility with older code by adding additional hacks and programmatic glue, but at the cost of code that is harder to read and maintain or that introduces unnecessary complexity (for example, switching over to the new xlet settings).  By moving everything to a central github repository, we solved all of that (or at least made it much easier to solve). We are no longer beholden to the api, because we can more easily be in communication with applet devs about upcoming changes in the api so you can adapt to it before the new version is even released, and even make the necessary changes ourselves if need be (such as for abandoned applets).

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: @collinss Thanks for elaborating on this. It probably seems like I'm complaining a lot, but they're mostly nitpicks and I really do appreciate the work that goes into making Cinnamon what it is. I know I'm not alone in that sentiment. I'm willing to work with the community here, and give you guys time to calibrate.

Name: Repo improvement: Add an ISSUE_TEMPLATE.md file
Comment_Body: Issue template added. Also updated CONTRIBUTING template. We'll see how it will work out and improve it, if necessary. I'm closing this for now. Suggestions for template still welcome.

Name: Icing Task Manager: Unable to use with LibreOffice
Comment_Body: Cinnamon version 3.2.7 Linux Mint 18.1 64-bit Icing Task Manager 4.3.1  16.json: http://pastebin.com/iva5YzZz glass.log: http://pastebin.com/jiERa6DR .xsession-errors: http://pastebin.com/30jEP1jp  Two instances: 1. Open LibreOffice Writer/Impress/whatever from the menu and you get the normal response: Libreoffice opens and the process shows up in the window list. However, when you type some text and save it, the active Libreoffice window disappears from the window list.  2. Open a Libreoffice document. The document opens but it does not show up in the Icing Task Manager window list.  The "Windows List with App Grouping" extension does not exhibit the same problems.

Name: Icing Task Manager: Unable to use with LibreOffice
Comment_Body: I was finally able to reproduce it thanks to jeweloper's steps [here](https://github.com/jaszhix/icingtaskmanager/issues/92). The problem is depending on how LibreOffice is launched, it will duplicate the app ID, so the script cannot tell one window from another. No, the original fork does indeed have this problem, though it applied a workaround that didn't work reliably.

Name: Icing Task Manager: Unable to use with LibreOffice
Comment_Body: I have similar problem but only regarding libreoffice base. Opening an existing database, 2 windows will normaly appear in "database.odb", 1. the odb container window, 2. the preferred form- or table- (opened by macro). Though libreoffice opens normally (2 windows), ice tea preview only shows the container window (1.)  May be it is a timing problem. If libreoffice opened I switch to to ice tea preferences changing e.g. the option "title" to "focus", the second window preview will be shown instantly.

Name: 0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus: Installing applets not compatible with vertical panel froze the session
Comment_Body: You can look for errors in both ```~/.cinnamon/glass.log``` and ```~/.xsession-errors.log``` files. You may need to add ```LimitSessionOutput=false``` under ```[debug]``` in ```/etc/mdm/mdm.conf``` to bypass the log size limit in ```.xsession-errors```.

Name: 0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus: Installing applets not compatible with vertical panel froze the session
Comment_Body: These logs just report things after I fixed my pb, i.e. after a reboot.   Can they survive a reboot? Is it the purpose of `LimitSessionOutput=false`  Given my only solution to reproduce the issue is to log in the UI Session and the only way I found to get out of the freeze is to hard reboot this might be useless to try to reproduce.

Name: 0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus: Installing applets not compatible with vertical panel froze the session
Comment_Body: They should stay persistent after reboots.  @pdcurtis @Odyseus

Name: 0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus: Installing applets not compatible with vertical panel froze the session
Comment_Body: Actually, neither log will survive a reboot. .xsession-errors is emptied when a new x-session is started, and glass.log is emptied when Cinnamon is restarted.  @DiWa51 Are you able to switch to a TTY? If so, you could make a copy of .xsession-errors with a different name from command line. This would allow it to survive a reboot, though even then, there is a good chance that there wont be anything there. Freezes often don't leave any errors, as they are often caused by valid code with faulty logic. (The increased cpu usage suggests that might indeed be the case here). They can be particularly difficult to find and fix. If you could find an applet that reliably reproduces the issue for you, that would probably help a lot more.

Name: 0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus: Installing applets not compatible with vertical panel froze the session
Comment_Body: @collinss Ah, my mistake. It seems at least for me my .xsession-errors is not clearing after reboots. I had to increase the log limit to see new errors after a while.

Name: 0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus: Installing applets not compatible with vertical panel froze the session
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @jaszhix & @collinss: I can reproduce what @DiWa51 is reporting with my applet ([0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus](https://github.com/linuxmint/cinnamon-spices-applets/tree/master/0dyseus%40SysmonitorByOrcus/files/0dyseus%40SysmonitorByOrcus)). If I try to place the applet into a vertical panel, I get the normal popup informing me that the applet isn't suitable for vertical panels and the system freeze.  This is the content of **.xsession-errors** at the exact time of the freeze.  ``` (nemo:4196): GVFS-RemoteVolumeMonitor-WARNING **: Owner of volume monitor org.gtk.vfs.UDisks2VolumeMonitor disconnected from the bus; removing drives/volumes/mounts  (nemo:4196): GVFS-RemoteVolumeMonitor-WARNING **: Owner of volume monitor org.gtk.vfs.AfcVolumeMonitor disconnected from the bus; removing drives/volumes/mounts  (nemo:4196): GVFS-RemoteVolumeMonitor-WARNING **: Owner of volume monitor org.gtk.vfs.GoaVolumeMonitor disconnected from the bus; removing drives/volumes/mounts  (nemo:4196): GVFS-RemoteVolumeMonitor-WARNING **: Owner of volume monitor org.gtk.vfs.MTPVolumeMonitor disconnected from the bus; removing drives/volumes/mounts  (nemo:4196): GVFS-RemoteVolumeMonitor-WARNING **: Owner of volume monitor org.gtk.vfs.GPhoto2VolumeMonitor disconnected from the bus; removing drives/volumes/mounts  ** (cinnamon-settings-daemon:4101): WARNING **: Name taken or bus went away - shutting down  ** (cinnamon-settings-daemon:4101): WARNING **: Name taken or bus went away - shutting down Terminated ```  Placing the applet into an horizontal panel works normally **but**, when I try to remove it from the horizontal panel, the system freeze with a similar error logged into **.xsession-errors**.  ``` cinnamon-session[4662]: Gdk-WARNING: t+478,68021s: cinnamon-session: Fatal IO error 11 (Resource not available temporarily) on X server :1.   ** (cinnamon-settings-daemon:4700): WARNING **: Name taken or bus went away - shutting down  ** (cinnamon-settings-daemon:4700): WARNING **: Name taken or bus went away - shutting down  (cinnamon-settings-daemon:4700): Gdk-WARNING **: cinnamon-settings-daemon: Fatal IO error 11 (Resource not available temporarily) on X server :1. ```  All this is very strange, because removing the applet from the panel on Cinnamon 2.8 (Linux Mint 17.3) or Cinnamon 3.0.7 (Linux Mint 18) works perfectly without any freeze nor errors/warnings logged anywhere. And when I switched this applet to *multiversion* a couple of months ago, the applet worked fine also on Cinnamon 3.2.x.  Just in case it's useful, my Cinnamon 3.2.x system is in a VirtualBox machine. It used to be a LM18 system with [this PPA](https://github.com/linuxmint/Cinnamon/wiki/Trying-out-the-latest-Cinnamon-without-building-it.) and then I updated it to LM18.1 through the updates manager (still using the same PPA and up-to-date).  @DiWa51  You don't need to completely reboot your system nor to completely remove your applets folder. You just have to go to a TTY (<kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>Alt</kbd> + <kbd>F1</kbd>), log in and then rename the **~/.xsession-errors** and **~/.cinnamon/glass.log** files (so they aren't overwritten on next Cinnamon start) and then rename the applet's folder (so the system would not freeze on next Cinnamon start). When you finish, just use the `startx` command to start Cinnamon. Remember to remove the applet from the panel after starting Cinnamon and renaming back the applet's folder.

Name: 0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus: Installing applets not compatible with vertical panel froze the session
Comment_Body: This is good news in a sense!  I knew there was a shortcut to actually switch to text mode but as I didn't know it by heart I couldn't search internet on my frozen computer, _from this you can guess I'm not in a VM_.  Just crazy how dependent we are on these machines ;)  Thanks for the info I'll try to reproduce it and grab the logs, but not in the following days unfortunately...

Name: 0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus: Installing applets not compatible with vertical panel froze the session
Comment_Body: Hello, everybody.  @DiWa51: I fixed the system freeze on my applet (0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus). A pulll request is queued to be approved. It seems that the error messages that I posted in my previous message weren't related at all with the system freeze produced by my applet. Because the next day, when doing tests, there were no errors at all when the system froze.  Although the system does not freeze when placing this applet on a vertical panel, it is still not compatible for panels of said orientation. And I don't know if it will ever be.  **P.S.:** It seems that the freeze was caused by the usage of the **Mainloop.timeout_add()** function without storing it and without *cleaning it* at applet removal.

Name: 0dyseus@SysmonitorByOrcus: Installing applets not compatible with vertical panel froze the session
Comment_Body: I'm closing this issue since it has been fixed. It can be reopened again, if the issue reappears.

Name: Show Desktop++: Preview of Desktop does not restore after Menu opening
Comment_Body: I know. But:  1. That's the wrong repo for that applet to report. 2. The Show-Desktp++ Applet has this issue as well.

Name: Show Desktop++: Preview of Desktop does not restore after Menu opening
Comment_Body: I see, why do we keep default applets in Cinnamon? Shouldn't they better be placed into this repo?

Name: Show Desktop++: Preview of Desktop does not restore after Menu opening
Comment_Body: No. The default applets are shipped with Cinnamon. You don't want Cinnamon ship without any applets preinstalled. They are installed in the root directory, so you don't delete them by accident.  All apps, which are here are optional and are installed into the local repo.

Name: Icing Task Manager: indicate active application
Comment_Body: @jaszhix ^^  @rik-shaw you should mention the author like I did above, so he can be notified.

Name: Icing Task Manager: indicate active application
Comment_Body: Hi, this was addressed in [another issue](https://github.com/jaszhix/icingtaskmanager/issues/67) a few weeks ago. Under Theme Settings in the applet's Preferences, you can either disable "Show active app indicators", or try "Use the panel launcher class for pinned apps". Depending on the theme, these options work. You can change the pseudo class for app buttons as well.   I was unable to find styling changes that everyone was happy with, so I gave everyone settings they can tinker with.

Name: Icing Task Manager: indicate active application
Comment_Body: @jaszhix thanks a lot for the reply.  With "show active app indicators" disabled and also the "Number display" set to "normal" (so a number is always shown for running apps), I can now tell the following:  1. Active application: hilighted by theme (in case of Arc / Mint-Y it is underlined with the hilight color) 2. Running (non-active) application: will have a number but is not underlined. 3. Non-running pinned application: is in the "taskbar", but no number, no underlining.  So that is basically what I felt was necessary and it does work well as you indicate.  Thanks again for the quick reply.  @clefebvre thanks for pointing this issue to @jaszhix : one thing I am confused about with the new consolidated github project for all the applets is how to find out who the author is?  So is there possibly a "README.md" that each applet should have to show this?  Or?  I tried digging around and I still can't determine that jaszhix is the author even though I know it is him :-)  Good work btw consolidating the applets, I think it will help in the long term.

Name: Icing Task Manager: indicate active application
Comment_Body: Yes, it's something we need to formalize. I was going to add metadata.json at the root of the spice like we did for themes, but we're also considering having that info within the files/... we're looking into that right now. It will be formalized eventually and documented and as much as possible we'll try to get authors to use their github username.
